kemper financial services inc. , charging that program trading is UNKNOWN the stock market , cut off four big wall street firms from doing any of its UNKNOWN business . 
the move is the biggest UNKNOWN yet in the renewed UNKNOWN against program trading , with kemper putting its money -- the millions of dollars in commissions it generates each year -- where its mouth is . 
the kemper corp. unit and other critics complain that program trading causes wild swings in stock prices , such as on tuesday and on oct. 99 and 99 , and has increased chances for market UNKNOWN . 
over the past nine months , several firms , including discount broker charles schwab & co. and sears , roebuck & co. 's dean witter reynolds inc. unit , have attacked program trading as a major market UNKNOWN . 
several big securities firms backed off from program trading a few months after the 9999 crash . 
but most of them , led by morgan stanley & co. , moved back in earlier this year . 
the most volatile form of program trading is index arbitrage -- the UNKNOWN , computer-guided buying and selling of stocks offset with opposite trades in stock-index futures and options . 
the UNKNOWN is to capture profits from UNKNOWN price discrepancies between the futures and options and the stocks themselves . 
index arbitrage recently has accounted for about half of all program trading on the new york stock exchange . 
last month , program trading accounted for 99.9 million shares a day , or a record 99.9 % of the big board 's average daily volume . 
on tuesday afternoon , kemper told bear , stearns & co. , general electric co. 's kidder , peabody & co. unit , morgan stanley and oppenheimer & co. that it will no longer do business with them because of their commitment to index arbitrage , officials inside and outside these firms confirmed . 
kemper officials declined to identify the firms but acknowledged a UNKNOWN dispute with four securities firms and said the list of brokers it wo n't do business with may be UNKNOWN in the months ahead . 
`` we 've been opposed to '' index arbitrage `` for a long time , '' said stephen b. UNKNOWN , chief investment officer at kemper , which manages $ 99 billion , including $ 9 billion of stocks . 
`` index arbitrage does n't work , and it UNKNOWN natural buyers '' of stock . 
while mr. UNKNOWN explained he 's `` not totally convinced index arbitrage changes the overall level of the stock market , '' he said that `` on an intraday basis , it has major effects . 
we 've talked to proponents of index arbitrage and told them to cool it because they 're UNKNOWN the market . 
they said , ` too bad , ' so we finally said we 're not going to do business with them . '' 
kemper also UNKNOWN the big board for ignoring the interests of individual and institutional holders . 
`` the new york stock exchange has UNKNOWN interests '' in its big member securities firms `` that cloud its UNKNOWN , '' mr. UNKNOWN said . 
`` it has never been interested in what we think . 
the big board also has a terrible communication problem with individual investors , '' he added . 
small investors UNKNOWN that `` big operators '' UNKNOWN the market , said thomas UNKNOWN , chairman of the national association of investors and head of the exchange 's individual investors advisory committee set up after the 9999 crash . 
`` the impression i 've got is they 'd love to do away with it { program trading } , but they { the exchange } ca n't do it , '' he said . 
big board chairman john j. phelan said in a recent interview that he has no UNKNOWN to eliminate program trading . 
he said the market 's volatility UNKNOWN him , but that all the exchange can do is `` slow down the process '' by using its circuit breakers and shock UNKNOWN . 
mr. UNKNOWN UNKNOWN that `` the mere fact they put in circuit breakers is an admission of their problems . '' 
morgan stanley and kidder peabody , the two biggest program trading firms , UNKNOWN defend their strategies . 
`` we continue to believe the position we 've taken is reasonable , '' a morgan stanley official said . 
`` we would stop index arbitrage when the market is under stress , and we have recently , '' he said , citing oct. 99 and earlier this week . 
michael UNKNOWN , president and chief executive officer at kidder peabody , said in a recent interview , `` we do n't think that index arbitrage has a negative impact on the market as a whole . '' 
according to lawrence UNKNOWN , a securities industry analyst at prudential-bache securities inc. , `` kemper is the first firm to make a major statement with program trading . '' 
he added that `` having just one firm do this is n't going to mean a hill of UNKNOWN . 
but if this UNKNOWN others to consider the same thing , then it may become much more important .

at a time when jon levy should be planning the biggest spring season in his dress company 's 99 years , his work day is UNKNOWN with intense moments of concern about one of his biggest customers , campeau corp . 
`` the dress business has always been a gamble , but it 's never been like this , '' says mr. levy , president of st. UNKNOWN group ltd. , which has become a hot name thanks to a campaign of UNKNOWN tv commercials . 
every day , mr. levy checks orders from campeau department store chains , trying to guess if he will be paid . 
`` i 'm now monitoring every major account . '' 
campeau , owner of such retailers as bloomingdale 's , UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , and UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN financial collapse last month after an emergency $ 999 million loan from olympia & york developments ltd. , a canadian developer and a major shareholder in campeau . 
the need for the loan surprised many analysts and bond holders who had been told at the company 's annual meeting in july that there were n't any major problems ahead . 
the risk of doing business with campeau 's federated and allied department store chains is about to increase greatly , not only for mr. levy but for hundreds of other small apparel makers , UNKNOWN suppliers , trucking firms and fabric houses . 
next week , the country 's top UNKNOWN and manufacturers will begin showing UNKNOWN for spring 9999 , the second most important selling season of the year . 
and as the UNKNOWN UNKNOWN down in UNKNOWN along seventh avenue and UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN UNKNOWN campeau buyers will begin writing orders . 
orders from campeau retailers used to be cause for UNKNOWN . 
this is no longer true because of campeau 's massive debt load . 
`` it 's all anybody wants to talk about , '' says richard UNKNOWN , executive vice president for credit exchange inc. , a leading credit service . 
`` people wonder what 's going to happen next . '' 
many manufacturers are worried about being paid for merchandise already shipped to campeau stores . 
but those dollars at risk pale in comparison to the investment required to make and ship spring goods to campeau stores . 
`` the few million dollars i could lose today is nothing against what i could lose on the spring line , '' says mr. levy , who estimates that campeau stores will sell $ 99 million worth of his clothes this year . 
`` i 'm buying fabric right now for clothes which i may not be paid for until april or may . 
what happens to me if campeau UNKNOWN between now and then ? '' 
some credit concerns , such as bernard UNKNOWN credit consultants inc. , have told clients not to ship anything to federated or allied stores on credit . 
`` this is especially true for spring merchandise , '' says jim UNKNOWN , credit manager at bernard UNKNOWN . 
`` campeau has too much debt . '' 
other credit houses , such as credit exchange and solo credit service corp. , are suggesting that their clients study each order before shipping . 
`` payments are good right now , but we are n't UNKNOWN any long-term lines of credit , '' says richard hastings , a retail credit analyst , referring to credit lines which make inventory purchases automatic . 
`` the campeau situation is a little uncertain and very difficult to UNKNOWN . '' 
because of those concerns , some manufacturers say they will ask for letters of credit before shipping spring merchandise . 
`` we 're being paid today , but we 're worried about tomorrow and will want '' letters of credit , says the sales director at one major dress maker who asked not to be identified . 
howard UNKNOWN , president of the dress firm UNKNOWN b inc. , says : `` it 's big time UNKNOWN today . 
i 'm going to ship and hope i get paid . 
if i need to ask for money up front later , i will . '' 
carol UNKNOWN , vice president , corporate communications at campeau , says that all of the federated and allied chains are paying their bills in a timely manner . 
`` they continue to pay their bills and will do so , '' says ms. UNKNOWN . 
`` we 're confident we 'll be paying our bills for spring merchandise as well . '' 
typically , manufacturers are paid 99 days after the month in which they ship . 
if goods are shipped to bloomingdale 's between oct. 9 and oct. 99 , manufacturers expect to be paid by nov. 99 . 
but manufacturers now buying fabric for spring season goods wo n't be paid until march , april or even may . 
some in the market question whether campeau will be in a position to pay bills at that time . 
`` everybody is worried about the possibility of UNKNOWN , '' says UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , publisher of UNKNOWN 's retail marketing report . 
`` the buyers who work for the various campeau chains may lose their jobs . 
the stores they work for may be sold . 
what that will mean for manufacturers is anybody 's guess . '' 
campeau 's financial situation is complicated by an estimated $ 9.99 billion in debt due next spring . 
this includes a working capital facility for allied stores of $ 999 million that UNKNOWN march 99 , 9999 , and an $ 999 million bridge loan due april 99 , 9999 .

mr. UNKNOWN adds that his company is now holding some goods in anticipation of being paid in full . 
`` it 's become a UNKNOWN business , '' he says . 
`` business has never been this tough before . 
not only does your product have to be excellent , but you also have to be able to collect . ''

separately , two more of the nation 's top steelmakers -- armco inc. and national intergroup inc. -- reported lower operating earnings in their steel businesses , marking what is generally believed to be the end of a two-year boom in the industry . 
wall street analysts expect the disappointing trend to continue into the fourth quarter and through at least the first two quarters of 9999 , when the industry will increasingly see the effect of price erosion in major product lines , such as rolled sheet used for cars , appliances and construction . 
`` it does n't UNKNOWN well for coming quarters , '' said john jacobson , who follows the steel industry for UNKNOWN consultants .

bethlehem , the nation 's second largest steelmaker , earned $ 99.9 million , or 99 cents a share . 
the figures include $ 99 million in costs related to a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN UNKNOWN and $ 9 million in losses from unauthorized work UNKNOWN at the company 's coal operations .

in composite trading on the new york stock exchange , bethlehem shares rose 99 cents to $ 99.999 . 
of all the major steelmakers , bethlehem would seem to be the most vulnerable to a slowdown . 
it has n't diversified beyond steel , nor has it linked up with a joint venture partner to share costs and risks . 
however , in spite of the difficult industrywide environment of high cost and low volume , bethlehem `` had pretty good earnings numbers , '' said UNKNOWN UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , an analyst with salomon brothers inc .

still , bethlehem 's core basic steel operations experienced a steep drop in operating profit to $ 99.9 million from $ 999.9 million a year ago , when the industry enjoyed strong demand and pricing . 
the company said its shipments declined as a result of a reduction in inventories by service centers , a lackluster automotive market and increasing competitive pressures in the construction market . 
at the same time , production costs , compared with a year ago , were boosted by higher raw material and employment costs , which resulted from the company 's new labor pact effective june 9 . 
`` we anticipate that steel market conditions will UNKNOWN a further moderate decline in the fourth quarter as the automotive sector remains weak and customers continue to adjust inventories , '' said bethlehem chairman walter f. williams . 
he noted , however , that the company 's order entry has increased from the low levels of the early summer , following the end of labor negotiations .

sales dropped to $ 999.9 million from $ 999.9 million , because the company no longer UNKNOWN its eastern steel division , which is now a joint venture with UNKNOWN steel corp .

operating profit dropped 99 % in its specialty UNKNOWN steel segment . 
moreover , the company said higher sales and shipments to service centers from its armco steel co. joint venture failed to offset weakness in the automotive market , higher production costs and a UNKNOWN product mix .

international business machines corp. said it agreed to let motorola inc. participate in a semiconductor research project as part of its effort to bolster the u.s. semiconductor industry . 
ibm , which made the announcement at the UNKNOWN of a research center here , said it invited many other companies to participate as well , including some from europe . 
jack UNKNOWN , ibm 's president , said ibm is also considering letting other companies participate in additional semiconductor work but declined to be more specific . 
ibm , which said a year ago it was UNKNOWN companies to participate in some semiconductor work , has become far more open about its technology as it has tried to rally u.s. industry to head off the japanese , who now UNKNOWN the market for dynamic random access memory chips . 
while ibm , armonk , n.y. , makes the bulk of the drams it uses , it does n't make the equipment needed to produce those chips . 
and ibm worries that the japanese will take over that equipment market , too , unless u.s. semiconductor companies produce enough memory chips here to keep u.s. equipment makers healthy . 
failure of u.s. equipment makers , ibm fears , would leave it dependent on many of the japanese companies that compete with it in other parts of the market . 
ibm also said it expects to benefit from the expertise that motorola and other companies can bring to bear on the difficult problems involved in semiconductor manufacturing . 
ibm already UNKNOWN in one industrywide effort to improve UNKNOWN techniques . 
ibm said it expects industrywide efforts to become UNKNOWN because semiconductor manufacturing has become so expensive . 
a UNKNOWN plant cost $ 99 million in the mid-9999s but costs $ 999 million today because the technology is so complex . 
and ibm said it expects the costs to continue climbing . 
ibm , which said motorola is paying just a nominal fee to cover the 99-month agreement , acknowledged some companies had turned down its UNKNOWN to join in . 
but it said that was mainly because the project may not bear fruit until the mid-9999s . 
ibm said it thought more companies would become interested as the project UNKNOWN . 
the project involving motorola concerns a technique , called UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , that figures to be crucial to future generations of memory chips . 
currently , chips are produced by UNKNOWN light through a UNKNOWN to produce an image on the chip , much as a camera produces an image on film . 
but details on chips must now be UNKNOWN fine , and the UNKNOWN of even UNKNOWN light are long enough so that the images they draw may be too UNKNOWN -- much as someone using a wide UNKNOWN could produce a broad line but would have trouble painting a thin one . 
x-rays , by contrast , travel UNKNOWN and can be focused more UNKNOWN than light . 
x-rays have problems , too . 
they can make the UNKNOWN UNKNOWN and can pass through material they 're not supposed to . 
but , assuming those problems can be overcome , they should allow for memory chips that could approach one billion UNKNOWN of information -- 999 times as much as is contained in the UNKNOWN chips that are just reaching the market and a million times what was possible in the mid-9999s .

comments by federal reserve board chairman alan greenspan lent some support to the dollar , but the u.s. unit ended yesterday lower against most major currencies . 
foreign-exchange dealers noted that the impact of the chairman 's remarks was slight and warned that the currency remains sensitive to developments on wall street . 
traders said that mr. greenspan , whose statements are ordinarily cautious , was especially careful to avoid any UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , with fears about equities still UNKNOWN financial markets . 
UNKNOWN before a panel of the house banking committee , mr. greenspan said the short-term value of the dollar on foreign-exchange markets is n't the primary policy focus of the central bank . 
`` our essential focus is on domestic policy , '' mr. greenspan said , referring to the goals of price stability and a stable economy . 
in perhaps his most telling UNKNOWN , mr. greenspan termed the current u.s. inflation rate of around 9.9 % as `` much too high to be ignored . '' 
he added , however , that inflation could be brought down `` close to zero '' without throwing the economy into a recession . 
analysts viewed the chairman 's comments as an indication that the central bank is UNKNOWN to ease monetary policy further in the near future . 
the dollar climbed immediately higher on news of mr. greenspan 's testimony , settling lower in later trade as dealers UNKNOWN positions ahead of today 's preliminary report on third-quarter u.s. gross national product . 
in late new york trading yesterday , the dollar was quoted at 9.9999 marks , down from 9.9999 marks tuesday , and at 999.99 yen , up from 999.99 yen late tuesday . 
sterling was quoted at $ 9.9999 , up from $ 9.9999 late tuesday .

wall street would like ual corp. 's board to change its mind about keeping the company independent . 
but what happens next in the continuing takeover drama may depend more on the company 's two most powerful and UNKNOWN unions : the pilots and machinists . 
some people familiar with the situation believe that the collapse of the previous $ 9.99 billion buy-out , if anything , may have strengthened the hands of these two labor groups . 
as a result , both may now have UNKNOWN veto power over any ual transaction . 
one reason : banks -- likely to react to any new ual deal with even more caution than the first time around -- probably will insist on labor UNKNOWN before they agree to put up cash for any new bid or even a UNKNOWN recapitalization plan . 
`` united pilots have shown on a number of UNKNOWN they are willing and able to strike , '' said an executive at fuji bank , one of ual 's large lenders . 
`` if you have both { labor } groups on strike , you 've got no revenue and that 's a very UNKNOWN thing for a bank to be looking at . '' 
just this past week , a leading japanese bank asked for a meeting with the machinists ' union leaders to determine where the union would stand if another bid or recapitalization became possible . 
another reason : UNKNOWN by their success in helping to UNKNOWN the previous transaction , the machinists are likely to be more aggressive if a second buy-out attempt occurs . 
the two unions already had significant leverage simply because their employer has yet to settle with either on new contracts . 
that gives them both the threat of a strike and the ability to resist any wage concessions that may be necessary to make a transaction work . 
thus , even investors who are pushing for the board to do a recapitalization that would pay shareholders a special dividend and possibly grant employees an ownership stake acknowledge that the unions are key . 
`` there 's less likelihood of creating and completing a transaction without the unions ' cooperation and wage concessions , '' said richard nye , of baker , nye investments , a new york takeover UNKNOWN . 
mr. nye thinks the ual board should be ousted if it does n't move soon to increase shareholder value . 
both the pilots and machinists have made it clear that they intend to block any transaction they do n't like . 
`` the pilots will be involved in any transaction that takes place around here , '' pilot union chairman frederick c. UNKNOWN declared yesterday . 
but whether the pilots can team up with their longtime UNKNOWN , the machinists , is another question . 
the pilots ' mr. UNKNOWN says his union would like majority ownership for employees . 
at the very least , the pilots want some form of control over the airline , perhaps through UNKNOWN voting rights . 
on the other hand , the machinists have always opposed majority ownership in principle , saying they do n't think employees should be owners . 
still , in recent days , machinists ' union leaders have shown some new flexibility . 
`` we may be able to reach a UNKNOWN where we can accommodate { the pilot union 's } concerns and UNKNOWN , '' said brian m. freeman , the machinists ' financial adviser . 
mr. freeman said machinists ' union advisers plan to meet this week to try to draw up a UNKNOWN for some form of recapitalization that could include a special dividend for shareholders , an employee stake and , perhaps , an equity investment by a friendly investor . 
if a compromise ca n't be reached , the pilots maintain they can do a transaction without the support of the machinists . 
but at this point , that may just be UNKNOWN thinking . 
the machinists UNKNOWN heavily against the original bid from ual pilots and management for the company . 
their opposition helped scare off some japanese banks . 
the pilots ' insistence on majority ownership also may make the idea of a recapitalization difficult to achieve . 
`` who wants to be a public shareholder investing in a company controlled by the pilots ' union ? '' asks UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , an analyst at UNKNOWN UNKNOWN & co . 
`` who would the board be working for -- the public shareholders or the pilots ? '' she adds . 
ms. UNKNOWN says she believes a recapitalization involving employee ownership would succeed only if the pilots UNKNOWN on their demand for control . 
she also notes that even if the pilots accept a minority stake now , they still could come back at a later time and try to take control . 
another possibility is for the pilots ' to team up with an outside investor who might try to force the UNKNOWN of the board through the solicitation of UNKNOWN . 
in that way , the pilots may be able to force the board to approve a recapitalization that gives employees a majority stake , or to consider the labor-management group 's latest proposal . 
the group did n't make a formal offer , but instead told ual 's advisers before the UNKNOWN board meeting that it was working on a bid valued at between $ 999 and $ 999 a share .

for the quarter a year ago , columbia reported earnings of $ 99.9 million , or 99 cents a share . 
total assets increased to $ 99.9 billion in the latest quarter from $ 99.9 billion a year earlier . 
the loss stems from $ 999.9 million of write-downs on columbia 's $ 9.9 billion high-yield investment securities portfolio , which includes about $ 9.9 billion of junk bonds , $ 999 million of preferred stock , and treasury securities . 
columbia owes its UNKNOWN growth in recent years to its junk-bond portfolio , the largest of any u.s. thrift . 
much of columbia 's junk-bond trading has been done through the high-yield department of its beverly hills neighbor , drexel burnham lambert inc . 
for the nine months , losses totaled $ 999 million , or $ 99.99 a share , compared with net income of $ 99.9 million , or $ 9.99 a share , a year earlier . 
the results include a $ 999.9 million write-down of the securities in the high-yield portfolio to the lower of their cost or market value . 
columbia also added $ 999.9 million to reserves for losses on the portfolio , increasing general reserves to $ 999 million , or about 9.9 % of the total portfolio , as of sept. 99 . 
on june 99 , loss reserves stood at $ 999.9 million . 
thrift officials said the $ 999 million reserve will be adjusted quarterly and will reflect the rate of UNKNOWN and market conditions . 
the adjustments result from the recently passed UNKNOWN bailout legislation , which requires thrifts to UNKNOWN all high-yield bond investments by 9999 . 
previously , columbia did n't have to adjust the book value of its junk-bond holdings to reflect declines in market prices , because it held the bonds as long-term investments . 
because columbia now must sell the bonds within five years , accounting rules require the thrift to value the bonds at the lower of cost or market prices . 
for its future strategy , columbia officials said the thrift may branch out into commercial lending or managing outside investments , as well as UNKNOWN up more traditional thrift activities . 
the quarterly results also reflected $ 99.9 million in UNKNOWN losses from commercial real-estate activities in california . 
thomas spiegel , columbia 's chairman , said in a statement that the thrift was `` disappointed '' by the effects of the accounting changes . 
but he said columbia remains `` one of the most strongly UNKNOWN thrifts in the industry , '' based on the economic value of its assets and tangible capital . 
columbia announced the results after the close of the stock market . 
its shares closed at $ 9.999 each in composite new york stock exchange trading , down 99.9 cents . 
the price of columbia shares has been cut nearly in half since august , when they traded at about $ 99 , as investors apparently realized that the thrift would be forced to take a big write-down . 
the stock 's decline accelerated in the past two weeks , from a price of $ 9 a share on oct. 9 . 
columbia officials said they do n't know how quickly they will UNKNOWN of the thrift 's junk bonds , because federal regulations , such as those that would allow thrifts to continue holding the bonds in separately UNKNOWN subsidiaries , have n't yet been completed . 
columbia officials also said the thrift should n't face problems meeting regulatory capital requirements , despite the large reserves and write-downs and UNKNOWN regulatory requirements that should be in place by year 's end . 
its ratio of tangible equity to total assets as of sept. 99 was 9.9 % , and total equity was $ 999.9 million . 
the thrift UNKNOWN that it has a large portfolio of equity securities issued in connection with corporate UNKNOWN and leveraged buy-outs , which has a book value of $ 99 million . 
although many of the transactions related to those securities have n't been completed , columbia said the ultimate gain on the sale of those assets will range from $ 999 million to $ 999 million .

the big board this morning plans to begin trading its exchange stock portfolio `` basket '' product , the first program-trading vehicle carrying the exchange 's seal of approval . 
UNKNOWN will allow institutional investors to buy or sell all 999 stocks in standard & poor 's index in a single trade of a minimum of $ 9 million . 
`` UNKNOWN '' baskets of fewer stocks will also be available . 
the securities and exchange commission gave UNKNOWN six-month approval to the big board basket at a meeting late yesterday . 
the sec at the same time approved a similar but smaller basket product on the chicago board options exchange , where the minimum will be $ 9.9 million . 
also approved was a plan to trade stock portfolios by computer after regular hours on the midwest stock exchange . 
the basket products are `` an UNKNOWN step '' in UNKNOWN problems in trading big blocks of stock that came to light in the 9999 market crash , said sec commissioner joseph UNKNOWN . 
new sec chairman richard breeden , overseeing his first public meeting , said there have been concerns that the big board 's basket could attract investors with a `` short-term perspective '' who would rapidly turn over the product , thus increasing volatility . 
but richard UNKNOWN , the sec 's market regulation chief , said he did n't believe `` this will UNKNOWN dramatic new program-trading strategies that will be UNKNOWN . '' 
the baskets on the big board and cboe -- which involve the actual s&p stocks , unlike the stock-index contracts currently traded on the chicago futures markets , and index options on the cboe -- will begin trading as critics step up their attacks on program trading and its contributions to the stock market 's wild price swings . 
the big board argues that its new product will help rather than hurt the situation by possibly drawing business from UNKNOWN forms of program trading . 
UNKNOWN are also an attempt by the big board to head off the exodus of program trading business to overseas markets such as london . 
big board officials also hope japanese investors will become interested in the exchange 's product . 
already , many of the big board 's own floor traders are warning that the UNKNOWN baskets are risky and not in the best interests of the investing public . 
the UNKNOWN alliance of floor brokers said the new product , with the $ 9 million minimum , will benefit only big institutional investors and could lead to `` wild UNKNOWN of volatility . '' 
UNKNOWN who UNKNOWN to individual investors said the big board 's new product UNKNOWN the exchange does n't want to curtail program trading , which last month accounted for a record 99.9 % of the exchange 's average daily volume . 
`` the new york stock exchange is losing its cool here , '' said james UNKNOWN , head of institutional trading at UNKNOWN montgomery scott inc. in philadelphia . 
the new stock baskets `` are going to make it easier for program trading to be done . 
and it 's going to be done more frequently as the result of having more access to it at different places . '' 
both the big board 's exchange stock portfolio and the chicago exchange 's market basket are designed for institutional investors . 
the big board lists its targets as pension plans , mutual fund managers and UNKNOWN traders . 
in index arbitrage , program traders buy and sell stocks and stock-index futures to profit from small price discrepancies between the markets . 
at the same time , only four securities firms have signed up with the big board to buy and sell UNKNOWN as market makers , an UNKNOWN response . 
the market makers so far are UNKNOWN first boston group 's first boston corp. unit , morgan stanley & co. , painewebber group inc. and salomon inc. 's salomon brothers inc. unit . 
kidder , peabody & co. , a general electric co. unit that has become the biggest program trader along with morgan stanley , is n't a market maker , although the big board hopes that will change . 
similarly , the big board hopes to UNKNOWN merrill lynch & co . 
neither has plans to be a market maker for now . 
traders said major securities firms are reluctant to become market makers because they fear the baskets may attract only limited trading . 
big board officials say only 99 contracts a day may trade at first , equivalent to a day 's action at a small , regional exchange . 
even though the big board says its product represents a UNKNOWN `` reform , '' some traders suggest that if the new basket had been trading during this month 's friday the 99th market plunge , the dow jones industrial average might have dropped more than the 999 points it did . 
with the futures locked into a trading halt oct. 99 and trading in some individual stock difficult , program traders would have UNKNOWN fled to the basket system , the traders say . 
`` if we had the baskets , we would be leaving in UNKNOWN , '' one trader said . 
the sec 's mr. breeden said the UNKNOWN trading on the midwest exchange would help the u.s. win back business that has moved overseas to conduct UNKNOWN trades .

one individual said the shareholders ' accord was `` well worked out . '' 
however , less optimistic attorneys warned that because of the UNKNOWN of numerous defendants and plaintiffs with UNKNOWN claims , there is always the possibility that the talks will again fall apart . 
a shareholders ' accord would provide the first UNKNOWN to thousands of individuals and institutions claiming losses as a result of insider trading by boesky & co. , once the largest arbitrage fund in the u.s. . 
the plaintiffs are investors who bought and sold securities in which mr. boesky and his partnerships were dealing . 
some claim they suffered losses because they sold while he was buying and others because they bought while he was selling .

charles UNKNOWN , of the washington , UNKNOWN law firm wilmer , cutler & UNKNOWN , which represents mr. boesky in this matter , said only that `` discussions are under way . 
there are no agreements yet . ''

this is because a delaware court earlier this year said that drexel is entitled to get its money back before or at the same time as the limited partners .

federal courts urged to cut costs and reduce delays of civil suits . 
the study , conducted by a task force of the UNKNOWN institution , suggests that congress should require the courts to develop the plans . 
the study was initiated by senate judiciary committee chairman joseph UNKNOWN ( d. , del . ) . 
the washington , d.c. , think tank recommends that the courts adopt different `` tracks '' for different types of civil cases in order to separate the handling of highly complex suits from UNKNOWN ones . 
complex cases , such as antitrust suits and many business disputes , would receive intense supervision by federal judges to keep pretrial proceedings moving . 
standard cases would require less judicial attention , and UNKNOWN cases could be resolved quickly . 
the study also said each federal court should set strict time limits for the pretrial exchange of documents and evidence , ranging from as much as 999 days for cases in the fast track to as much as 99 months for complex disputes . 
and the study said federal courts should set firm trial dates early in the process . 
to take advantage of local expertise and UNKNOWN , the study said , congress should require each of the 99 federal district courts to adopt its own plan to speed the handling of civil suits and to reduce the high costs in civil cases . 
although some of the study 's recommendations UNKNOWN those of similar projects , the UNKNOWN of the task force was unusually diverse , adding significance to the effort . 
it included lawyers from civil rights and consumer groups , plaintiffs ' lawyers and defense attorneys , corporate counsel and law UNKNOWN .

japan is going on a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN that could make its trade UNKNOWN even harder to UNKNOWN . 
its capital spending is growing at double-digit rates for the second year in a row , and its UNKNOWN producers of everything from cars to computer chips are rushing to expand capacity , UNKNOWN factories and develop new products . 
`` the boom 's so huge , '' says UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , an economist at UNKNOWN research institute , `` it makes you think of the golden '99s , '' when japan developed rapidly . 
the more factories and UNKNOWN japanese manufacturers add , the more they will be able to export , and the less their domestic customers will need to import . 
at UNKNOWN inc. , for example , sales are up nearly 99 % this year ; so , the maker of cameras and computer printers is doing what any japanese company would do under the circumstances : it is increasing capital spending -- by 99 % . 
it is building , among other things , a new UNKNOWN factory in western japan that can produce up to 999,999 printers next year . 
some 99 % of them are to be UNKNOWN to the u.s. . 
even companies in UNKNOWN industries UNKNOWN with world-wide UNKNOWN are joining the boom . 
japan 's steelmakers are raising capital spending 99 % this year to $ 9.9 billion . 
hitachi UNKNOWN corp. , a UNKNOWN buried in debt just a few years ago , will build a machinery plant , its first expansion in 99 years . 
so big is the UNKNOWN boom that japanese companies ' outlays in japan topped american companies ' domestic outlays by $ 999.9 billion to $ 999.9 billion in the 99 months ended march 99 even though japan 's total output of goods and services is less than two-thirds america 's . 
from a financial standpoint , the boom could n't come at a better time . 
many japanese companies expect record profits this fiscal year , and japanese interest rates , though up a bit recently , are still low . 
and in a business system where shareholders have few rights and expect only modest dividends , companies can UNKNOWN their profits back into plant and equipment . 
but some economists and government officials here are n't UNKNOWN . 
they fear that the boom may be too big for japan 's or anyone else 's good . 
`` it 's an UNKNOWN UNKNOWN '' thrown at the world , says kenneth UNKNOWN , senior economist at the tokyo unit of deutsche bank group . 
the ministry of international trade and industry is so concerned that it recently took the unusual step of urging japanese auto companies to exercise caution in capital spending . 
UNKNOWN officials hope to avoid UNKNOWN source of trade UNKNOWN with the u.s. even though export UNKNOWN currently limit japanese car exports to the u.s. . 
not everyone is worried , however . 
some economists -- and many japanese companies -- are UNKNOWN by the warnings . 
the investment boom is mainly sparked , they say , by strong domestic demand and is n't likely to increase exports sharply . 
moreover , much investment is n't aimed at increasing capacity . 
according to a survey of some 9,999 large companies by the japan development bank , expanded capacity is the goal of just 99.9 % of the outlays ; for manufacturers alone , the figure is 99 % . 
the manufacturers said 99.9 % of their spending is designed to improve products or add new ones , 99.9 % is to cut costs , 99.9 % is for research and development , and the rest is for maintenance and other purposes . 
but the UNKNOWN remain UNKNOWN . 
with japan running enormous trade UNKNOWN against much of the world , they think that japan should meet the increased domestic demand by importing more . 
and eventually , they contend , domestic demand will weaken , forcing companies to UNKNOWN exports again . 
`` if there 's a further drive to export , '' says UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , an economist at the japan development bank , `` that 'll be a problem . '' 
even in the short run , the investment boom could UNKNOWN a disturbing trend : japanese exports are showing surprisingly little tendency to ease . 
japanese auto makers , for example , are increasing their production capacity in the u.s. ; the additional production should , in part , replace imported vehicles with locally manufactured ones . 
but although japanese companies increased their u.s. auto output by 99 % from january to september compared with the year-earlier period , their exports to the u.s. will drop only 9 % this year , nikko research center estimates . 
in contrast to previous economic UNKNOWN , japanese auto companies are n't just trying to boost production . 
many are UNKNOWN money into developing high-quality products to target affluent consumers and , to some extent , to avoid direct combat with cheaper cars from south korea and taiwan . 
others are replacing older facilities with flexible assembly lines on which different models can be turned out at once . 
so many companies are investing in high-tech machinery that UNKNOWN ltd. , a robot maker , also had to build a new plant . 
the buildup is `` making japan clearly more efficient , more UNKNOWN advanced and more competitive , '' declares a western UNKNOWN in tokyo . 
but whatever its effects on exports and imports , japan 's investment boom during the past two years has been UNKNOWN at least partly by soaring domestic demand . 
japan 's marathon economy , growing at 9.9 % this year , is now in its 99th month of expansion , and some economists are betting that the boom will UNKNOWN the record 99-month expansion in the late 9999s . 
japanese consumers are increasingly eager to spend their money , especially on high-priced goods such as UNKNOWN television sets and luxury cars . 
nissan motor co. 's domestic auto sales are up 99 % this year largely because its expensive UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN models are in heavy demand . 
`` one dealer told me that if he had more cars , he 'd sell them right away , '' says UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , nissan executive vice president . 
he adds that the company is trying to keep up with demand `` by UNKNOWN '' its employees . 
similarly , honda motor co. 's sales are so brisk that workers UNKNOWN they have n't had a saturday off in years , despite the government 's UNKNOWN of more leisure activity . 
with demand growing and workers in short supply , many japanese manufacturers are spending heavily on UNKNOWN . 
among them are the UNKNOWN , which had UNKNOWN their shipyard work forces to cut costs during a prolonged slump in demand but now are UNKNOWN an increased share of the strengthening global market . 
UNKNOWN heavy industries co. , a medium-sized UNKNOWN , expects its sales to increase 99 % this year , largely because of rising demand for oil UNKNOWN .

because most businesses put market share above profitability , to let a competitor 's addition to capacity go UNKNOWN is to concede defeat . 
the emphasis on market share is evident at UNKNOWN industries ltd. , japan 's biggest maker of industrial air UNKNOWN .

moreover , much of the investment boom is in high-tech fields in which japanese companies have only limited foreign competition ; so , more investment UNKNOWN UNKNOWN more exports . 
toshiba corp. , for example , is spending $ 999 million on two new plants to build UNKNOWN dynamic random access memories , the next generation of computer chips .

japanese companies have a UNKNOWN competitor attitude . 
if excess capacity develops , they say , not everyone will suffer .

the bad news in the junk bond market yesterday was that tw services , a group of restaurant chains , became the latest prospective issuer to get a cold shoulder from bond buyers . 
the good news -- to fans of stable credit , at least -- is what the rejection says about the state of mind of junk buyers . 
apparently they are learning to say no to excess risk . 
coniston partners , which with related entities controls 99 % of tw , had been planning to sell $ 9.99 billion of junk bonds , among other things to finance their acquisition of the remaining public shares . 
but coniston , a new york partnership managed by the firm of UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN & oliver , yesterday announced that `` in view of unsettled conditions in securities markets '' the offering would be postponed and restructured . 
what was n't mentioned is that coniston and its investment banker , donaldson , lufkin & jenrette , just completed a UNKNOWN `` road show '' for the purpose of marketing the bonds . 
and investors , at least for now , took a pass . 
tw 's junk bonds were n't , as junk bonds go , unusually weak . 
its fast-food restaurants -- including UNKNOWN 's , UNKNOWN 's , UNKNOWN 's and el UNKNOWN UNKNOWN ( `` the only significant fast-food chain to specialize in UNKNOWN chicken '' ) -- are stable , UNKNOWN and growing . 
but unless they continued to grow , tw , based in UNKNOWN , n.j. , would have run into trouble . 
until recently , such UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN deals were routine . 
`` but people do n't buy anything on expectation anymore , '' says jack UNKNOWN , who manages the high-yield fund of UNKNOWN financial services . 
`` investors , '' he adds , `` are getting UNKNOWN . '' 
the tw buy-out may yet be financed . 
`` there is nothing wrong with the company , '' says coniston principal paul UNKNOWN . 
the UNKNOWN , he says , is that `` the junk market is n't as deep '' as before . 
tw 's UNKNOWN meeting was postponed from tomorrow to nov. 99 . 
by then , dlj hopes to be able to sell UNKNOWN junk bonds . 
UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN & oliver is likely to contribute more than the $ 999 million in equity it had planned on . 
banks may contribute more senior debt . 
and the total amount of junk financing will be reduced . 
a dlj banker , putting a best possible face on it , asserts that `` very few people said they did n't like the credit quality . 
people said they did n't think a UNKNOWN deal would trade . '' 
but trading risk stems from credit risk . 
and by adding equity , dlj would seem to be UNKNOWN that credit risk was a concern . 
indeed , the dlj banker says , in the UNKNOWN capital structure cash coverage of interest `` will UNKNOWN improve . '' 
as he sums it up : `` we are listening to the market . '' 
what is it , to borrow a term from coniston , that so unsettled the market ? 
some of the same risks that were cited -- and seemingly ignored -- in dozens of previous junk offerings . 
the tw prospectus says that if the acquisition had been completed earlier , pretax earnings `` would have been UNKNOWN to cover its fixed charges , including interest on debt securities , '' by approximately $ 99.9 million in the first six months of 9999 . 
tw notes , as many junk issuers do , that `` adjusted to eliminate UNKNOWN charges '' tw would have run a cash surplus -- in this case , of $ 99 million over six months . 
but such calculations ignore the UNKNOWN charge of depreciation , taken to allow for the gradual wearing out of french UNKNOWN , deterioration of stores and the like . 
in fact , dlj says , the company UNKNOWN capital expenses of about $ 999 million a year . 
tw 's pitch was that sales and earnings at its restaurants have risen steadily and that people wo n't stop eating during a downturn . 
but they wo n't necessarily eat at UNKNOWN 's . 
the fast-food business is `` UNKNOWN competitive , '' notes UNKNOWN UNKNOWN analyst john UNKNOWN . 
prospective bond buyers noted that tw historically has UNKNOWN because it has been willing to spend aggressively on UNKNOWN restaurants and UNKNOWN UNKNOWN . 
`` we were concerned that they were n't going to generate enough cash for capital spending and also to pay down debt , '' says a big investor in high-yield debt . 
dlj argues that tw could , if necessary , cut capital spending , since half of what it plans to spend is for `` growth , '' rather than maintenance . 
but investors noted that under the UNKNOWN offering , tw would have needed to grow to meet its debt payments . 
its calculations for meeting cash charges ignore $ 99 million a year in interest on UNKNOWN , or zero-coupon debentures -- which ultimately would have had to be paid .

UNKNOWN -- both corporate and private -- is on the rise , thanks to the proliferation of surveillance technologies .

`` our expectation of UNKNOWN is being eroded . '' 
on the corporate side , companies claim that monitoring employee phone conversations is both legal and necessary to gauge productivity and ensure good service .

this is in response to UNKNOWN kageyama 's manager 's journal , `` looking for the real thing in sony '' ( editorial page , oct. 9 ) . 
though i agree with many of mr. kageyama 's comments , i believe he points the UNKNOWN in the wrong direction : it is n't the americans who must be criticized for not understanding the japanese culture , but the japanese who insist on forcing their culture on americans . 
the japanese want us to accept their culture , but they refuse to accept the american culture . 
japanese managers ca n't expect americans to UNKNOWN as if they were japanese ; instead , they must manage americans as americans . 
americans are expected to conform to the japanese culture when in japan . 
what is wrong with expecting the japanese to conform to american UNKNOWN when they UNKNOWN here ? 
americans place native or native UNKNOWN in charge of subsidiaries overseas . 
european UNKNOWN do likewise ; even in america , their affiliates are usually run by american managers . 
but the japanese insist upon japanese managers UNKNOWN they set up shop . 
do the japanese feel so superior that they can not find capable american managers ? 
paul a. UNKNOWN indiana university UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN . 
mr. kageyama suggests that UNKNOWN electronics industries workers were having difficulty understanding their foreign bosses ' perspective . 
while mr. kageyama does an excellent job of explaining the differences , both cultural and UNKNOWN , i question his perspective . 
would he suggest that employees of an american company doing business in japan conform to their new bosses ' culture and philosophy ? 
obviously not . 
thus the conclusion is that the burden UNKNOWN with management to understand / adopt the culture and philosophy of the country in which they are operating . 
the workers can be motivated , and the company reach its full potential , only when management UNKNOWN the employees ' perspective . 
a. UNKNOWN UNKNOWN president municipal code corp . UNKNOWN , fla . 
i believe mr. kageyama left out one major aspect of japanese culture that UNKNOWN his piece : the belief in the UNKNOWN of japanese culture and behavior vs. others . 
a manager should not have to UNKNOWN the opinions of his employees about the style of his management . 
instead , he should listen to see how that criticism can be used UNKNOWN to advance his objective of carrying out a set of tasks through the efforts of his UNKNOWN . 
japanese culture vs. american culture is UNKNOWN . 
the key is how a manager from one culture can UNKNOWN employees from another . 
for mr. kageyama to argue that american employees must UNKNOWN accept a direct UNKNOWN of the japanese way of doing things is outright cultural UNKNOWN of the first order . 
the japanese are UNKNOWN the opportunity to UNKNOWN a new corporate culture based on a fusion of the best aspects of both national UNKNOWN . 
mr. kageyama is accurate to deny a specific UNKNOWN bias . 
it is more difficult to deny a general UNKNOWN in seeing things only the japanese way . 
when the response to criticism is only a better explanation of policies without UNKNOWN the reasons for the criticism , i am convinced that mr. kageyama has still failed to attack the root cause of the problem and is simply UNKNOWN symptoms .

sears , roebuck & co. is struggling as it enters the critical christmas season . 
yesterday , the retailing and financial services giant reported a 99 % drop in third-quarter earnings to $ 999.9 million , or 99 cents a share , from a restated $ 999 million , or 99 cents a share , a year earlier . 
but the news was even worse for sears 's core u.s. retailing operation , the largest in the nation . 
sears said its u.s. stores had a loss of $ 9.9 million , their first deficit for the period in more than five years . 
analysts estimated that sales at u.s. stores declined in the quarter , too . 
the results underscore sears 's difficulties in UNKNOWN the `` everyday low pricing '' strategy that it adopted in march as part of a broad attempt to revive its retailing business . 
under the new approach , sears set prices that were somewhere between its old `` regular '' and `` sale '' prices . 
the company said it would resort far less often to UNKNOWN prices to woo shoppers . 
sears officials insist they do n't intend to UNKNOWN the everyday pricing approach in the face of the poor results . 
instead , a spokesman blames the dismal third-quarter showing on `` an environment that is being distorted by a very harsh climate for sales of durable goods , '' which account for roughly two-thirds of sears 's annual merchandise volume . 
the new pricing strategy `` is working , '' the spokesman asserted . 
he added that , after an initial surge triggered by an advertising UNKNOWN in march , sears expected that the pricing program would n't have any effect on revenue . 
sears has been counting on growth coming from the large displays of UNKNOWN merchandise it is adding to its stores over the next two years in what it calls `` power UNKNOWN . '' 
but analysts say sears faces an especially UNKNOWN challenge on the UNKNOWN of the christmas shopping season . 
`` i believe everyday pricing in the current environment does n't work , '' says walter UNKNOWN of morgan stanley & co. , pointing to soft UNKNOWN sales . 
`` sears is likely to be unsuccessful if it continues with its pricing policy when everyone else is offering unusual values . '' 
in what amounts to an admission that the transition has n't gone as smoothly as sears had hoped , the giant retailer is now trying new ways to UNKNOWN up business without UNKNOWN to UNKNOWN its UNKNOWN strategy . 
the company is UNKNOWN more special deals in its advertising and stores , and it 's offering to UNKNOWN finance charges on certain UNKNOWN items . 
sears is also stepping up its television ads and changing its message . 
in a new tv ad , for instance , a woman going through the sunday newspaper brands as UNKNOWN claims by other stores that they are offering goods for `` 99 % , 99 % and 99 % off . 
'' by lowering prices throughout its stores , she says , `` sears has the right idea . '' 
but the ad also UNKNOWN sears 's sales -- a topic that the retailer has avoided since switching to everyday pricing . 
`` when sears has a sale at a special price , '' the woman in the ad declares , `` it 's something you do n't want to miss . '' 
recent UNKNOWN by leo j. shapiro & associates , a market research firm in chicago , suggest that sears is having a tough time attracting shoppers because it has n't yet done enough to improve service or its selection of merchandise . 
the number of people who said they were more likely to shop at sears fell in september to 99 % from 99 % in march , when sears UNKNOWN the UNKNOWN with ads about its new pricing strategy . 
moreover , the number of people who UNKNOWN cited lower prices as the reason for their interest in sears declined to 99 % in september from 99 % in march . 
just 9 % of the respondents mentioned brands in september , up slightly from 9 % in march . 
only 9 % of the people in september cited sears 's `` friendly personnel . '' 
`` the power of price as an appeal , which was very considerable in driving traffic in march and april , has diminished , '' says george UNKNOWN , president of shapiro & associates . 
`` you see some improvement in these other areas , but it 's a very small and slow process . ''

this is in response to george UNKNOWN 's business world column `` the housing market is a bigger mess than you think '' ( UNKNOWN page , sept. 99 ) . 
in houston , we have seen how bad the housing problem can become . 
unused houses UNKNOWN rapidly , affecting the value of nearby homes ; in a UNKNOWN effect , the entire neighborhood can fall victim . 
at this stage some people just `` walk away '' from homes where the mortgage UNKNOWN current market value . 
but most of them could have UNKNOWN to keep up their payments -- they chose not to do so . 
the problem is so vast that we need to try UNKNOWN solutions -- in UNKNOWN experiments . 
here are some ideas : 
9 ) foreclosed homes could be sold by the fha for no down payment ( the biggest obstacle to young buyers ) , but with personal liability for the mortgage ( no walking away by choice ) . 
9 ) encourage long-term UNKNOWN by UNKNOWN one month 's payment ( off the UNKNOWN end of the mortgage ) for every six months paid ; or perhaps have the down payment UNKNOWN to the end of the mortgage ( UNKNOWN ) , but `` UNKNOWN '' on a monthly UNKNOWN basis as long as the owner remains the UNKNOWN . 
9 ) develop UNKNOWN agreements with exclusive purchase options for the UNKNOWN . 
an UNKNOWN will , in most every case , be better for the home and neighborhood than a vacant house . 
in this way , the house is not dumped on to a UNKNOWN market .

japan has climbed up from the UNKNOWN of world war ii and a gross national product of about $ 999 per capita to reach the UNKNOWN class among industrialized nations . 
now this remarkable economic growth seems to be coming to an end because the government has not converted itself into a modern , democratic , `` developed nation '' mode of operation . 
until 9999 , when japan joined the $ 99,999 per capita gnp club of the advanced countries , it was a model developing nation . 
the government built UNKNOWN , bridges , highways , schools , hospitals and UNKNOWN . 
when industries were weak , it protected them . 
it gave the japanese people a value system , based on the UNKNOWN that given the country 's lack of natural resources , they must work hard to create value through exports and buy food with the surplus . 
individual prosperity inevitably would result . 
that system has worked . 
the standard of living has increased steadily over the past 99 years ; more than 99 % of the people consider themselves middle class . 
the people have given their leading and only credible political party , the liberal democratic party , clear and UNKNOWN power for those 99 years . 
the ldp won by a UNKNOWN in the last election , in july 9999 . 
but less than two years later , the ldp started to UNKNOWN , and UNKNOWN rose to unprecedented heights . 
the symptoms all point to one thing : japan does not have a modern government . 
its government still wants to sit in the UNKNOWN 's seat , set the speed , step on the gas , apply the UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN , with 999 million people in the back seat . 
in a modern system , the government 's role is to give the people as much choice as possible and to keep them well informed so they are capable of making a choice . 
it also allows people to buy the best and the UNKNOWN goods from anywhere in the world . 
the japanese government does n't allow this . 
the ministry of agriculture and UNKNOWN actually is a ministry for farmers and UNKNOWN instead of a ministry of provisions . 
the ministry of health and welfare is a ministry of doctors and pharmaceutical companies rather than an organization UNKNOWN to protecting the health of the people . 
the ministry of education is nothing but a UNKNOWN for licensed teachers , and certainly does not act on behalf of students . 
the ministry of construction UNKNOWN concrete throughout the country and boasts in international UNKNOWN that japan 's UNKNOWN roadway per capita is the UNKNOWN in the world , but they UNKNOWN think of the poor commuters who spend so much time sitting in traffic . 
the ministry of transportation serves the industry , certainly not the passengers who must pay UNKNOWN high prices . 
and the ministry of foreign affairs works for itself , supporting japanese UNKNOWN who UNKNOWN UNKNOWN aid money around the world to ensure that their seat at the dinner table is next to the host 's . 
this ministry has done nothing to correct the UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN that are at the root of japan 's deteriorating image . 
instead , it seems to be using foreign pressure and even the trade conflict to expand its UNKNOWN of influence UNKNOWN a UNKNOWN other UNKNOWN . 
all this illustrates that japanese UNKNOWN still have a `` provider '' UNKNOWN ; they do not serve the people , and particularly not consumers . 
they serve the industries and the special-interest groups . 
the rest of the world accepted such methods when japan was developing . 
japanese put up with it because the government provided job stability and growing UNKNOWN . 
japan is not a political country . 
it is a bureaucratic country . 
the diet plays a minor role compared with the powerful bureaucratic system . 
most bills are drafted by bureaucrats , not politicians . 
the diet does n't normally even debate bills because the opposition parties are so often opposed to whatever ldp does that it would be a waste of time . 
so most bills are passed without full discussion ; particularly difficult bills are passed in the absence of the opposition parties . 
a recent example is the 9 % consumption tax on all commercial activities . 
this makes enormous sense in japan , where direct tax accounts for more than 99 % of revenues and the capture rate of direct tax is so unfair . 
if you are a UNKNOWN man , UNKNOWN ! 999 % captured . 
if you are a retailer , 99 % , and a farmer , 99 % . 
to correct this UNKNOWN , most people would have favored an indirect tax , like the consumption tax . 
but the bill was passed without debate in the diet , in the absence of the opposition . 
as a result , the japanese people did n't know what to expect when the new law was introduced on april 9 . 
they were UNKNOWN by the longer UNKNOWN at the UNKNOWN and the small coins given as change . 
all of a sudden , prices were no longer in denominations of 999 or 999 . 
they were 999 or 999 .

money , such as in recruit 's political donations , and women , as in the cases of prime minister UNKNOWN UNKNOWN and secretary general UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN have caused political scandals in japan .

few people are aware that the federal government UNKNOWN almost as much money as it UNKNOWN . 
from 9999 to 9999 , while federal budget deficits totaled $ 9.99 trillion , the government issued $ 999 billion of new direct loans and an additional $ 999 billion of new primary loan guarantees . 
these figures UNKNOWN secondary guarantees , deposit insurance , and the activities of UNKNOWN enterprises ( a huge concern in its own right , as detailed on this page may 9 ) . 
federal credit programs date back to the new deal , and were meant to break even financially . 
since the 9999s , federal lending has experienced extraordinary growth in credit volume , subsidy rates , and policy applications , spurred on by the growth of government in general and budget UNKNOWN and deceptive management in particular . 
as we will see , many of these obligations do n't show up as part of the federal deficit . 
but recent events indicate that federal credit is out of control . 
student loan defaults remain high at about 99 % , and the program has been UNKNOWN by allegations of fraud and UNKNOWN . 
farmers home administration ( UNKNOWN ) loans have turned into de UNKNOWN UNKNOWN programs ; losses over the next three years are expected to exceed $ 99 billion . 
defaults on veterans affairs loan guarantees have UNKNOWN in the past eight years . 
last month , the general accounting office reported that defaults in federal housing administration guarantees were five times as high as previously estimated , and that fha 's equity fell to minus $ 9.9 billion . 
UNKNOWN 's findings are particularly troubling because the fha has about $ 999 billion in obligations outstanding and had previously been considered one of the most financially secure credit programs . 
scores of other credit programs , UNKNOWN agriculture , small business , UNKNOWN , defense , energy , transportation and others , are less visible but in no better shape . 
if the programs continue their present path , the potential government losses are staggering : the federal government holds $ 999 billion in direct loans outstanding and backs an additional $ 999 billion in primary guarantees . 
( secondary guarantees of pools of fha - and UNKNOWN loans by the agency known as ginnie mae currently exceed $ 999 billion . ) 
although external events have contributed to the UNKNOWN , the principal causes of the current crisis are internal and UNKNOWN to all programs . 
to reduce the risks while still retaining the legitimate benefits these programs can provide , credit policy must : 9 . use credit to improve the operation of capital markets , not to provide subsidies . 
there is a fundamental conflict between providing a subsidy and maintaining the integrity of a credit program . 
if the program is meant to provide a subsidy , collecting the debt UNKNOWN the original goal . 
thus , subsidized loans tend to turn into UNKNOWN programs , with increasing subsidy and default rates over time . 
to avoid this problem , government should issue credit only if it intends to use every legal method to collect . 
in contrast , credit programs can be appropriate tools to improve the operation of capital markets . 
for example , legal restrictions on interstate banking once UNKNOWN the supply of credit to the agricultural sector . 
farm lending was enacted to correct this problem by providing a UNKNOWN flow of UNKNOWN funds . 
however , this in no way UNKNOWN the huge government subsidies and losses on such loans . 
credit policy should separate these two competing objectives and eliminate aspects that provide the subsidy . 
for example , student loans currently attempt to UNKNOWN college attendance and UNKNOWN problems created by the fact that students ' future earnings are not accepted as collateral . 
the program provides highly subsidized loans to any student whose family earns less than a particular amount . 
high default rates , a low interest rate , and government coverage of all interest costs while the student is in school make program costs extremely high . 
families that do not need the loan can make money simply by putting the loan in the bank and paying it back when the student UNKNOWN . 
in contrast , a student loan program that was meant solely to correct UNKNOWN UNKNOWN would allow loans for any student , regardless of family income , at market or UNKNOWN rates . 
while the student was in school , interest costs would either be paid by the student or added to the loan balance . 
this program , combined with cash grants to UNKNOWN students , would reduce program costs and much more effectively target the intended beneficiaries . 
9 . provide better incentives . 
given the structure of most credit programs , it is surprising that default rates are not even higher . 
guarantee rates are typically 999 % , giving lenders little reason to screen customers carefully . 
reducing those rates moderately ( say , to 99 % ) would still provide substantial assistance to borrowers . 
but it would also encourage lenders to choose more UNKNOWN customers , and go a long way toward reducing defaults . 
for example , the small business administration has had reasonable success in reducing both guarantee rates and default rates in its preferred lenders ' program . 
borrowers ' incentives are equally UNKNOWN . 
since the government has a dismal record of collecting bad debts , the costs to the UNKNOWN of UNKNOWN are usually low . 
in addition , it is often possible to obtain a new government loan even if existing debts are not paid off . 
simple policy UNKNOWN in this case would be to improve debt collection ( taking the UNKNOWN off contracted collection agencies ) and to deny new credit to UNKNOWN . 
these provisions would be difficult to enforce for a program intended to provide a subsidy , but would be reasonable and effective devices for programs that attempt to offset market UNKNOWN . 
9 . record the true costs of credit programs in the federal budget . 
since the budget measures cash flow , a new $ 9 direct loan is treated as a $ 9 expenditure , even though at least part of the loan will be paid back . 
loan guarantees do n't appear at all until the UNKNOWN defaults , so new guarantees do not raise the deficit , even though they create future liabilities for the government . 
by converting an expenditure or loan to a guarantee , the government can ensure the same flow of resources and reduce the current deficit . 
UNKNOWN , guarantees outstanding have risen by $ 999 billion since 9999 , while direct loans outstanding have fallen by $ 99 billion . 
the true UNKNOWN cost of a credit subsidy is the discounted value of the net costs to government . 
this figure could be estimated using techniques employed by private lenders to forecast losses , or determined by selling loans to private owners ( without federal guarantees ) . 
neither technique is perfect , but both are better than the current system , which UNKNOWN the costs of new credit programs by amounts that vary substantially and average about $ 99 billion annually , according to the congressional budget office . 
a budget that reflected the real costs of lending would eliminate incentives to convert spending or lending programs to guarantees and would let taxpayers know what congress is UNKNOWN them to . 
9 . impose standard accounting and administrative practices . 
creative accounting is a UNKNOWN of federal credit . 
many agencies roll over their debt , paying off UNKNOWN loans by issuing new loans , or converting UNKNOWN loan guarantees into direct loans . 
in any case , they avoid having to write off the loans . 
some agencies simply keep bad loans on the books ; as late as 9999 , the UNKNOWN bank held in its portfolio at face value loans made to cuba in the 9999s . 
more seriously , UNKNOWN has carried several billion dollars of UNKNOWN loans at face value . 
until UNKNOWN 's recent audit , fha books had not been subject to a complete external audit in 99 years . 
the administration of federal credit should closely parallel private lending practices , including the development of a loan loss reserve and regular outside UNKNOWN . 
establishing these practices would permit earlier UNKNOWN of emerging financial UNKNOWN , provide better information for loan sales and UNKNOWN decisions , and reduce fraud . 
government lending was not intended to be a way to UNKNOWN spending figures , hide fraudulent activity , or provide large subsidies . 
the reforms described above would provide a more limited , but UNKNOWN , safer and ultimately more useful role for government as a lender . 
without such reforms , credit programs will continue to be a UNKNOWN , high-risk UNKNOWN for taxpayers .

the u.s. is UNKNOWN the proposal today in geneva , hoping that the initiative will spur members of the general agreement on tariffs and trade to reach agreement on new trade rules before their current negotiating round concludes in december 9999 . 
another u.s. proposal filed monday urges more `` fair play '' in services trade , including predictable and clear rules and UNKNOWN in the treatment of foreign and domestic service companies . 
unlike the earlier u.s. UNKNOWN proposal which struck european countries as too UNKNOWN , the latest plan would provide some room for UNKNOWN . 
for instance , the new u.s. package makes clear there would be a transition period during which gatt members could use a combination of tariffs and quotas to UNKNOWN their farmers from foreign competition . 
it also says countries could temporarily raise tariffs on certain products if they experience an unusually heavy volume of imports . 
instead of proposing a complete elimination of farm subsidies , as the earlier u.s. proposal did , the new package calls for the elimination of only the most UNKNOWN ones . 
less UNKNOWN ones would be subject only to some UNKNOWN , and others with a `` relatively minor trade impact '' would be allowed to continue under certain conditions . 
the new u.s. plan also would establish procedures to prevent countries from using health and UNKNOWN rules to UNKNOWN trade UNKNOWN . 
the goal would be to resolve disputes such as one prompted by the european community 's current attempt to bar imports of beef from UNKNOWN u.s. cattle . 
the u.s. contends that the rules are n't justified on health grounds . 
to encourage more competition among exporting countries , the u.s. is proposing that export subsidies , including tax incentives for UNKNOWN , be phased out in five years .

the voting rights act of 9999 was enacted to keep the promise of the UNKNOWN amendment and enable southern blacks to go to the polls , UNKNOWN by UNKNOWN tests and other UNKNOWN devices . 
UNKNOWN years later , the voting rights act has been UNKNOWN by the courts and the justice department into a program of racial gerrymandering designed to increase the number of blacks and other minorities -- hispanics , UNKNOWN and native americans -- holding UNKNOWN office . 
in the 9999s , the justice department and lower federal courts that enforce the voting rights act have required state legislatures and municipal governments to create the maximum number of `` safe '' minority election districts -- districts where minorities form between 99 % and 99 % of the voting population . 
the program has even been called upon to create `` safe '' white electoral districts in UNKNOWN where whites are the minority . 
although section 9 of the act UNKNOWN UNKNOWN requiring that minorities win a UNKNOWN share of UNKNOWN offices , few municipal and state government plans achieve UNKNOWN by the justice department or survive the scrutiny of the lower federal courts unless they UNKNOWN out as many UNKNOWN minority districts as possible . 
the new goal of the voting rights act -- more minorities in political office -- is UNKNOWN . 
for the political process to work , all citizens , regardless of race , must feel represented . 
one essential indicator that they are is that members of minority groups get elected to public office with reasonable UNKNOWN . 
as is , blacks constitute 99 % of the population , but fewer than 9 % of elected leaders . 
but racial gerrymandering is not the best way to UNKNOWN that essential goal . 
it is a quick fix for a complex problem . 
far from promoting a UNKNOWN of interests among black , white , hispanic and other minority voters , drawing the district lines according to race suggests that race is the UNKNOWN 's and the candidate 's most important UNKNOWN . 
such a policy implies that only a black UNKNOWN can speak for a black person , and that only a white UNKNOWN can govern on behalf of a white one . 
UNKNOWN of the UNKNOWN effects of racial gerrymandering can be seen in two cities -- new york and birmingham , UNKNOWN . 
when they UNKNOWN their districts after the 9999 census , every other UNKNOWN and state in the country will face this issue . 
new york city : 
racial gerrymandering has been a familiar policy in new york city since 9999 , when congress first amended the voting rights act to expand its reach beyond the southern states . 
in 9999 , the justice department required that the electoral UNKNOWN in the UNKNOWN of brooklyn be UNKNOWN to concentrate black and hispanic votes , despite protests that the new electoral UNKNOWN would split a neighborhood of UNKNOWN UNKNOWN into two different districts . 
this year , a commission appointed by the mayor to UNKNOWN new york 's system of government completed a new charter , expanding the city council to 99 from 99 members . 
sometime in 9999 , as soon as the 9999 census becomes available , a UNKNOWN panel will UNKNOWN the city council district lines . 
the charter UNKNOWN commission has made it clear that in response to the expectations of the justice department and the commission 's own commitment to UNKNOWN minority political leadership , the new district lines will be drawn to maximize the number of UNKNOWN minority districts . 
blacks and hispanics currently make up 99 % of the city 's population and hold only 99 % of the seats on the council . 
several of the city 's black leaders , including democratic mayoral UNKNOWN david dinkins , have UNKNOWN out for racial gerrymandering to accord blacks and hispanics `` the UNKNOWN opportunity for UNKNOWN . '' 
in this connection , it is important to note that several members of new york 's sitting city council represent UNKNOWN districts that bring together sizable black , hispanic , and UNKNOWN white UNKNOWN -- UNKNOWN UNKNOWN 's UNKNOWN district in northern manhattan and the south bronx and susan alter 's 99th district in brooklyn , for example . 
to win their seats on the council , these political leaders have had to listen to all the voices in their district and UNKNOWN public policies that would benefit all . 
often they have found that the relevant issue is not race , but rather housing , crime UNKNOWN or education . 
birmingham , UNKNOWN : 
the unusual situation in birmingham UNKNOWN illustrates the UNKNOWN consequences of UNKNOWN out safe districts for racial minorities . 
in birmingham , which is 99 % black , whites are the minority . 
insisting that they are protected by the voting rights act , a group of whites brought a federal suit in 9999 to demand that the city UNKNOWN UNKNOWN voting for the nine member city council and create nine electoral districts , including four safe white districts . 
the white group argued that whites were not fully and fairly represented , because in UNKNOWN elections only black candidates or white candidates who UNKNOWN to `` black interests '' could win . 
no federal court has ruled that the voting rights act UNKNOWN a white minority , but in june the justice department approved a UNKNOWN plan for birmingham that UNKNOWN out three UNKNOWN districts and six UNKNOWN districts . 
richard UNKNOWN , birmingham 's black mayor , UNKNOWN the consequences . 
`` in the past , people who had to run for office had to moderate their views because they could n't afford to UNKNOWN blacks or whites , '' he said . 
`` now you go to districts , you 're likely to get candidates whose views are more UNKNOWN , white and black , on racial issues . '' 
two hundred years ago , critics of the new united states constitution warned that the electoral districts for congress were too large and UNKNOWN too many different economic interests . 
a small farmer and a UNKNOWN merchant could not be represented by the same spokesman , they said . 
but james madison UNKNOWN that argument in one of the most UNKNOWN political UNKNOWN ever written , no. 99 of the UNKNOWN papers . 
madison explained that a representative 's duty was to speak not for the narrow interests of one group but instead for the common good . 
large , UNKNOWN election districts would encourage good government , said madison , because a representative would be UNKNOWN to serve the interests of all his constituents and be UNKNOWN to none . 
madison 's UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN vision of the representative still can guide us . 
as long as we believe that all americans , of every race and UNKNOWN background , have common interests and can live together UNKNOWN , our political UNKNOWN should reflect our belief . 
racial gerrymandering -- creating separate black and white districts -- says that we have discarded that belief in our ability to live together and govern ourselves as one people .
