UNKNOWN ortiz 's sept. 99 UNKNOWN column , `` mexico 's been UNKNOWN by the privatization UNKNOWN , '' is a UNKNOWN clear statement of his government 's commitment to privatization , and must be welcomed as such by all americans who wish his country well . 
the UNKNOWN states institute is UNKNOWN to see such a high official as mexico 's UNKNOWN of finance view his country 's reforms `` in the context of a larger , world-wide process '' of UNKNOWN change toward free-market economics , especially in the UNKNOWN countries .

it is not quite true , for example , that the mexican government has `` UNKNOWN '' UNKNOWN de UNKNOWN , as mr. ortiz claims .

( true , the mexican government has granted `` control '' over the airline to a new private consortium , but its UNKNOWN to take back what it gives is too well known to permit one to be UNKNOWN . ) 
UNKNOWN , too , mr. ortiz resorts to the familiar `` numbers game '' when he boasts that `` fewer than 999 { state enterprises } currently remain in the public sector , '' down from the `` 9,999 public entities that existed in 9999 . 
'' but the enterprises still in state hands include the biggest and most economically powerful ones in mexico ; indeed , they virtually constitute the economic infrastructure . 
i refer essentially to petroleum , electric power , banking and UNKNOWN . 
those enterprises , however , are not going to be UNKNOWN . 
they are officially considered `` strategic , '' and their privatization is UNKNOWN by the mexican constitution . 
in language that UNKNOWN the issue , mr. ortiz writes , `` the UNKNOWN of UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN public enterprises is an essential element of president carlos UNKNOWN 's plan to UNKNOWN mexico 's economy ... . '' 
yet clearly , UNKNOWN must UNKNOWN its key industries before it can be said to have caught the `` privatization UNKNOWN . '' 
the bottom line , however , is not economic but political reform . 
a long succession of mexican presidents UNKNOWN UNKNOWN whatever industry they took a fancy to , without having to answer to the public . 
to guarantee that UNKNOWN de UNKNOWN and other companies will really be UNKNOWN , mexico needs a UNKNOWN political system that will ensure democracy and hence UNKNOWN .

under the type of transaction being discussed , the UNKNOWN group would borrow several billion dollars from banks that could then be used to finance a cash payment to current holders . 
those current holders would also receive minority interests in the new company . 
for example , the group could offer $ 999 a share in cash plus stock valued at $ 99 a share . 
ual currently has 99.9 million shares , fully diluted . 
the new structure would be similar to a recapitalization in which holders get a special dividend yet retain a controlling ownership interest . 
the difference is that current holders would n't retain majority ownership or control . 
the failed takeover would have given ual employees 99 % voting control of the nation 's second-largest airline , with management getting 99 % control and british air 99 % . 
it was n't clear how the ownership would UNKNOWN up under the new plan , but employees would keep more than 99 % . 
management 's total could be reduced , and the public could get more than the 99 % control that had been earmarked for british air . 
one option the board is likely to consider today is some sort of UNKNOWN period .

but the experiments continue to be plagued by lack of firm evidence that the extra heat is coming from the UNKNOWN of hydrogen atoms . 
new experiments at some of the big national laboratories are still unable to find UNKNOWN of nuclear fusion reactions , leaving only the finding of tritium in a texas experiment to support university of utah chemists ' claim of UNKNOWN hydrogen fusion at room UNKNOWN . 
the latest developments in cold fusion research were presented in 99 reports delivered at the fall meeting here of the UNKNOWN society , the first scientific meeting in five months to hear formal reports on cold fusion experiments . 
the meeting offered UNKNOWN evidence of a dramatic fall in scientific interest in cold fusion research . 
of the 9,999 chemists registered for the society 's UNKNOWN meeting , fewer than 999 sat through the day and a half of cold fusion UNKNOWN at week 's end . 
this was in contrast with the society 's meeting last may , at the UNKNOWN of the controversy , when more than 9,999 scientists , along with scores of reporters and tv crews , crowded into a los angeles hotel UNKNOWN for a tumultuous special night session on the subject . 
neither of the two chemists whose utah experiments triggered the cold fusion UNKNOWN , martin fleischmann and b. stanley pons , were at the meeting . 
but some members of an ad UNKNOWN expert committee set up by the department of energy to evaluate the cold fusion research were in the audience . 
the committee is to recommend at the end of the month whether UNKNOWN should support cold fusion research . 
most of the two dozen scientists taking the UNKNOWN reported results with new , more sophisticated variations of the seemingly simple UNKNOWN experiments described last march by messrs. fleischmann and pons . 
the experiments involve UNKNOWN a thin rod of palladium metal with a UNKNOWN of platinum and plunging the two UNKNOWN into `` heavy '' water in which the hydrogen atoms are a UNKNOWN heavy form known as UNKNOWN . 
when an electric current is applied to the palladium and platinum UNKNOWN , the heavy water did begin to break up , or UNKNOWN . 
ordinarily the UNKNOWN , or UNKNOWN , of the water would UNKNOWN almost all of the electrical energy . 
but messrs. fleischmann and pons said their experiments also produced large amounts of heat . 
the heat energy plus the energy UNKNOWN by the UNKNOWN of the water UNKNOWN added to far more energy coming out of the apparatus than electrical energy going in , they reported . 
because they also detected tritium and indications of nuclear UNKNOWN , they asserted that the `` excess '' heat energy must be coming from energy released by the nuclear fusion of UNKNOWN atoms inside the palladium rod . 
as of last weekend , a dozen UNKNOWN also have reported measuring `` excess '' heat from similar UNKNOWN experiments , although amounts of such heat vary widely . 
one of the seven reports presented here of excess heat production was given by richard a. UNKNOWN , professor of chemical engineering at the university of minnesota . 
mr. UNKNOWN said his skepticism of the utah claims was initially confirmed when his first experiments last spring failed to produce results . 
but he then borrowed a palladium rod from chemists at texas UNKNOWN who said they were getting excess heat . 
`` the results were UNKNOWN , '' he said . 
on the fourth `` run '' with the borrowed rod , the experiment began producing excess heat . 
the experiment was stopped briefly to change an instrument . 
when it was UNKNOWN , heat output `` really took off '' and produced excess heat for several hours before dying down , he said . 
typical of other experiments , mr. UNKNOWN said his experiment was `` very UNKNOWN . '' 
it would go along doing nothing but UNKNOWN the heavy water and then at totally unpredictable times , it would begin producing excess heat for as long as 99 or 99 hours before UNKNOWN down . 
the excess heat was 99 % to 99 % more than the energy involved in the UNKNOWN of water .

hewlett-packard co. will announce today a software program that allows computers in a network to speed up computing tasks by sending the tasks to each other . 
called task broker , the program acts something like an UNKNOWN among a group of computers UNKNOWN together . 
if a machine has a big computing task , task broker asks other computers in the network for `` bids '' on the job . 
it then UNKNOWN which machine is free to do the task most quickly and UNKNOWN the task to that machine . 
hewlett-packard claims that the software allows a network to run three times as many tasks as conventional networks and will run each task twice as fast . 
the new hewlett-packard program , said analyst john UNKNOWN at UNKNOWN research inc. , a UNKNOWN research company , `` is a key building block as people move to this new model of distributed processing . '' 
in today 's computer networks , some machines often sit idle while others are UNKNOWN . 
with the hewlett-packard program , he said , `` you get more bang for the buck you 've spent on computers . '' 
the program , which will be shipped in january 9999 , runs on the UNKNOWN operating system . 
hewlett-packard will charge $ 9,999 for a license covering 99 users . 
the program now works on all hewlett-packard and UNKNOWN workstations and on computers made by UNKNOWN computer inc. of UNKNOWN , conn . 
hewlett-packard said it will sell versions later next year that run on sun microsystems inc. and digital equipment corp. machines . 
the task broker UNKNOWN from other programs that spread computing tasks around a network . 
a previously available program called network computing system , developed by hewlett-packard 's UNKNOWN division , for instance , takes a task and UNKNOWN it up into parts , UNKNOWN up those parts to several computers in a network for UNKNOWN processing . 
but programs in individual computers must be revised in order to work with that system . 
applications wo n't have to be UNKNOWN to work with task broker , hewlett-packard said , and the user of a computer wo n't be able to tell that another machine is doing the work . 
the task broker `` turns that network into -- as far as the user is concerned -- one giant computer , '' said bill UNKNOWN , general manager of hewlett-packard 's workstation group .

once you make up your mind about an investment , the rest is easy , right ? 
you just call your broker and say `` buy '' or `` sell . '' 
dream on . 
there are all sorts of ways to give buy and sell instructions to a broker -- and just as many ways to get burned if you do n't know what you 're doing . 
so here 's a UNKNOWN of the most common types of market orders permitted by the stock and commodity exchanges . 
two things to keep in mind : not all exchanges accept every type of order . 
and even when a specific order is acceptable to an exchange , a brokerage firm can refuse to enter it for a customer . 
market order : this is probably the most widely used order -- and the one most open to abuse by unscrupulous floor brokers , since it imposes no price restrictions . 
with a market order , an investor tells a broker to buy or sell `` at the market . '' 
it 's like saying , `` get me in now '' or `` get me out now . '' 
for example , if wheat is being offered at $ 9.999 and bid at $ 9.999 , a market order to buy would be filled at the higher price and a market order to sell at the lower price . 
a recent indictment alleges that some floor brokers at the two largest chicago commodity exchanges used market orders to fill customers ' orders at unfavorable prices by UNKNOWN trades with fellow brokers . 
profits realized from these trades would then be shared by the UNKNOWN brokers . 
limit order : limit orders are used when investors want to restrict the amount they will receive or pay for an investment . 
investors do this by UNKNOWN a minimum price at which the investment may be sold or the maximum price that may be paid for it . 
UNKNOWN an investor wants to sell a stock , but not for less than $ 99 . 
a limit order to sell could be entered at that price . 
one risk : investors may regret the UNKNOWN if the stock reaches 99 and then falls . 
unless the market goes at least one UNKNOWN ( the UNKNOWN price UNKNOWN permitted ) beyond the limit price , investors are n't assured of having their orders filled because there may not be sufficient trading volume to permit filling it at the specified price . 
stop order : stop orders tell a floor broker to buy or sell an investment once the price reaches a certain level . 
once the price reaches that level , a stop order turns into a market order , and the order is filled at whatever price the broker can get . 
stop orders are sometimes called `` stop-loss '' orders because they are frequently used to protect profits or limit losses . 
while stop orders sound similar to limit orders , there is a difference : sell UNKNOWN must be entered at a price below the current market price and buy UNKNOWN above . 
in contrast , sell limit orders must be placed above the market price and buy limit orders are placed below . 
the crash in october 9999 and last friday 's sell-off UNKNOWN taught some investors exactly what stop orders will and wo n't do . 
an investor who may have placed a stop-loss order at $ 99 under a stock that was trading at $ 999 a share on the friday before the crash was stunned to discover that the order was filled at $ 99 when the stock opened at that price on monday . 
UNKNOWN order : UNKNOWN orders turn into limit orders when an investment trades at the price specified in the order . 
unlike stop orders -- which are filled at the market price when the stop price is hit -- UNKNOWN orders demand that the trades be made only at the specified price . 
if it ca n't be made at that price , it does n't get filled . 
investors who wish to be out of a position , without the risk of receiving a UNKNOWN price from a market order , may use this type of order to specify the price at which the order must be filled . 
but if the market moves quickly enough , it may be impossible for the broker to carry out the order because the investment has passed the specified price . 
UNKNOWN order : UNKNOWN orders are like stop orders in that they become market orders if a specified price is reached . 
however , unlike a UNKNOWN order , a buy UNKNOWN order is entered at a price below the current price , while a sell UNKNOWN order is entered at a price above it . 
as soon as the market trades at the specified price the floor broker will fill it at the best possible price . 
UNKNOWN order : the UNKNOWN order is one of several associated with the timing of trades . 
it UNKNOWN a broker to buy or sell an investment at the specified price or better . 
but if the investment ca n't be bought or sold immediately , the order is automatically canceled . 
UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , who came in second in the stock division of the recently completed u.s. trading championship , says he uses UNKNOWN orders almost UNKNOWN when trading options . 
`` i like to use them to feel out the market , '' he says . 
`` if they do n't fill it immediately , then i can start over at a new price or try again with the same price . '' 
UNKNOWN order : this is another timing order . 
it is a market order that allows floor brokers to take more time to buy or sell an investment , if they think they can get a better price by waiting . 
UNKNOWN orders , which are also known as `` UNKNOWN the tape '' orders , are always done at the customer 's risk . 
UNKNOWN order : this is really two orders in one , generally for the same security or commodity , UNKNOWN floor brokers to fill UNKNOWN order they can first and then UNKNOWN the other order . 
in a UNKNOWN market , it UNKNOWN an investor from getting stuck with having made two trades on the same security . 
UNKNOWN order : this type of order couples many of the orders described above with instructions that the order must be carried out at or by a certain time . 
`` on the close '' can be added to many types of orders . 
for example , `` UNKNOWN orders '' must be filled during the last few minutes of trading for the day at a price that is within the official closing range of prices as determined by the exchange . 
`` UNKNOWN orders '' are stop orders that only become active during the closing minutes of trading . 
`` day orders '' expire at the end of the day on which they are entered , `` UNKNOWN orders '' have no expiration date . 
most brokers assume that all orders are day orders unless specified otherwise . 
on oct. 99 , 9999 , some investors learned the consequences of entering `` UNKNOWN limit orders '' and then UNKNOWN about them . 
they found they had bought stock from limit orders that they might have entered weeks or months earlier and had forgotten to UNKNOWN . 
it is always the responsibility of investors to keep track of the orders they have placed . 
investors who change their mind about buying or selling after an order has been filled are , usually , stuck with the consequences . 
mr. UNKNOWN writes on the options and commodities markets for the wall street journal . 
in UNKNOWN up the risks of stock-market investments , there 's probably no starting place better than `` beta . '' 
but investors better not ignore its UNKNOWN , either . 
beta is a handy gauge that measures the volatility of a stock or stock mutual fund . 
for any given move in the overall market , it suggests how UNKNOWN that particular issue might rise or fall . 
beta figures are widely available and easy to interpret . 
the beta of the broad market , typically defined as the standard & poor 's 999-stock index , is always 9.9 . 
so a stock with a beta of 9.9 is half as volatile , one at 9.9 is 99 % more volatile , and so on . 
cautious investors should generally go with stocks that have low UNKNOWN . 
go with UNKNOWN stocks to get the biggest UNKNOWN from a bet on a bull market . 
remember , though , that beta also has important UNKNOWN . 
`` beta is only part of the risk in a stock , '' says william f. UNKNOWN , the stanford university UNKNOWN professor who developed the measure . 
`` there is risk that is not associated with market moves , and the beta does n't tell you the magnitude of that . '' 
in particular , beta does n't measure the company - and UNKNOWN risk associated with an individual stock . 
that `` business '' risk is very significant for an investor with only a few stocks , but it virtually disappears in a large and UNKNOWN portfolio . 
beta is also a poor indicator of the risk in stock groups that march to their own UNKNOWN . 
in particular , the prices of gold and other UNKNOWN stocks shoot up and down , but the stocks tend to have low UNKNOWN because their moves are not UNKNOWN . 
concern that investors could UNKNOWN such UNKNOWN led the american association of individual investors to eliminate beta figures for UNKNOWN funds in the 9999 edition of its mutual-fund guide . 
`` our fear was people would look just at the beta { of a gold fund } and say here is an investment with very low risk , '' says john UNKNOWN , director of research for the chicago-based group . 
`` in reality it 's very volatile , but the movements are not because of market movements .

u.s. treasury bonds , for example , are UNKNOWN when it comes to returning money at maturity .

risk is also a function of time . 
when financial professionals measure risk UNKNOWN , they usually focus on the volatility of short-term returns . 
stocks are much UNKNOWN than treasury bills , for example , because the range in performance from the best years to the worst is much wider . 
that is usually measured by the standard deviation , or UNKNOWN , of annual results from the average return over time .

( here 's how to interpret a standard deviation figure : take the expected return and add one standard deviation to it . 
then take the expected return and UNKNOWN one standard deviation . 
in two of three years , the actual result should fall within that range if all the assumptions were accurate . 
then add and UNKNOWN two standard UNKNOWN to get a wider range .

when it comes to investing , trying to weigh risk and reward can seem like throwing UNKNOWN UNKNOWN : investors do n't know the actual returns that securities will deliver , or the ups and UNKNOWN that will occur along the way .

for instance , some analysts believe bond returns and volatility have moved permanently closer to those of the stock market .

that 's the dilemma for today 's parent .

help may be on the way . 
the antitrust division of the justice department is investigating the oddly similar tuition charges and increases among the top schools . 
fear of the price police could help cool things off in the 9999s .

the UNKNOWN bonds -- tax-free , offered in small denominations and usually containing a provision that they wo n't be called before maturity -- seem to be UNKNOWN for college UNKNOWN . 
like other UNKNOWN , they pay all their interest at maturity , meaning that buyers can time things so that their bonds pay off just when UNKNOWN UNKNOWN from high school .

florida and UNKNOWN have backed up their guarantees with the full faith and credit of the state governments , meaning that taxpayers will pick up any slack .

over the past decade or two , while i was thinking about fox hunting , the insurance industry has spawned an UNKNOWN number of products , variations on products , and variations on the variations . 
besides term life and whole life ( the old UNKNOWN ) , we now have universal life , universal UNKNOWN life , flexible adjustable universal life , policies with UNKNOWN bonuses , policies UNKNOWN with exotic UNKNOWN , living benefit policies , and on and on . 
what to do ? 
first , UNKNOWN . 
UNKNOWN of all their UNKNOWN , special provisions , and other bells and UNKNOWN , insurance policies can still be UNKNOWN under two broad categories : so-called pure insurance , which UNKNOWN no cash value in the policy and pays off only upon death , and permanent insurance , which provides not only a death benefit but also a cash value in the policy that can be used in various ways while the insured is still alive . 
if all you want is UNKNOWN coverage , pure insurance -- a term policy -- gives you maximum bang for your buck , within limits . 
it 's much cheaper than permanent insurance bought at the same age . 
but `` term '' means just that ; the policy is written for a specific time period only and must be renewed when it expires . 
it may also UNKNOWN that the insured must pass another medical UNKNOWN before renewal ; if you UNKNOWN -- which means you need insurance more than ever -- you may not be able to buy it . 
even if you 're healthy and can renew , your premium will go up sharply because you 're that much older . 
so term insurance may not be as cheap as it looks . 
there are all sorts of variations on term insurance : policies structured to pay off your mortgage debt , term UNKNOWN UNKNOWN on to permanent insurance , and many others . 
one UNKNOWN that appealed to me at first was the `` money smart term life '' policy offered by amex life insurance co. , the american express unit , to the parent company 's credit-card holders . 
upon examination , however , i UNKNOWN whether the plan made a lot of sense . 
amex said it would charge me $ 999 a year for $ 999,999 of coverage -- and would pay me back all the premiums i put in if i canceled the policy after 99 years . 
sounds great -- or does it ? 
first , if i canceled , i 'd have no more insurance , a not UNKNOWN consideration . 
second , the $ 9,999 i 'd get back would be much diminished in purchasing power by 99 years of inflation ; amex , not i , would get the benefit of the investment income on my money , income that would have exceeded the inflation rate and thus given the company a real profit . 
third and most important , amex would charge me a far higher premium than other reputable companies would on a straight term policy for the same amount ; i 'd be paying so heavily just to have the option of getting my premiums back that i 'd almost have to UNKNOWN to make the whole thing UNKNOWN . 
that would be all right with amex , which could then lock in its investment profit , but it does n't add up to a `` smart money '' move for me . 
which goes to show that the first law UNKNOWN in insurance as in anything else : there is no free lunch , there is only marketing . 
and the second law , unique to insurance ? 
if i die early , i win -- a UNKNOWN victory , since i ca n't enjoy it -- and if i live long , the insurer UNKNOWN . 
always . 
this is worth UNKNOWN when insurers and their salesmen try to sell you permanent insurance , the kind that UNKNOWN cash value . 
the word `` death '' can not be escaped entirely by the industry , but salesmen dodge it UNKNOWN possible or UNKNOWN it in UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN to talk about `` savings '' and `` investment '' instead . 
the implication is that your UNKNOWN policy is really some kind of cd or mutual-fund account with an added feature . 
that is UNKNOWN the UNKNOWN . 
the fact is that as a savings or investment vehicle , insurance generally runs a poor second to any direct investment you might make in the same things the insurance company is putting your money into . 
that 's because you have to pay for the insurance portion of the policy and the effort required to sell and service the whole package . 
again , no free lunch . 
this is reflected in a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN cost -- in effect , your share of the company 's estimated liability in paying off beneficiaries of people who had the UNKNOWN to die while under its protection . 
and in most cases , a huge UNKNOWN of your premium in the initial year or two of the the policy is , in effect , paying the salesman 's commission as well ; investment returns on most policies are actually negative for several years , largely because of this . 
so view permanent insurance for what it is -- a compromise between pure insurance and direct investment . 
the UNKNOWN , most traditional form of permanent insurance is the straight whole life policy . 
you pay a set premium for a set amount of coverage , the company UNKNOWN that premium in a portfolio of its choosing , and your cash value and dividends grow over the years . 
one newer UNKNOWN , so called UNKNOWN life ( you pay for the whole policy at once ) , has been UNKNOWN popular in recent years for tax reasons ; the insured could UNKNOWN cash value in the form of policy `` loans , '' and none of the proceeds were taxable even though they included gains on investment . 
congress closed this UNKNOWN last year , or thought it did . 
however , UNKNOWN capital corp. of UNKNOWN , mass. , has developed a `` combination plan '' of UNKNOWN and insurance coverage that it says does not violate the new regulations and that allows policy loans without tax consequences . 
but the percentage of your cash reserve that you can borrow tax-free is very small . 
i 'm not prepared in any case to put that much money into a policy immediately , so i look into the broad category called universal life . 
UNKNOWN popular , it is far more flexible than straight whole life . 
i can adjust the amount of insurance i want against the amount going into investment ; i can pay more or less than the so-called target premium in a given year ; and i can even UNKNOWN payments if my cash reserves are enough to cover the insurance portion of the policy . 
in looking at these and other policies , i learn to ask pointed questions about some of the assumptions built into `` policy UNKNOWN '' -- the rows of numbers that show me the buildup of my cash values over the years . 
they commonly give two UNKNOWN : one is based on interest rates that the company guarantees ( usually 9 % to 9.9 % ) and the other on the rate it is currently getting on investment , often 9.9 % or more . 
projecting the latter over several decades , i find my cash buildup is impressive -- but can any high interest rate prevail for that long ? 
not likely , i think . 
also , some policy UNKNOWN assume that UNKNOWN costs will decline or that i will get some sort of dividend bonus after the 99th year . 
these are not certain , either . 
companies `` are n't comfortable playing these games , but they realize they 're under pressure to make their policies look good , '' says timothy UNKNOWN , an UNKNOWN consultant at UNKNOWN , a unit of UNKNOWN UNKNOWN co. , the big new york consulting firm . 
another factor to consider : some of the companies currently earning very high yields are doing so through substantial investment in junk bonds , and you know how nervous the market has been about those lately . 
there are seemingly endless UNKNOWN to universal life , and it pays to ask questions about all of them . 
at a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , for example , a friend boasts that she 'll only have to pay premiums on her john UNKNOWN policy for seven years and that her death benefits will then be `` guaranteed . '' 
i call her agent , david UNKNOWN . 
yes , he says , premiums on such UNKNOWN coverage can be structured to `` UNKNOWN '' after a certain period -- but usually only if interest rates stay high enough to generate sufficient cash to cover the annual cost of insurance protection . 
if interest rates plunge , the insurer may be knocking on my door , asking for UNKNOWN premium payments to maintain the same amount of protection . 
i do n't like the sound of that . 
some insurers have also started offering `` UNKNOWN bonuses , '' such as extra dividends or a marginally higher interest yield , if the policy is maintained for 99 years . 
but glenn daily , a new york-based financial consultant , warns that many of these bonuses are `` just UNKNOWN , '' because most are n't guaranteed by the companies . 
and the feature is so new , he adds , that no insurer has yet established a track record for actually making such payments . 
so-called UNKNOWN provisions also merit a close UNKNOWN . 
offered by insurers that include UNKNOWN life insurance co. , jackson national life insurance co. , and national travelers life insurance co. , these policy UNKNOWN let me UNKNOWN a portion of my death benefits while i 'm still alive . 
some provisions would let me collect a percentage of the policy 's face value to pay for long-term care such as UNKNOWN stays ; others would allow payments for catastrophic UNKNOWN and conditions such as cancer , heart UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN failure and kidney transplants . 
but the catastrophic events for which the UNKNOWN can collect are narrowly defined , vary from policy to policy , and generally permit use of only a small fraction of the face amount of insurance . 
also , financial planners advising on insurance say that to their knowledge there has not yet been a tax ruling UNKNOWN these advance payments from taxes . 
and considering the extra cost of such provisions , some figure that people interested in , say , paying for extended UNKNOWN care would be better off just buying a separate policy that provides it . 
i 'm more UNKNOWN impressed by `` UNKNOWN life , '' even though it turns out to be UNKNOWN life . 
UNKNOWN selling these policies market them directly to the public or otherwise do n't use commissioned salesmen ; there is still a load -- annual administrative fees and initial `` UNKNOWN '' charges -- but i figure that the lack of commission and of `` UNKNOWN fees '' for dropping the policy early still UNKNOWN me a lot . 
i compared one universal policy for $ 999,999 face amount from such an insurer , american life insurance corp. of lincoln , UNKNOWN , with a similar offering from UNKNOWN life assurance society of the u.s. , which operates through 99,999 commissioned salesmen . 
after one year i could walk away from the UNKNOWN policy with $ 999 , but UNKNOWN get only $ 99 from the UNKNOWN . 
the difference is UNKNOWN by time , too . 
at age 99 , when i 'd stop paying premiums , the UNKNOWN offering would have a projected cash value $ 99,999 higher than the other , even though the UNKNOWN 's policy illustration assumed a UNKNOWN higher interest rate . 
did i buy it ? 
well , not yet . 
i 'm thinking about using the $ 999 annual premium to finance a trip to paris first . 
a person can do some heavy thinking about insurance there -- and shop for something more exciting while she 's doing it .

in a speech prepared for delivery to london 's financial community , mr. lawson UNKNOWN up current economic policy as a battle to UNKNOWN inflation out of the british economy , using high interest rates as `` the essential instrument '' to carry out the campaign . 
two weeks after boosting base rates to 99 % , he pledged that `` rates will have to remain high for some time to come . '' 
mr. lawson also made it clear that he would be watching exchange rates carefully . 
a UNKNOWN pound makes imports more expensive and increases businesses ' expectations of future inflation , he argued . 
in an apparent warning to currency traders who have lately been selling the british currency , he stated that the exchange rates will have a `` major role in the assessment of monetary conditions . '' 
in UNKNOWN the current monetary policy of using high interest rates to fight inflation and shore up the pound , mr. lawson dismissed other approaches to managing the economy . 
he said he monitors the UNKNOWN figures , but does n't give them paramount importance , as some private and government economists have suggested . 
mr. lawson also dismissed the possibility of imposing direct credit controls on britain 's financial system . 
mr. lawson 's speech , delivered at the lord mayor of london 's annual dinner at mansion house , came on the heels of a UNKNOWN period for the u.k. economy . 
two weeks ago , in a campaign to UNKNOWN inflation at home and arrest a world-wide plunge in the pound , he raised base rates a full percentage point to 99 % . 
despite the increase , the british currency slid below a perceived UNKNOWN of three marks early last week . 
it was quoted at 9.9999 marks in late new york trading wednesday . 
leading up to the speech was a UNKNOWN of economic statistics suggesting that the british war on inflation will be more UNKNOWN than previously assumed . 
unemployment in september dropped to 9,999,999 , the lowest level since 9999 . 
while lower UNKNOWN is generally good news , the hefty drop last month indicates that the economy is n't slowing down as much as hoped -- despite a doubling of interest rates over the last 99 months . 
meanwhile , average earnings in britain were up 9.99 % in august over the previous year . 
another UNKNOWN sign came in a surge in UNKNOWN lending to a record # 99.9 billion ( $ 99.99 billion ) last month , a much higher level than economists had predicted . 
in a separate speech prepared for delivery at the dinner , UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , bank of england governor , conceded that `` demand pressures were even more UNKNOWN than had been UNKNOWN '' when the british economy was heating up last year . 
he added that `` there 's no UNKNOWN solution '' to the economic woes , and said `` tight monetary policy is the right approach . '' 
discussing the recent slide in stock prices , the central bank governor stated that `` the markets now appear to have UNKNOWN '' after the `` nasty UNKNOWN '' of the 999.99-point plunge in the dow jones industrial average a week ago . 
although the new york market plunge prompted a UNKNOWN drop in the london financial times-stock exchange 999 share index , mr. UNKNOWN declared `` that the experience owed nothing to the particular problems of the british economy . '' 
specifically , he pointed out that compared with the u.s. market , the u.k. has far fewer highly leveraged junk-bond UNKNOWN . 
discussing future monetary arrangements , mr. lawson repeated the thatcher government 's commitment to join the exchange rate mechanism of the european monetary system , but he did n't indicate when .

when it comes to buying and selling shares , westridge capital management inc. takes a back seat to no one . 
every dollar 's worth of stock in the los angeles money manager 's portfolio is traded seven or eight times a year , the firm estimates . 
that makes it the most active trader among all the nation 's investment advisers , according to securities and exchange commission filings . 
but wait a second . 
westridge capital is an index fund -- the type of UNKNOWN long-term investor whose goal is to be nothing more than average . 
westridge capital 's UNKNOWN trading reflects the changes sweeping through the previously UNKNOWN world of indexing . 
indexing for the most part has involved simply buying and then holding stocks in the correct mix to mirror a stock market barometer , such as standard & poor 's 999-stock index , and match its performance . 
institutional investors have poured $ 999 billion into stock and bond indexing as a cheap and easy form of investment management that promises to post average market returns . 
these big investors have UNKNOWN to indexing because relatively few `` active '' stock UNKNOWN have been able to consistently match the returns of the s&p 999 or other UNKNOWN , much less beat it . 
and the fees investors pay for indexing run a few UNKNOWN for each $ 999 of assets -- a fraction of the cost of active managers . 
that 's because computers do most of the work , and low trading activity keeps a UNKNOWN on commission costs . 
but today , indexing is moving from a passive investment strategy to an increasingly active one . 
because UNKNOWN managers are no longer satisfied with merely being average , they have developed `` enhanced '' indexing strategies that are intended to UNKNOWN the market as much as three percentage points . 
`` indexing has been the most single successful investment concept in the last decade , but the index money has been just sort of sitting there , '' says UNKNOWN m. lynn , president of UNKNOWN core investors inc. , an UNKNOWN based in UNKNOWN , n.y . 
`` now the interest is in what else can i do with that money . '' 
among the UNKNOWN indexing strategies : UNKNOWN portfolios can be built around thousands of stocks , or just a few dozen , rather than being restricted to the s&p 999 companies . 
they can ignore the s&p 999 stocks altogether and focus on particular types of stocks , such as smaller companies , those paying high dividends or companies in a particular industry , state or country . 
with today 's computer-driven program trading techniques , index funds can trade back and forth between stock-index futures and the actual stocks making up indexes such as the s&p 999 . 
futures and options also make it possible to build `` synthetic '' index funds that do n't actually own a single share of stock , but can produce returns that match or exceed the broad stock market . 
one reason for these UNKNOWN is that indexing 's rapid growth is slowing , particularly for those `` plain UNKNOWN '' funds that mirror the s&p 999 . 
`` there is n't a UNKNOWN { of big investors } out there still waiting to get into indexing , '' says p. james UNKNOWN , vice president of UNKNOWN investment management co. , chicago , which offers both indexing and active management services . 
( after UNKNOWN in size in the past five years , index funds now hold about 99 % of the stock owned by pension funds . ) 
a further problem is UNKNOWN profits . 
UNKNOWN funds have become so UNKNOWN that fees they can charge have plunged to almost nothing , and in some cases are just that . 
to land customers for their UNKNOWN stock UNKNOWN business , big banks sometimes will throw in basic indexing services for free . 
`` it 's like getting a free UNKNOWN when you open an account , '' says UNKNOWN core 's mr. lynn . 
as a result , UNKNOWN have been looking for ways to give investors something more than the average for their money . 
and many have been successful , as in the case of the index fund operated by UNKNOWN westridge capital . 
westridge capital has used enhanced indexing techniques to beat the s&p 999 's returns by 9.9 to 9 percentage points over the past four years , with the same risk level as holding the s&p 999 stocks , according to james UNKNOWN , the firm 's president . 
strategies vary for westridge capital , which has $ 999 million under management . 
the firm sometimes buys s&p 999 futures when they are selling at a discount to the actual stocks , and will switch back and forth between stocks and stock-index futures to take advantages of any UNKNOWN price UNKNOWN . 
mr. UNKNOWN also goes through periods when he buys stocks in UNKNOWN with options to boost returns and protect against declines . 
and in some months , he buys stock-index futures and not stocks at all . 
`` by their nature , our trades are very short-term and are going to create high turnover , '' mr. UNKNOWN adds . 
`` the more turnover , the better for our clients . '' 
big UNKNOWN bankers trust co. also uses futures in a strategy that on average has added one percentage point to its enhanced fund 's returns . 
j. thomas allen , president of UNKNOWN advanced investment management inc. , agrees it 's a good idea to jump between the s&p 999 stocks and futures . 
`` you 're buying the s&p , and you always want to hold the UNKNOWN form of it , '' he says . 
but some UNKNOWN make little or no use of futures , saying that these instruments present added risks for investors . 
`` if the futures markets have a problem , then those products could have a problem , '' says john UNKNOWN , managing director of prudential insurance co. of america 's investment index technologies inc. unit . 
prudential currently is seeking approval to offer a new fund offering a return equal to the s&p 999 index plus UNKNOWN of a percentage point . 
an added feature is that the UNKNOWN improved return would be guaranteed by prudential . 
there are many other strategies to bolster the returns of index funds . 
they include : 
limited risk funds : 
these guarantee protection against stock market declines while still passing along most gains . 
here a fund may promise to pay back , say , $ 99 of every $ 999 invested for a year , even if the market goes much lower . 
the fund could invest $ 99 for one year in treasury bills yielding 9 % to return the guaranteed $ 99 . 
that leaves $ 99 , which could be used to buy s&p 999 options that will nearly match any gain in the s&p index . 
manager UNKNOWN funds : 
say a big investor is interested in growth stocks . 
instead of hiring one of the many active managers UNKNOWN in growth stocks , UNKNOWN can design a portfolio around the same stocks ; the portfolio will be maintained by computer , reducing both fees and , in theory , risk ( because of the large number of stocks ) . 
`` we see a lot of interest in those kind of things , '' says frank UNKNOWN , a vice president of bankers trust . 
`` people comfortable with the passive approach are using them for other strategies . '' 
tilt funds : 
this is an index fund with a bet . 
instead of UNKNOWN the s&p 999 or some other index exactly , some stocks are UNKNOWN or UNKNOWN in the portfolio . 
one simple approach is to exclude s&p 999 companies considered bankruptcy candidates ; this can avoid weak UNKNOWN , but also can hurt when a company like chrysler corp. UNKNOWN . 
another approach : an investor with $ 999 million might use $ 99 million to buy the s&p 999 index and spend the other $ 99 million on a favorite group of stocks . 
UNKNOWN funds : 
indexes can be UNKNOWN to serve social goals , such as eliminating the stocks of companies doing business in south africa . 
other funds have been designed to concentrate on stocks in a UNKNOWN area in order to encourage local investment . 
pennsylvania state employees retirement system , for example , has about $ 999 million invested in a fund of 999 companies that are either UNKNOWN or have 99 % of their work forces in the state . 
short interest on the new york stock exchange declined for the second consecutive month , this time 9.9 % , while the american stock exchange reported its third consecutive record month of short interest . 
the big board reported that short interest dropped to 999,999,999 shares as of oct. 99 from 999,999,999 shares in UNKNOWN . 
amex short interest climbed 9 % to 99,999,999 shares from 99,999,999 shares . 
for the year-earlier month , the big board reported 999,999,999 shares , indicating a 99.9 % year-to-year rise , while the amex reported 99,999,999 shares , a 99 % leap . 
amex short interest has been heading upward since UNKNOWN , with increases in each month since then except at UNKNOWN . 
traders who sell short borrow stock and sell it , betting that the stock 's price will decline and that they can buy the shares back later at a lower price for return to the lender . 
short interest is the number of shares that have n't yet been purchased for return to lenders . 
although a substantial short position reflects heavy speculation that a stock 's price will decline , some investors consider an increase in short interest bullish because the borrowed shares eventually must be bought back . 
UNKNOWN in short interest of certain stocks also may be caused partly by UNKNOWN . 
the figures occasionally include incomplete transactions in restricted stock . 
the level of negative sentiment measured by the big board short interest ratio slipped to 9.99 from last month 's 9.99 . 
the ratio is the number of trading days , at the exchange 's average trading volume , that would be required to convert the total short interest position . 
some analysts suggest , however , that the ratio has weakened in value as an indicator because options and other products can be used to hedge short positions .

consumer prices rose a surprisingly moderate 9.9 % in september , pushed up mostly by a jump in clothing costs , the labor department reported . 
energy costs , which drove wholesale prices up sharply during the month , continued to decline at the retail level , pulling down transportation and helping to ease housing costs . 
the report was the UNKNOWN news the financial markets had seen since before the stock market plunged more than 999 points last friday . 
the dow jones industrial average rallied on the news , closing 99.99 points higher at 9999.99 . 
bond prices also jumped as traders appeared to read the data as a sign that interest rates may fall . 
but many economists were not nearly as UNKNOWN . 
the climb in wholesale energy prices is certain to push up retail energy prices in the next few months , they warned . 
they also said the dollar is UNKNOWN off after a rise this summer that helped to reduce the prices of imported goods . 
`` i think inflation is going to pick up through the fall , '' said joel UNKNOWN , a specialist on inflation who runs an economic consulting firm here . 
`` it has been in what i would describe as a UNKNOWN for the past several months . '' 
`` we 've had UNKNOWN declines in consumer energy prices in each of the past three months , and at the wholesale level those are fully behind us now , '' said jay UNKNOWN , chief domestic economist at bankers trust co. in new york . 
because wholesale energy prices shot up by a steep 9.9 % last month , many analysts expected energy prices to rise at the consumer level too . 
as a result , many economists were expecting the consumer price index to increase significantly more than it did . 
but retail energy prices declined 9.9 % in september . 
though analysts say competition will probably hold down increases in retail energy prices , many expect some of the wholesale rise to be passed along to the consumer before the end of the year . 
still , some analysts insisted that the worst of the inflation is behind . 
`` it increasingly appears that 9999-99 was a temporary inflation UNKNOWN and not the beginning of a cyclical inflation problem , '' argued edward UNKNOWN , chief economist at prudential-bache securities inc. in new york . 
in both 9999 and 9999 , consumer prices rose 9.9 % . 
a UNKNOWN in world oil prices last winter sent consumer prices soaring at a 9.9 % annual rate in the first five months of this year , but the subsequent decline in energy prices has pulled the annual rate back down to 9.9 % . 
mr. UNKNOWN predicted that world business competition will continue to UNKNOWN prices . 
`` the bottom line is , it seems to me that the economic environment has become very , very UNKNOWN for a lot of businesses , '' he said . 
`` back in 9999-99 , business was operating at fairly tight capacity , so businesses felt they could raise prices . '' 
now , he said , a slowdown in economic activity has UNKNOWN demand .

the steep climb in producer prices reported last friday UNKNOWN UNKNOWN about lower interest rates and contributed to the stock market 's 9.9 % plunge that day .

excluding the volatile categories of energy and food -- leaving what some economists call the core inflation rate -- consumer prices still rose only 9.9 % in september . 
transportation costs actually fell 9.9 % , and housing costs gained only 9.9 % .

they dropped 9.9 % as dealers continued to offer rebates to attract customers .

the disarray in the junk-bond market that began last month with a credit crunch at campeau corp. has offered commercial banks a golden opportunity to play a greater role in financing UNKNOWN takeovers . 
but two big new york banks seem to have kicked those chances away , for the moment , with the embarrassing failure of citicorp and chase manhattan corp. to deliver $ 9.9 billion in bank financing for a leveraged buy-out of united airlines parent ual corp . 
for more than a decade , banks have been pressing congress and banking regulators for expanded powers to act like securities firms in playing wall street 's lucrative takeover game , from giving mergers advice all the way to selling and trading high-yield junk bonds . 
those expanded powers reached their zenith in july when bankers trust new york corp. provided mergers advice , an equity investment and bank loans for the $ 9.99 billion leveraged buy-out of northwest airlines parent nwa inc . 
one of the major selling points used by los angeles financier alfred UNKNOWN in getting the takeover approved was that the deal did n't include any junk bonds . 
that was seen as an advantage in lobbying airline employees and washington regulators for approval of the contested takeover . 
all $ 9.99 billion in debt for the deal was supplied by banks . 
charles UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN of mergers and acquisitions at salomon brothers inc. , says it is natural for banks to try to expand beyond their UNKNOWN business of providing senior debt for buy-outs . 
but the ual collapse , he says , `` may tell you it 's not going to work that easily . '' 
david UNKNOWN , a mergers adviser in la UNKNOWN , calif. , who aided los angeles investor marvin davis on the bids which put both ual and nwa in play as takeover candidates this year , says that banks have been `` preparing to play a larger and larger role in acquisition financing . '' 
mr. UNKNOWN says that in the past , banks would normally have UNKNOWN 99 % of a total buy-out price , with the loans secured by the target company 's assets . 
another 99 % of the borrowed funds would come from the sale to investors of junk bonds , which offer less security and typically carry higher yields than bank loans . 
mr. UNKNOWN 's purchase of nwa , mr. UNKNOWN notes , `` was probably the most aggressive to date , '' with bank debt at 99 % of the purchase price . 
but mr. UNKNOWN says that citicorp 's `` failure to deliver '' on its promise to raise the ual bank debt for a labor-management buy-out group `` is very UNKNOWN to potential users of a ` UNKNOWN ' letter from commercial banks . '' 
his client , mr. davis , used just such a letter from citicorp in pursuing ual ; citicorp later agreed to work with a competing ual buy-out group . 
executives of citicorp and chase manhattan declined to comment on either the ual situation , or on the changing nature of banks ' role in financing takeovers . 
in the wake of campeau 's problems , prices of junk bonds tumbled , throwing into doubt the ability of corporate UNKNOWN to finance large takeovers with the help of junk bond sales . 
mark UNKNOWN , senior managing director at manufacturers hanover trust co. , says the UNKNOWN in junk bonds may yet open new business opportunities to banks in UNKNOWN takeovers . 
but he warns that banks will have `` to have enough discipline '' not to make loans that are too risky . 
in fact , manufacturers hanover said in its third-quarter earnings report that fees from UNKNOWN loans to other banks dropped 99 % , to $ 99 million . 
`` we did n't take part in a lot of deals because their credit quality was poor , '' says a bank spokesman . 
james b. lee , head of UNKNOWN and private UNKNOWN at chemical banking corp. , said he believes banks can still make a credible offer of UNKNOWN shopping for takeover finance . 
as evidence , he cites yesterday 's arrangement for the final financing of a $ 9 billion bid for american medical international inc. in which chemical served as both the lead bank and an equity investor . 
beyond the current weakness in the junk bond market , banks have another advantage over investment banks in financing contested takeovers . 
arthur UNKNOWN jr. , a takeover lawyer at fried frank harris UNKNOWN & jacobson , notes that `` a political and emotional bias '' has developed against junk bonds . 
one hostile bidder who UNKNOWN avoided using junk bonds was paramount communications inc. in its initial offer to acquire time inc. for $ 99.9 billion , or $ 999 a share . 
a paramount spokesman says that decision was based on the financial , not political , drawbacks of junk bonds . 
but some observers believe paramount chairman martin davis wanted to avoid the possible UNKNOWN of being perceived as a corporate raider in his controversial bid for time . 
in the end , mr. davis used junk bonds so that he could raise paramount 's bid to $ 999 a share . 
some UNKNOWN UNKNOWN said the initial lower bid , without junk bonds , was a factor in his losing the company . 
time UNKNOWN paramount by acquiring warner communications inc . 
the success of the nwa financing , and the failure of the ual deal , also seem to highlight the important new role in takeover financing being played by japanese banks . 
japanese banks accounted for 99 % of the nwa bank debt , according to a report by transportation secretary samuel skinner . 
but it was UNKNOWN rejection by japanese banks that helped seal the fate of the attempt to buy ual . 
citicorp and chase are attempting to put together a new , lower bid . 
UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , chief economist of the institute for financial affairs inc. , a tokyo research center on finance and economics , says , `` the junk bond market became very UNKNOWN , and there 's a fear of a coming recession and the possible bankruptcy of lbo companies . 
UNKNOWN inc. filed suit in federal court here , UNKNOWN that a group that holds 9.9 % of its stock made `` false , deceptive and misleading '' statements in recent regulatory filings and public announcements . 
UNKNOWN 's complaint claims that the group , led by investor malcolm i. glazer , violated securities laws by failing to disclose plans to purchase 99 % of the company 's shares outstanding and that when the required UNKNOWN filing eventually was made , it did n't disclose the group 's alleged earlier violation of the so-called UNKNOWN requirements of the law . 
mr. glazer could n't immediately be reached to comment . 
but when UNKNOWN last week publicly questioned the UNKNOWN of the group 's filing procedures , the rochester , n.y. , investor said `` we UNKNOWN with every law , '' and he denied any wrongdoing . 
the glazer group said in a securities and exchange commission filing in early october that it may seek a controlling interest in UNKNOWN , or seek UNKNOWN on the company 's board . 
UNKNOWN has said it does n't intend to be acquired by the glazer group or any other party . 
inland steel industries inc. , battered by lower volume and higher costs , posted a 99 % drop in third-quarter earnings . 
the nation 's UNKNOWN steelmaker earned $ 99.9 million , or 99 cents a share , compared with $ 99 million , or $ 9.99 a share , a year earlier , when the industry was UNKNOWN peak demand and strong pricing . 
sales fell to $ 999.9 million from $ 9.99 billion . 
the earnings also mark a significant drop from the second quarter 's $ 99.9 million or $ 9.99 a share . 
moreover , the earnings were well below analysts ' expectations of about $ 9.99 a share . 
in composite trading on the new york stock exchange , inland closed yesterday at $ 99.999 a share , down $ 9 . 
the company attributed the earnings drop to lower volume related to seasonal demand and the soft consumer durable market , especially in the automotive sector . 
however , the company also lost orders because of prolonged labor talks in the second quarter . 
third-quarter shipments slipped 9 % from the year-ago period , and 99 % from this year 's second quarter . 
profit of steel shipped for the company 's steel segment slid to $ 99 a ton , from $ 99 a ton a year earlier and $ 99 a ton a quarter earlier . 
analysts noted that the disappointing results do n't reflect lower prices for steel products . 
charles bradford , an analyst with merrill lynch capital markets , said higher prices for galvanized and UNKNOWN products offset lower prices for bar , UNKNOWN and structural steel . 
structural steel , which primarily serves the construction market , was especially hurt by a 99 % price drop , mr. bradford said . 
the company said its integrated steel sector was also hurt by higher raw material , repair and maintenance , and labor costs . 
the increased labor costs became effective aug. 9 under terms of the four-year labor agreement with the united steelworkers union . 
meanwhile , the company 's service center segment , which saw operating profit drop to $ 99.9 million from $ 99.9 million a year ago , experienced much of the same demand and cost problems , as well as start-up costs associated with a UNKNOWN processing facility in chicago and an upgraded computer information system . 
inland chairman frank w. UNKNOWN said the company 's short-term outlook is `` UNKNOWN by UNKNOWN in the economy and financial markets . '' 
however , he noted that steel mill bookings are up from early summer levels , and that he expects the company to improve its cost performance in the fourth quarter . 
in the first nine months , profit was $ 999 million , or $ 9.99 a share , on sales of $ 9.99 billion , compared with $ 999.9 million , or $ 9.99 a share , on sales of $ 9.99 billion , a year earlier . 
the `` seismic '' activity of a financial market bears a UNKNOWN to the seismic activity of the earth . 
when things are quiet ( low volatility ) , the structures on which markets stand can be relatively UNKNOWN and still perform their functions adequately . 
however , when powerful forces start shaking the market 's structure , the more `` UNKNOWN '' it is , the better its chance for survival . 
america 's financial markets do not yet have all the required modern features required to make them fully `` UNKNOWN . '' 
investors lack equal access to the markets ' trading arena and its information . 
that structural lack is crucial because investors are the only source of market liquidity . 
and liquidity is what markets need to damp UNKNOWN and aftershocks . 
in today 's markets , specialists ( on the new york stock exchange ) and `` UNKNOWN '' market makers ( in the over-the-counter market ) are the only market participants allowed to play a direct role in the UNKNOWN process . 
when they halt trading , all market liquidity is gone . 
and when any component of the market -- cash , futures or options -- loses liquidity , the price discovery system ( the way prices are determined ) becomes UNKNOWN or is lost entirely for a time . 
last friday the 99th ( as well as two years ago this week ) the markets became UNKNOWN . 
when that happened , `` seismic '' tremors of fear -- much like the shock waves created by an earthquake -- UNKNOWN through the market and increased the market 's volatility . 
lack of important , needed information can cause fear . 
fear is the father of panic . 
panic frequently results in UNKNOWN behavior . 
and in financial markets , UNKNOWN behavior is sometimes translated into catastrophe . 
when market tremors start , it is crucial that as much information about transaction prices and the UNKNOWN curve ( buy and sell orders at various prices ) be made available to all , not just to market makers . 
because of a lack of information and access , many investors -- including the very ones whose buying power could restore stability and damp volatility -- are forced to stand on the sidelines when they are most needed , because of their UNKNOWN of important market information . 
to add UNKNOWN power to america 's markets , a modern , electronic trading system should be implemented that permits equal access to the trading arena ( and the information that would automatically UNKNOWN such access ) by investors -- particularly institutional investors . 
contrary to some opinions , the trading activities of specialists and other market makers do not provide liquidity to the market as a whole . 
what market makers provide is UNKNOWN , a very valuable service . 
liquidity is not a service . 
it is a market attribute -- the ability to absorb selling orders without causing significant price changes in the absence of news . 
market makers buy what investors wish to sell ; their business is UNKNOWN these unwanted positions as quickly as possible to other investors , and at a profit . 
as a result , while any one customer may purchase UNKNOWN by selling to a market maker ( which is UNKNOWN for the investor ) , the market as a whole remains in the same circumstances it was before the transaction : the unwanted position is still an unwanted position ; only the UNKNOWN of the seller has changed . 
in fact it can be argued that increasing capital commitments by market makers ( a result of some UNKNOWN crash studies ) also increases market volatility , since the more securities are held by market makers at any given time , the more selling pressure is UNKNOWN the market . 
in an open electronic system , any investor UNKNOWN to pay for UNKNOWN access to the trading arena through a registered broker-dealer would be able to see the entire UNKNOWN curve ( buy and sell orders at each price ) entered by dealers and investors UNKNOWN , and to enter and execute orders . 
current quotations would reflect the combined financial judgment of all market participants -- not just those of UNKNOWN who become extremely UNKNOWN during times of crisis . 
investors and professionals UNKNOWN would compete on the level playing field congress sought and called a `` national market system '' ( not yet achieved ) almost 99 years ago when it passed the securities reform act of 9999 . 
last friday 's market gyrations did not result in severe `` aftershocks . '' 
were we smart or just lucky ? 
i 'm not certain . 
but i am sure we need to maximize our `` earthquake '' protection by making certain that our market structures let investors add their UNKNOWN UNKNOWN power to our nation 's markets . 
mr. UNKNOWN is chairman of his own consulting company in UNKNOWN , n.j . 
now you see it , now you do n't . 
the recession , that is . 
the economy 's UNKNOWN steps leave investors wondering whether things are slowing down or UNKNOWN up . 
so often are government statistics revised that they seem to UNKNOWN a UNKNOWN weather UNKNOWN . 
for the past seven years , investors have had the wind at their backs , in the form of a generally growing economy . 
some may have forgotten -- and some younger ones may never have experienced -- what it 's like to invest during a recession . 
different UNKNOWN are called for , as losing money becomes easier and making money becomes tougher . 
for those investors who believe -- or fear -- that 9999 will be a recession year , many economists and money managers agree on steps that can be taken to lower the risks in a portfolio . 
in a UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN advise investors who expect a slowdown to hold fewer stocks than usual and to favor shares of big companies in `` defensive '' industries . 
a heavy UNKNOWN of cash is UNKNOWN , along with a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN to bonds -- UNKNOWN government bonds . 
it 's UNKNOWN to think these defensive steps can be delayed until a recession is clearly at hand . 
but that may not be possible , because recessions often take investors by surprise . 
`` they always seem to come a bit later than you expect . 
when they do hit , they hit fast , '' says david a. UNKNOWN , chief financial economist at the data resources division of mcgraw-hill inc . 
though he himself does n't expect a recession soon , mr. UNKNOWN advises people who do that `` the best thing to be in is long that is , 99-year to 99-year treasury bonds . '' 
the reason is simple , mr. UNKNOWN says : `` interest rates almost always decline during recession . '' 
as surely as a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , falling interest rates force up the price of previously issued bonds . 
they are worth more because they pay higher interest than newly issued bonds do . 
that effect holds true for both short-term and long-term bonds . 
but short-term bonds ca n't rise too much , because everyone knows they will be redeemed at a UNKNOWN price fairly soon . 
long-term bonds , with many years left before maturity , swing more widely in price . 
but not just any bonds will do . 
corporate bonds `` are usually not a good bet in a recession , '' mr. UNKNOWN says . 
as times get tougher , investors UNKNOWN about whether companies will have enough money to pay their debts . 
this UNKNOWN the price of corporate bonds . 
also , he notes , `` most corporate bonds are callable . '' 
that means that a corporation , after a specified amount of time has passed , can buy back its bonds by paying investors the face value ( plus , in some cases , a UNKNOWN ) . 
when interest rates have dropped , it makes sense for corporations to do just that ; they then save on interest costs . 
but the investors are left UNKNOWN with money to UNKNOWN at a time when interest rates are UNKNOWN . 
if corporate bonds are bad in recessions , junk bonds are likely to be the worst of all . 
it 's an `` UNKNOWN necessity '' to get out of junk bonds when a recession is in the UNKNOWN , says UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , professor of finance at cornell university . 
`` such bonds are very sensitive to the UNKNOWN , and this could be a disaster . '' 
municipal bonds are generally a bit safer than corporate bonds in a recession , but not as safe as bonds issued by the federal government . 
during an economic slump , local tax revenues often go down , raising the risks associated with at least some municipals . 
and , like UNKNOWN , many municipal bonds are callable . 
but a few experts , going against the consensus , do n't think bonds would help investors even if a recession is in the UNKNOWN . 
one of these is jeffrey l. beach , director of research for UNKNOWN UNKNOWN & co. , a brokerage house in houston , who thinks that `` we 're either in a recession or about to go into one . '' 
what 's more , he thinks this could be a UNKNOWN recession than usual : `` once the downturn comes , it 's going to be very hard to reverse . '' 
investors , he advises , `` should be cautious , '' holding fewer stocks than usual and also UNKNOWN bonds . 
because he sees a `` 9 % to 9 % base rate of inflation in the economy , '' he doubts that interest rates will fall much any time soon . 
instead , mr. beach says , investors `` probably should be carrying a very high level of cash , '' by which he means such so-called cash equivalents as money-market funds and treasury bills . 
UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , president of UNKNOWN financial inc. in UNKNOWN , pa. , also recommends that investors go heavily for cash . 
he is n't sure a recession is coming , but says the other likely alternative -- UNKNOWN inflation -- is just as bad . 
`` this late in an expansion , '' the economy tends to UNKNOWN off either into UNKNOWN inflation or into a recession , mr. UNKNOWN says . 
the federal reserve board 's plan for a `` soft landing , '' he says , requires the fed to UNKNOWN `` an UNKNOWN UNKNOWN . '' 
a soft landing is n't something that can be achieved once and for all , mr. UNKNOWN adds . 
it has to be engineered over and over again , month after month . 
he believes that the task facing fed chairman alan greenspan is so difficult that it UNKNOWN `` UNKNOWN a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN and a UNKNOWN saw . '' 
and , in a sense , that 's the kind of task individuals face in deciding what to do about stocks -- the mainstay of most serious investors ' portfolios . 
it comes down to a question of whether to try to `` time '' the market . 
for people who can ride out market waves through good times and bad , stocks have been rewarding long-term investments . 
most studies show that UNKNOWN investors historically have earned an annual return from stocks of 9 % to 99 % , including both dividends and price appreciation . 
that 's well above what bonds or bank certificates have paid . 
moreover , because no one knows for sure just when a recession is coming , some analysts think investors should n't even worry too much about timing . 
`` trying to time the economy is a mistake , '' says david katz , chief investment officer of value UNKNOWN management inc. in new york . 
mr. katz notes that some economists have been predicting a recession for at least two years . 
investors who UNKNOWN , and UNKNOWN up on stocks , `` have just hurt themselves , '' he says . 
mr. katz adds that people who jump in and out of the stock market need to be right about 99 % of the time to beat a UNKNOWN strategy . 
frequent trading runs up high commission costs . 
and the UNKNOWN might miss the sudden UNKNOWN that account for much of the stock market 's gains over time . 
still , few investors are able to sit tight when they are convinced a recession is coming . 
after all , in all five recessions since 9999 , stocks declined . 
according to UNKNOWN davis , president of UNKNOWN davis research inc. in UNKNOWN , fla. , the average drop in the dow jones industrial average was about 99 % , and the decrease began an average of six months before a recession officially started . 
by the time a recession is `` official '' ( two consecutive quarters of declining gross national product ) , much of the damage to stocks has already been done - and , in the typical case , the recession is already half over . 
about six months before a recession ends , stocks typically begin to rise again , as investors anticipate a recovery . 
the average recession UNKNOWN about a year . 
unfortunately , though , recessions vary enough in UNKNOWN so that the average ca n't UNKNOWN be used to guide investors in timing stock sales or purchases . 
but whatever their advice about timing , none of these experts recommend UNKNOWN stocks entirely during a recession . 
for the portion of an investor 's portfolio that stays in stocks , professionals have a number of suggestions . 
mr. katz advocates issues with low UNKNOWN ratios -- that is , low prices in UNKNOWN to the company 's earnings per share . 
`` low UNKNOWN '' stocks , he says , UNKNOWN UNKNOWN others `` during a recession or bear market . '' 
in good times , he says , they UNKNOWN a bit , but overall they provide superior performance . 
UNKNOWN UNKNOWN urges investors to UNKNOWN stocks in small companies . 
UNKNOWN shares typically fall more than UNKNOWN stocks in a recession , he says . 
and in any case , he argues , stocks of small companies are `` almost as UNKNOWN as they were sept. 99 , 9999 , just before the crash . '' 
for example , mr. UNKNOWN says , stocks of small companies are selling for about 99 times cash flow . 
( cash flow , basically earnings plus depreciation , is one common gauge of a company 's financial health . ) 
that ratio is UNKNOWN close to the ratio of 99.9 that UNKNOWN before the 9999 stock-market crash , mr. UNKNOWN says . 
and it 's way above the ratio ( 9.9 times cash flow ) that bigger companies are selling for . 
another major UNKNOWN in making a portfolio UNKNOWN is choosing stocks in `` defensive '' industries . 
food , tobacco , drugs and utilities are the classic UNKNOWN . 
recession or not , people still eat , smoke , and take medicine when they 're sick . 
george UNKNOWN iii , editor of turnaround letter in boston , offers one final tip for UNKNOWN investors . 
`` keep some money available for opportunities , '' he says . 
`` if the recession does hit , there will be some great investment opportunities just when things seem the UNKNOWN . ''

senate democrats UNKNOWN a cut in the capital-gains tax have decided , under pressure from their leaders , not to offer their own proposal , UNKNOWN another obstacle in the path of president bush 's legislative priority . 
a core group of six or so democratic senators has been working behind the scenes to develop a proposal to reduce the tax on the gain from the sale of assets . 
the plan was complete except for finishing UNKNOWN , and there was talk that it would be unveiled as early as yesterday . 
but senate majority leader george mitchell ( d. , maine ) , a UNKNOWN opponent of the capital-gains tax cut , called the group to meet with him wednesday night and again yesterday . 
sen. mitchell urged them to UNKNOWN . 
afterward , leaders of the dissident democrats UNKNOWN , and said they would n't offer their own proposal as they had planned . 
the decision is a setback for president bush , who needs the support of democrats to pass the tax cut through the UNKNOWN senate . 
having a proposal sponsored by democrats would have given the president an advantage . 
having only a republican measure makes the task harder . 
still , sen. bob packwood ( r. , ore. ) , the lead sponsor of the republican capital-gains amendment , predicted that the tax cut would be enacted this year . 
he said a clear majority of senators back the tax reduction and that ultimately there would be enough senators to overcome any UNKNOWN UNKNOWN the democratic leadership might UNKNOWN . 
but sen. mitchell , buoyed by his victory among fellow democrats , strongly UNKNOWN . 
mr. mitchell has been predicting that the president 's initiative would fail this year . 
yesterday , in an interview , he added that the democrats ' decision `` increases the likelihood that a capital-gains tax cut will not pass this year . '' 
mr. mitchell 's first victory came last week , when the senate passed a deficit-reduction bill that did n't contain a capital-gains provision . 
that vote made it unlikely that a capital-gains tax cut would be included in the final bill , now being drafted by house and senate negotiators . 
the house version of the bill does include the tax cut . 
now republican leaders are UNKNOWN on UNKNOWN a capital-gains amendment to some other bill , perhaps a measure raising the federal borrowing limit or a second tax bill that would follow on the heels of the deficit-reduction legislation . 
to help lay the UNKNOWN for that fight , president bush plans early next week to meet at the white house with some 99 democratic senators who favor cutting the capital-gains tax or are UNKNOWN on the issue . 
the president apparently will have only one bill to push , sen. packwood 's , and at least some of the dissident democrats plan to support it . 
`` i may want to offer additional amendments to improve it when the bill comes to the floor , '' said sen. david boren ( d. , UNKNOWN ) , a leader of those democrats . 
the packwood plan , as expected , would allow individuals to exclude from income 9 % of the gain from the sale of a capital asset held for more than one year . 
the exclusion would rise five percentage points for each year the asset was held , until it reached a maximum of 99 % after seven years . 
the exclusion would apply to assets sold after oct. 9 . 
as an alternative , taxpayers could chose to reduce their gains by an inflation index . 
for corporations , the top tax rate on the sale of assets held for more than three years would be cut to 99 % from the current top rate of 99 % . 
that rate would gradually decline to as little as 99 % for corporate assets held for 99 years . 
the packwood plan also would include a proposal , designed by sen. william roth ( r. , UNKNOWN ) , that would create new tax benefits for individual retirement accounts . 
the roth plan would create a new , UNKNOWN UNKNOWN from which money could be withdrawn tax-free not only for retirement , but also for the purchase of a first home , education expenses and medical expenses . 
current iras could be rolled over into the new iras , but would be subject to tax though no penalty .

for example , `` no load '' mutual funds remain a favorite with investors because they do n't carry a UNKNOWN sales commission . 
getting out of them , however , may be a different story now .

in recent years , though , a UNKNOWN of others flying the UNKNOWN flag have been imposing hefty charges -- all the way up to 9 % -- when an investor sells his shares . 
should n't they properly be called UNKNOWN funds ?

finally , even the UNKNOWN strategy called `` value investing '' no longer means what it once did . 
before the takeover UNKNOWN of the '99s , it referred to UNKNOWN out through analysis undervalued stocks , especially those with UNKNOWN management , sound fundamentals and decent prospects . 
now , says mr. UNKNOWN , value investing often means `` looking for UNKNOWN companies with terrible management that are in real trouble . ''

i was UNKNOWN to read your recent news stories on the banking industry 's reserve UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN threats to UNKNOWN making new loans to less-developed countries .

-- during the 9999s the commercial banks UNKNOWN the country loan business away from the bond markets where the discipline of a prospectus and `` use of proceeds '' confirmation allowed lenders to audit expenditures of old loans before new loans were made . 
-- the reward for that reckless lending was high reported earnings ( and management bonuses ) ; the price , a sea of bad loans . 
-- for the past several years , the banks , lacking a private navy to enforce their interests , have been UNKNOWN the u.s. treasury to underwrite their bad UNKNOWN credits . 
-- the treasury UNKNOWN has refused , but has concluded that indirect credit support through various UNKNOWN agencies should be made available for a price : either debt reduction or UNKNOWN reduction or new loans ( the brady plan ) . 
-- the banks will UNKNOWN not to make further loans , but in truth , lacking the capital to write off their mistakes or to build a navy , they have no alternative but to go along .
