in his affidavit filed yesterday , warner 's mr. ross indicated he is n't buying any such argument : `` if sony succeeds here , no written contract in hollywood will be worth the paper it 's written on . 
the sales pitch could n't sound better . 
first , there 's the name : `` asset-backed securities . '' 
better than all those offers you get to buy securities backed by nothing . 
and there 's more . 
the assets backing the securities come from some of the country 's biggest -- and most secure -- institutions . 
most earn high ratings from credit agencies . 
their yields are higher than those of u.s. treasury issues . 
and the booming market has already attracted many of the nation 's biggest institutional investors . 
ready to jump ? 
well , think twice . 
the concept may be simple : take a UNKNOWN of loans , tie them up in one UNKNOWN package , and sell pieces of the package to investors . 
but the UNKNOWN may be misleading . 
UNKNOWN say the slightly higher returns are n't enough to compensate for the extra risk . 
they UNKNOWN that asset-backed securities are only as good as the assets and credit backing that support them -- and those are hard to evaluate . 
moreover , the securities were introduced only about 9 9\/9 years ago ; the biggest unknown is how they will fare in a recession . 
`` a lot of this stuff really is in UNKNOWN waters , '' says owen UNKNOWN , director of the investment securities division of the u.s. comptroller of the currency . 
`` we do n't know how this whole market will work in a serious economic downturn . '' 
such concerns , however , have n't stopped asset-backed securities from becoming one of wall street 's hottest new products . 
since the spring of 9999 , financial UNKNOWN have UNKNOWN a wide variety of debt into these new securities . 
they have sold issues backed by car loans , UNKNOWN loans and UNKNOWN loans . 
they have offered UNKNOWN of UNKNOWN loans , as well as packages of loans used to buy UNKNOWN UNKNOWN . 
last year , there was an issue of `` UNKNOWN bonds '' -- securities backed by loans to life-insurance policyholders . 
some predict there will be `` third world bonds , '' backed by loans to brazil , argentina and other UNKNOWN nations . 
and the biggest volume this year has been on securities backed by credit-card receivables , sometimes known as `` plastic bonds . '' 
`` this is the UNKNOWN of debt , '' says james grant , editor of grant 's interest rate UNKNOWN , a newsletter . 
`` before the sun sets on the '99s , it seems nothing will be left UNKNOWN . '' 
the result is a $ 99 billion market , according to securities data co . 
that includes more than $ 9.9 billion issued through august of this year , up sharply from $ 9.9 billion in the comparable 9999 period -- and more than in all of 9999 . 
most issues have been sold to professional money managers , pension funds , bank trust departments and other institutions . 
but wealthy individuals also have been jumping in , and lately brokers have been pushing smaller investors into the asset-backed market . 
the entry fee is affordable : issues typically are sold in minimum denominations of $ 9,999 . 
`` we expect additional offerings '' of asset-backed securities targeted toward individual investors , says bill UNKNOWN , a senior vice president at shearson lehman hutton inc . 
the process typically begins when an institution , such as citibank or sears , roebuck & co. , takes a pool of credit-card or other receivables and sells them to a specially created trust . 
the trust then issues securities -- generally due in five years or less -- that are underwritten by wall street brokerage firms and offered to investors . 
issues typically come with `` credit enhancements , '' such as a bank letter of credit , and thus have received high credit ratings . 
UNKNOWN say the booming market has opened up a valuable new source of funds to issuers , while providing a valuable new investment for individuals and institutions . 
asset-backed securities `` are an attractive investment compared to bank certificates of deposit or other corporate bonds , '' says craig j. goldberg , managing director and head of the asset-backed securities group at merrill lynch capital markets . 
but UNKNOWN question whether asset-backed bonds offer sufficient rewards to compensate for the extra risks . 
consider a $ 999 million offering of 9 % securities issued last spring and backed by citibank credit-card receivables . 
the UNKNOWN issue offered a yield of only about 9.9 percentage point above four-year treasury issues . 
on a $ 99,999 investment , that 's a difference of only $ 99 a year . 
that kind of spread can be critical for money managers who buy bonds in large quantities and whose UNKNOWN depends on UNKNOWN the money manager across the street . 
but for individuals who buy much smaller amounts and care less about relative performance than in UNKNOWN what they have , that margin is UNKNOWN . 
`` if you 're in the bond business playing the UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , then even an extra 99 basis points ( 9.99 percentage point ) becomes an important consideration on a career basis , '' says mr. grant . 
`` but if you 're an individual investing money and trying to get it back again , then that is n't of overwhelming importance . '' 
moreover , the interest on asset-backed securities is fully taxable , while interest on treasury issues is tax-free at the state and local level . 
that 's why some investment managers , such as alex powers , a vice president of chase manhattan bank 's private banking division , do n't recommend most asset-backed issues for individuals in UNKNOWN states , such as new york or california . 
but mr. powers has purchased asset-backed issues for individuals with UNKNOWN accounts , such as retirement plans . 
he points out that institutions buying asset-backed issues in large quantities can earn higher UNKNOWN over treasurys than individuals buying smaller amounts . 
another concern is liquidity , or how easily a security can be converted into cash . 
the secondary , or UNKNOWN , market for asset-backed securities is relatively new and much less active than for treasury issues . 
that could make it tricky for investors who need to sell their holdings quickly before the securities mature . 
that 's particularly true , analysts say , for certain of the securities , such as those backed by UNKNOWN loans . 
`` you could see massive gyrations here because it 's such a UNKNOWN traded market , '' says jonathan s. paris , a vice president of european investors inc. , a new york UNKNOWN firm . 
in addition , an investor who wants to know the daily value of treasury bonds , or corporate bonds traded on the new york stock exchange , can simply check newspaper UNKNOWN . 
there are n't any such UNKNOWN for asset-backed securities . 
evaluating asset-backed securities UNKNOWN another problem . 
investors , for instance , may UNKNOWN assume that the bank or company that originally held the assets is guaranteeing the securities . 
it is n't . 
the front cover of the prospectus for the citibank credit-card receivables offering points out in bold capital letters that the certificates represent an interest only in the specially created trust and `` do not represent interests in or obligations of the banks , citibank UNKNOWN , citicorp or any affiliate UNKNOWN . '' 
in other words , if there 's a problem , do n't expect citibank to come to the rescue . 
the prospectus also notes that the securities are not guaranteed by any government agency . 
that means investors have to focus on the quality of the debt that lies beneath the securities , as well as on the credit UNKNOWN for the issue and the credit ratings the issue has received . 
that also is n't easy . 
take the `` credit enhancements , '' which typically include a bank letter of credit or insurance from a UNKNOWN company . 
the letter of credit typically is not offered by the bank selling the assets to back the securities . 
nor does it cover the entire portfolio . 
details of credit enhancements vary widely from issue to issue . 
still , they play a crucial role in winning top ratings for most asset-backed issues -- which in turn is why the yield above treasurys is so slim . 
but UNKNOWN ask why you should bother buying this stuff when you can get only slightly lower yields on UNKNOWN paper . 
when you buy an asset-backed issue , you take the risk that a bank or an insurer could run into unexpected difficulties . 
if a bank 's credit rating was lowered because of , say , its loans to third world nations , that could also affect the ratings , liquidity and prices of the asset-backed issues that the bank supports . 
underwriters insist these issues are UNKNOWN to withstand extremely tough economic conditions . 
but despite the credit enhancements , despite the high ratings , some money managers still worry that a recession could UNKNOWN UNKNOWN on the underlying assets . 
at a time when americans are leveraged to their UNKNOWN , asset-backed investors may be taking a UNKNOWN gamble that consumers will be able to repay loans in hard times . 
at the very least , a recession would UNKNOWN investors to buy the UNKNOWN bonds they can find -- that is , treasurys . 
that could UNKNOWN the yield spread between treasurys and asset-backed securities , as well as make it tougher to UNKNOWN the latter . 
but it could be much worse . 
some analysts are especially wary of credit-card issues . 
for one thing , credit-card loans are unsecured . 
in addition , they fear that banks have been UNKNOWN to issue cards to the public -- giving cards to too many big UNKNOWN who will default during a recession . 
`` a day of UNKNOWN is coming where we think the market will place a high premium on the UNKNOWN debt issues , and therefore we think the best debt investment is u.s. government bonds , '' says craig UNKNOWN of davis / UNKNOWN futures inc. , an investment advisory firm . 
what about UNKNOWN asset-backed issues ? 
`` UNKNOWN , we still say to stick with treasurys , '' mr. UNKNOWN replies . 
ratings , he notes , `` are subject to change . '' 
all this makes asset-backed securities seem too risky for many people . 
and it UNKNOWN raymond f. devoe jr. , a market strategist at UNKNOWN mason wood walker inc. , of what he calls `` devoe 's UNKNOWN but highly UNKNOWN theory no. 9 : 
`` more money has been lost reaching for yield than in all the stock UNKNOWN , scams and UNKNOWN of all time . ''

if you force financial planners to sum up their most important advice in a single sentence , it would probably be a UNKNOWN sentence : diversify . 
judging by a poll of wall street journal readers conducted this summer by UNKNOWN & morgan inc. , serious investors have taken that advice to heart . 
nearly 9,999 investors responded to the journal 's poll , providing an UNKNOWN look at their portfolios . 
those portfolios are UNKNOWN diversified . 
by spreading their wealth among several investment alternatives , the respondents have protected themselves against UNKNOWN in any one area , be it stocks , bonds or real estate . 
for example , about 99 % of journal readers owned stock ( down slightly from 99 % in a similar poll last year ) . 
but only 99.9 % said they had more than half their money in the stock market . 
similarly , 99 % of respondents own shares in a money-market mutual fund , and 99 % own municipal bonds . 
but only 9 % to 9 % of the investors were UNKNOWN more than half their funds to either of those alternatives . 
the poll , conducted aug. UNKNOWN , also provides a UNKNOWN into the thinking of serious investors on a variety of other UNKNOWN . 
it found them in a cautious , but not UNKNOWN , mood . 
of 9,999 people sent a UNKNOWN , 999 UNKNOWN . 
the response rate , more than 99 % , allows the results to be interpreted with a high degree of confidence . 
the results ca n't be UNKNOWN to all investors , though . 
journal readers are relatively affluent , with a median household income of between $ 99,999 and $ 99,999 . 
nearly half of the respondents ( 99 % ) said their investment portfolio was worth $ 999,999 or more , and 99 % said it was worth $ 9 million or more . 
the respondents were mildly optimistic about the economy and investment markets , but their UNKNOWN judgments were a UNKNOWN more UNKNOWN than they were a year ago . 
for example , 99 % of this year 's respondents said they expect a recession within 99 months . 
last year , only 9 % were expecting a recession . 
an additional 99 % of this year 's respondents expect the economy to slow down during the next 99 months . 
only 99 % of last year 's respondents anticipated slowing growth . 
apparently , the respondents do n't think that an economic slowdown would harm the major investment markets very much . 
a slim majority ( 99 % ) think stock prices will be higher in august 9999 than they were in august 9999 . 
their verdict on real estate is almost the same . 
some 99 % expect real estate in their local area to increase in value over the next 99 months . 
by contrast , only 99 % expect an increase in the price of gold . 
since gold tends to soar when inflation is high , that finding suggests that people believe inflation remains under control . 
even though only 99 % actually predicted a recession , many respondents were taking a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN investment stance . 
nearly a third said they have made some portfolio changes to anticipate a possible recession . 
for the most part , the changes were `` slight . '' 
the two-thirds who have n't tried to make their portfolios more UNKNOWN were split about evenly between investors who `` do n't believe in trying to predict the markets '' ( about 99 % ) and investors who `` do n't expect a recession '' ( about 99 % ) or are `` UNKNOWN if and when a recession might come '' ( about 99 % ) . 
a UNKNOWN approach to stocks continues to be the rule among respondents . 
most own two to 99 stocks , and buy or sell no more than three times a year . 
some 99 % had bought some stock in the past year ; only 99 % had sold any . 
but the UNKNOWN shadow of 9999 's stock-market crash still seems dark . 
about 99 % considered another crash `` likely , '' while about 99 % said one is `` unlikely . '' 
those UNKNOWN hardly changed from the previous year 's poll . 
and the respondents ' commitment to the stock market remains somewhat UNKNOWN than usual . 
about 99 % of them said they would `` ordinarily '' have at least 99 % of their money in stocks . 
but as of august , only 99 % actually had stock-market investments of that size . 
most stock-market indexes were UNKNOWN UNKNOWN highs at around the time of the poll . 
but it appears that many journal readers were taking that news as a sign to be cautious , rather than a signal to jump on the UNKNOWN .

electronic theft by foreign and industrial UNKNOWN and disgruntled employees is UNKNOWN u.s. companies billions and UNKNOWN their international competitive advantage . 
that was the message delivered by government and private security experts at an UNKNOWN conference on corporate electronic UNKNOWN . 
`` hostile and even friendly nations routinely steal information from u.s. companies and share it with their own companies , '' said UNKNOWN d. UNKNOWN , a former UNKNOWN at the federal national security agency and now president of information security inc. , silver spring , md .

banco popular de puerto rico and banponce corp. -- agreed to merge in a transaction valued at $ 999 million . 
under the agreement , banponce stockholders will be able to exchange each of their shares for either shares in the new entity or cash . 
in each case , the exchange is valued at $ 99.99 a share . 
the two companies , both based in san UNKNOWN , will form a bank holding company with assets of just over $ 9 billion . 
the holding company will be called banponce corp . 
the primary subsidiary will be the combined banking operations of the two companies and will be known as banco popular de puerto rico . 
UNKNOWN UNKNOWN jr. , chairman of banco popular , will be the chairman of the holding company . 
UNKNOWN m. UNKNOWN , currently chairman of banponce , will serve as president of the bank holding company and chairman of the subsidiary . 
banco popular originally proposed the merger in july , in a cash and stock transaction valued at $ 99 a share , or about $ 999 million . 
banponce reacted UNKNOWN at first , but appeared to be won over , analysts said , by banco popular 's assurances that it wanted only a friendly transaction . 
`` banco popular just kept waiting , '' said edward thompson , a vice president and analyst at UNKNOWN UNKNOWN inc. in new york . 
`` they got a transaction that 's good for both companies . '' 
the two banks appear to be a good fit .

the prices of corn futures contracts jumped amid rumors that the soviet union is keeping up its UNKNOWN october buying UNKNOWN of u.s. corn . 
those rumors were confirmed after the end of trading yesterday when the u.s. agriculture department announced that the soviets had bought 9.9 million metric tons of u.s. corn , bringing their u.s. corn purchases confirmed so far this month to about five million metric tons . 
in trading at the chicago board of trade , the corn contract for december delivery jumped 9.99 cents a bushel to settle at $ 9.99 a bushel . 
the soviet purchases are close to exceeding what some analysts had expected the soviet union to buy this fall , the season in which it usually buys much of the corn it imports from the u.s. . 
that pace is causing some analysts to speculate that the soviet union might soon purchase as much as another two million metric tons . 
one sign that more soviet purchases are possible is that u.s. grain companies yesterday bought an unusually large amount of corn futures contracts . 
that sometimes signals that they are UNKNOWN plans to export corn . 
by some estimates , several grain companies combined bought contracts for the UNKNOWN of roughly one million metric tons of corn . 
by buying futures contracts , these companies attempt to protect themselves from swings in the price of the corn that they are UNKNOWN to deliver . 
rumors of soviet interest also pushed up the prices of soybean futures contracts . 
among other things , the agriculture department is widely thought to be UNKNOWN whether to UNKNOWN the sale of soybean oil to the soviet union . 
on top of all this , corn and soybean prices rose on reports that the midwest harvest was disrupted by a UNKNOWN early snow storm that dumped several inches in parts of indiana and ohio . 
the harvest delays , however , are expected to be temporary . 
UNKNOWN UNKNOWN are forecast for next week , said robert UNKNOWN , an analyst at farmers grain & UNKNOWN corp. , chicago . 
many farmers used the jump in prices to sell their recently UNKNOWN crop to grain UNKNOWN companies . 
the heavy selling by farmers helped to damp the price rally .

also , the analyst said , economic circumstances are such that both south africa and the soviet union , the principal gold and platinum producers , are being forced to continue selling the metals . 
both are in great need of foreign exchange , and south africa is also under pressure to meet foreign loan commitments , he said . 
`` putting it all together , we have a negative scenario that does n't look like it will improve overnight , '' he said . 
copper : 
futures prices recovered in quiet trading . 
the december contract rose 9.99 cents a pound to $ 9.9999 . 
that contract fell a total of 9.99 cents during the first three days of this week , mostly in reaction to last friday 's stock market plunge , which prompted concern that it might signal a similar sharp slowing of the u.s. economy and thus reduced demand for copper , a leading industrial metal . 
in recent days , however , there has been increased purchasing of copper in london , an analyst said . 
some of this buying was by japan , which has had its supplies sharply reduced by long production UNKNOWN at the UNKNOWN mine in UNKNOWN new UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN valley mine in british columbia , and the cananea mine in mexico , which are major shippers to japan . 
the increasing likelihood that cananea and UNKNOWN valley will soon return to production may have cut some of that purchasing , but even if any of these mines begin operating soon , their output wo n't be significant until at least the end of the year , analysts note . 
so , one analyst said , even though the long-term production problems may be easing , there will still be a significant need for copper over the next three months , when inventories will remain relatively low .

suits are likely to be filed against engineering firms , contractors and developers , as well as against UNKNOWN agencies . 
but lawyers looking to cash in on the quake may have a tough time once their cases reach a judge . 
experts on california UNKNOWN law say UNKNOWN UNKNOWN government agencies in such cases are pretty UNKNOWN . 
even claims against individuals and companies face significant UNKNOWN . 
the major legal barrier is the principle that no one can be held liable for an `` act of god . '' 
for now , says laurence UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN of the UNKNOWN california trial lawyers association , `` the last thing we really need to worry about is whether anybody is going to get sued , or whether they have liability or not . 
we still have people UNKNOWN around in a UNKNOWN in san francisco UNKNOWN about whether it 's going to rain UNKNOWN . '' 
but that wo n't stop plaintiffs ' lawyers from seeking a little room for UNKNOWN . 
in san francisco , they argue , an earthquake was a near UNKNOWN .

`` my UNKNOWN is there will be mass litigation over errors and UNKNOWN in engineering and UNKNOWN , '' says stanley UNKNOWN , a well-known cincinnati plaintiffs lawyer .

he adds that `` they were aware of the UNKNOWN for earthquakes and the san andreas fault . ''

`` a lot of this is going to be UNKNOWN , '' says UNKNOWN j. ruvolo , a construction law specialist at UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN & UNKNOWN , a san francisco law firm . 
plaintiffs , he says , will argue that damaged structures were n't built to proper design standards . 
but if defendants can prove that they met san francisco 's UNKNOWN building codes , `` that 's probably going to protect them , '' mr. ruvolo says . 
government entities , continues mr. ruvolo , could be protected by the california government UNKNOWN liability act . 
under the statute , agencies are provided `` UNKNOWN that normally are n't available in the private sector , '' mr. ruvolo says . 
`` the legislature does not want to UNKNOWN the unique government activities by UNKNOWN public entities to liability . '' 
built into the statute are so-called design UNKNOWN , which are likely to protect government agencies , according to mr. ruvolo and richard covert , a lawyer with the california department of transportation , which UNKNOWN the damaged bay bridge . 
the state is protected when plans and designs for public structures were approved ahead of time or when structures met previously approved standards , says mr. covert . 
he believes those UNKNOWN might well apply to the bay bridge collapse . 
nevertheless , he adds , `` i would n't get totally UNKNOWN if we get lawsuits out of the bay bridge . ''

tuesday 's UNKNOWN of a gop congressional hopeful in a mississippi district that has n't backed a democratic presidential candidate since UNKNOWN UNKNOWN is another reminder that , at least at the federal level , political `` ticket splitting '' has been on the rise over the past half century . 
in only one presidential election year prior to 9999 did more than 99 % of the nation 's congressional districts choose a different party 's candidate for the white house than for the house of representatives . 
now that percentage routinely UNKNOWN a third and twice has been above 99 % . 
as we know , voters tend to favor republicans more in races for president than in those for congress . 
in every presidential election over the past half century , except for the UNKNOWN presidential UNKNOWN , the gop has captured a greater percentage of the UNKNOWN popular vote for president than it has of congressional seats or the popular vote for congress . 
prior to 9999 , the pattern was nearly the opposite . 
what accounts for the results of recent decades ? 
a simple economic theory may provide at least a partial explanation for the split UNKNOWN UNKNOWN by americans in the voting UNKNOWN . 
the theory relies on three assumptions : 
9 ) voters can `` buy '' one of two brands when they select their political agents -- a republican brand that believes in the UNKNOWN state and in the UNKNOWN of private markets over the UNKNOWN of public action , and a democratic brand that believes in big government and in public UNKNOWN to remedy the UNKNOWN UNKNOWN to the pursuit of private interest . 
9 ) congressional representatives have two basic responsibilities while voting in office -- dealing with national issues ( UNKNOWN actions such as casting roll call votes on legislation that imposes costs and / or UNKNOWN benefits on the population at large ) and attending to local issues ( constituency service and pork barrel ) . 
9 ) republican congressional representatives , because of their belief in a UNKNOWN state , are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than are democratic members of congress . 
if these assumptions hold , voters in races for congress face what in economic theory is called a UNKNOWN 's dilemma and have an incentive , at the margin , to lean democratic . 
if they put a republican into office , not only will they acquire less in terms of local benefits but their selected legislator will be relatively UNKNOWN to prevent other legislators from `` bringing home the UNKNOWN '' to their respective UNKNOWN . 
each legislator , after all , is only one out of 999 when it comes to national policy making . 
in races for the white house , a UNKNOWN 's incentive , at the margin , is to lean republican . 
although a gop president may limit local benefits to the UNKNOWN 's particular district / state , such a president is also likely to be more effective at preventing other districts / states and their legislators from bringing home the local benefits . 
the individual UNKNOWN 's standing consequently will be enhanced through lower taxes . 
while this theory is UNKNOWN simple , it appears to explain several things . 
first , why ticket splitting has increased and taken the UNKNOWN pattern that it has over the past half century : prior to the election of franklin UNKNOWN as president and the UNKNOWN of the new deal , government occupied a much smaller role in society and the UNKNOWN 's dilemma problem UNKNOWN voters in races for congress was considerably less severe . 
second , it explains why voters hold congress in UNKNOWN but generally love their own congressional representatives : any individual legislator 's constituents appreciate the specific benefits that the legislator UNKNOWN for them but not the overall cost associated with every other legislator doing likewise for his own constituency . 
third , the theory suggests why legislators who pay too much attention to national policy making relative to local benefit-seeking have lower security in office . 
for example , UNKNOWN members of the house , once the most vulnerable of UNKNOWN , have become virtually immune to defeat . 
the one exception to this recent trend was the defeat of 99 of the 99 UNKNOWN republicans brought into office in 9999 by the reagan revolution and running for UNKNOWN in 9999 . 
because these UNKNOWN placed far more emphasis on their UNKNOWN role -- spreading the reagan revolution -- in national policy making , they were more vulnerable to defeat . 
fourth , the theory indicates why the republican party may have a difficult time attracting viable candidates for congressional office . 
potential candidates may be UNKNOWN from running less by the congressional salary than by the prospect of defeat at the hands of a democratic opponent . 
to the extent that potential republican candidates and their financial UNKNOWN realize that the congressional UNKNOWN 's dilemma game works to their UNKNOWN , the republican party will be UNKNOWN in its attempts to field a competitive slate of congressional candidates . 
fifth , the theory may provide at least a partial reason for why ticket splitting has been particularly UNKNOWN in the south . 
to the extent that democratic legislators from the south have held a disproportionate share of power in congress since 9999 and have been able to UNKNOWN such UNKNOWN into relatively more local benefits for their respective UNKNOWN , voters in the south have had an especially strong incentive to keep such democrats in office . 
finally , the theory suggests why republicans generally have fared better in senate races than in campaigns for the house . 
since local benefit-seeking matters more and national policy making matters less in the lower chamber of congress , this is precisely the pattern one would expect if republicans are less willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their democratic counterparts . 
is there any UNKNOWN support for this theory ? 
three pieces of evidence UNKNOWN the key assumption that democratic legislators are more willing to engage in local benefit-seeking than their republican colleagues . 
first , economists james bennett and thomas UNKNOWN find that gop senators turn back roughly 99 % more of their allocated personal staff budgets than democrats do . 
to the extent that the primary duty of personal staff involves local benefit-seeking , this indicates that political philosophy leads congressional republicans to pay less attention to narrow UNKNOWN concerns . 
second , if the key assumption is valid , democrats should have lower attendance rates on UNKNOWN votes than republicans do to the extent that such votes reflect national policy making and that participating in such votes takes away from the time a legislator could otherwise UNKNOWN to local benefit-seeking . 
this is indeed what the data indicate , particularly in the case of the house . 
the democratic house attendance rate has not exceeded the republican house attendance rate since 9999 . 
finally , as shown in the table , democrats UNKNOWN a higher proportion of their personal UNKNOWN to district offices -- where local benefit-seeking duties matter more and national policy making activities matter less relative to washington offices . 
an examination of changes in personal UNKNOWN decisions in the senate between 9999 and 9999 ( when control of that body changed party hands ) , moreover , UNKNOWN that the personal UNKNOWN differences noted in the table can not be attributed to the disproportionate control democrats exercise , due to their UNKNOWN status , over other resources such as committee staff . 
an additional piece of evidence from the senate : holding other factors constant , such as UNKNOWN advantages and regional factors , the difference between popular votes for republican presidential and UNKNOWN candidates in states conducting a senate election turns out to be a positive function of how onerous the federal government 's tax burden is per state ( a UNKNOWN tax rate hits UNKNOWN states harder ) . 
put more simply , gop candidates for president are looked on more UNKNOWN by voters than republican candidates for the senate when the UNKNOWN 's dilemma is more severe . 
moreover , ticket splitting appears to take the same UNKNOWN pattern at the state government level as it does at the federal level . 
state government is more typically split along UNKNOWN / UNKNOWN lines than the reverse . 
a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN investigation , furthermore , UNKNOWN that , holding other factors constant , the difference between a state 's UNKNOWN vote going to the republican gubernatorial candidate and the republican share of the lower state house is a positive function of the state tax rate . 
in sum , at both the federal and state government levels at least part of the seemingly UNKNOWN behavior voters display in the voting UNKNOWN may have an UNKNOWN rational explanation .

is an american secretary of state seriously suggesting that the khmer rouge should help govern cambodia ? 
apparently so .

recall that nicaragua 's sandinistas came into UNKNOWN as partners in a coalition government with UNKNOWN UNKNOWN .

tuesday 's earthquake will depress local real-estate values in the short term and force companies to UNKNOWN expanding in or UNKNOWN to the bay area and california , real-estate and relocation specialists said . 
few specialists said they expect the quake to have much of an effect on most california property values . 
but real-estate experts and brokers said the quake UNKNOWN will drag down prices in neighborhoods built on less stable ground , especially in the bay area . 
`` california prices were already coming down . 
this is n't going to help , '' said kenneth t. rosen , chairman of the center for real estate and urban economics at the university of california at berkeley . 
state housing prices , at a median $ 999,999 , have declined in recent months because of potential buyers ' UNKNOWN to afford homes . 
mr. rosen , among others , suggested that the quake , the strongest since the 9999 temblor that struck san francisco , will in the short term create a two-tier price system for UNKNOWN communities , with dwellings built on UNKNOWN ground likely to demand higher prices . 
one san francisco neighborhood likely to test mr. rosen 's theory soon is the city 's UNKNOWN marina district , which boasts some of the highest home prices in the state . 
the district , built on landfill , suffered heavy quake damage , including collapsed buildings . 
yesterday , the city UNKNOWN two dwellings in the district because of severe structural damage and said as many as 99 of the district 's 999 dwellings might have to be UNKNOWN . 
brokers agreed with the two-tier price theory . 
`` my UNKNOWN feeling is that the marina properties will be affected , '' said grace UNKNOWN , senior vice president at UNKNOWN & ellis residential brokerage inc . 
neither she nor other real-estate executives and brokers could project how much less marina properties might bring , but she said the two-tier price structure would affect prices `` for a while . '' 
mr. rosen said the quake will revive consumer interest in a UNKNOWN 9999 state law that requires brokers to disclose to potential buyers how close a property UNKNOWN to a fault line . 
because of the size of the california market , few relocation specialists expect a widespread corporate flight in the quake 's aftermath . 
but they said the quake will force some companies to UNKNOWN or expand part or all of their operations outside the state . 
`` what you 're going to get is ` we do n't want to put all of our eggs in one basket ' theory , '' said james h. UNKNOWN , president of location management services inc. , a palo alto , calif. , relocation concern . 
mr. UNKNOWN , among others , said the quake will UNKNOWN companies in certain industries , like semiconductors , computers and aerospace , to consider moving operations that involve particularly sensitive machinery to locations outside california . 
because of the quake threat , `` some firms have UNKNOWN what the cost is to shore up their buildings and compared it with the cost of building it UNKNOWN , '' he said . 
one southern california aerospace firm , for example , two months ago asked location management to compare the costs of UNKNOWN its current building against earthquakes with the cost of building a new structure elsewhere . 
a new UNKNOWN would cost $ 99 million , location management found , compared with $ 99 million to make the present building UNKNOWN .

h&r block is one of the great success stories of u.s. business .

( during its centennial year , the wall street journal will report events of the past century that stand as milestones of american business history . ) 
puts and calls , stock market UNKNOWN for options to sell or buy a company 's shares , were long an UNKNOWN wall street art best left to the experts , who used them either as a hedge or for pure speculation . 
options lost some of their mystery in 9999 when the chicago board of trade set up a special exchange to deal in them . 
until then , options had been traded only in the over-the-counter market , mostly in new york , and in an almost UNKNOWN secondary market operating UNKNOWN by telephone . 
the chicago board of trade , the no. 9 u.s. grain market , had long UNKNOWN under the attention won by its UNKNOWN archrival , the UNKNOWN mercantile exchange . 
so the men who ran the grain UNKNOWN UNKNOWN when joseph sullivan , a 99-year-old former wall street journal UNKNOWN , offered them the idea of UNKNOWN trading . 
after four year of UNKNOWN and $ 9.9 million in UNKNOWN money , the board set up the new marketplace , UNKNOWN it the chicago board options exchange , and named sullivan its first president . 
the UNKNOWN were modest . 
the cboe opened for business on april 99 , 9999 , in what had been a board of trade UNKNOWN . 
it listed just 99 options to buy a `` pilot list '' of stocks on the new york stock exchange . 
( puts , or sell options , would not be added until 9999 . ) 
the 999 members had paid $ 99,999 apiece for seats . 
( the 9999 price : $ 999,999 . ) 
the first day 's business was 999 contracts ( each for 999 shares of one of the listed stocks ) . 
by the end of 9999 , the number of `` underlying '' big board stocks had been increased to 99 and the options exchange had run up volume of 9.9 million contracts . 
a year later , it was 9.9 million . 
last year , more than 9,999 traders on the cboe bought and sold 999 million contracts on 999 listed stocks , 99 % of all u.s. listed options trading . 
the new exchange drew instant recognition from an unwelcome quarter . 
the government , UNKNOWN against fixed brokerage commissions , promptly sued the cboe over its UNKNOWN system .

where do americans put their money ? 
it depends on when you look . 
in 9999 , for instance , less than 9 % of assets went into bank deposits . 
that rose to nearly 99 % during the depression , and has n't changed much since . 
pension reserves , on the other hand , made up a relatively small part of household assets until the last decade , when they UNKNOWN . 
and there has been a UNKNOWN decline in the importance of UNKNOWN business assets -- thanks to industry UNKNOWN and a decline in family farms . 
that 's some of what UNKNOWN from the following charts , which show how americans have changed their investment patterns over the past 99 years . 
some results are UNKNOWN . 
but other figures are surprising . 
housing , for instance , has remained a fairly steady component of household assets over the past decade -- although common wisdom would have expected an increase . 
`` there is a lot of attention paid to housing as a form of household wealth , '' says edward n. UNKNOWN , professor of economics at new york university . 
`` but it has n't increased much relative to other assets . 
it suggests that households UNKNOWN wealth across a broad UNKNOWN of assets . 
and housing though it appears in the popular mind as being the major { growing } household asset , is n't . '' 
in addition , investors ' desire to hold stocks -- directly and through mutual funds -- has held surprisingly steady ; stocks ' importance among assets largely reflects the ups and UNKNOWN of the stock market , and not a shift in UNKNOWN preferences . 
`` stocks have not spread to the general public , despite the fact that the environment is much different , '' concludes robert UNKNOWN , an economist at cornell university . 
`` to me it says that despite all the views that we spend too much of our wealth on paper assets , we have ways of holding wealth similar to 999 years ago . '' 
-- the charts show how UNKNOWN assets have been distributed over time . 
the main components of the various UNKNOWN categories : housing : primary home , but not the land it 's on . 
land and other real estate : land on which primary home is built , investment property . 
consumer UNKNOWN : automobiles , appliances , furniture . 
bank deposits : currency , UNKNOWN deposits , small savings and time deposits , certificates of deposits , money-market fund shares . 
bonds : UNKNOWN bond funds . 
stocks / mutual funds : stocks and mutual funds other than money-market funds . 
UNKNOWN business : partnerships and sole UNKNOWN , professional corporations . 
pension reserves : holdings by pension funds .

after last friday 's stock-market plunge , investment professionals cautioned people to resist the urge to call their brokers and sell stocks . 
not selling into a panic turned out to be very good advice : despite the market 's volatility , the dow jones industrial average has surged 999 points in the past four days . 
now , with a UNKNOWN of normalcy returning , some advisers say it 's time for investors to take a hard , cold look at the stocks they own and consider some careful UNKNOWN . 
`` the market is sending nervous signals , '' says peter j. canelo , chief market strategist for bear , stearns & co. , and it 's `` UNKNOWN '' to be UNKNOWN to stocks . 
alan UNKNOWN , president of UNKNOWN capital management , a los angeles UNKNOWN firm , adds that in periods of uncertainty like today , `` it 's a good time to cut out the dead branches of your portfolio . '' 
not everybody agrees that it 's time to trim . 
`` we are n't inclined to UNKNOWN stock portfolios now , '' says steven g. einhorn , chairman of the investment policy committee of goldman , sachs & co . 
`` investors should stay with their stocks . 
we expect a UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN market for a short period , but we do n't think it will be UNKNOWN . 
the UNKNOWN is limited . '' 
and even those who say some selective selling may be in order stress that individuals need to be in the stock market to achieve their long-term investment objectives and to help balance their other assets . 
any selling , they say , should be well UNKNOWN , and executed gradually , during market rallies . 
they offer these suggestions : 
get rid of the dogs . 
`` sell stocks that are n't doing well now , and that do n't have good earnings prospects , '' says alfred goldman , technical analyst at st. UNKNOWN UNKNOWN edwards & sons . 
`` most people do just the opposite : they sell their winners and keep their losers . '' 
which types of stocks are most likely to qualify ? 
technology stocks , says mr. goldman . 
watch for earnings disappointments . 
a company does n't have to post a loss to be a candidate for sale , says charles i. UNKNOWN jr. , chief market strategist at merrill lynch & co . 
if earnings do n't live up to analysts ' expectations , he says , that 's enough to dump the stock . 
john UNKNOWN , director of research for the american association of individual investors , raises a UNKNOWN note . 
`` UNKNOWN a rule of UNKNOWN for your own judgment '' can be a mistake , he says . 
an earnings disappointment may reflect a situation that 's short-term . 
but mr. UNKNOWN says , `` the risk is that earnings disappointments will continue . '' 
the economy is UNKNOWN after six good years , and `` right now it 's better to shoot first and ask questions later . '' 
which types of stocks currently have the greatest earnings risks ? 
computer companies ; commodity cyclical stocks , like autos ; and retailing stocks , he says . 
UNKNOWN of heavy debt . 
the companies apt to run into earnings problems UNKNOWN are the ones with heavy debt UNKNOWN , says larry UNKNOWN , partner in the san mateo , calif. , UNKNOWN firm of UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN & kaiser . 
mr. canelo of bear stearns agrees : `` if we do have an economic slowdown , '' he says , `` companies with high debt ratios will be dumped UNKNOWN UNKNOWN . '' 
the best course for individual investors is to sell these stocks now , the two advisers say . 
sell ` UNKNOWN ' stocks . 
ual corp. 's difficulty in obtaining bank financing for its leveraged buy-out and its resulting price plunge is a UNKNOWN to what 's going to happen to `` takeover stocks , '' says mr. canelo . 
takeover activity will slow down as more and more banks UNKNOWN their lending requirements , he says . 
`` there 'll be fewer and fewer deals . '' 
moreover , many financial advisers say individuals should be in the stock market as long-term investors , not as traders trying to catch the next hot stock . 
in general , they say , avoid takeover stocks . 
compare UNKNOWN / UNKNOWN ratios with prospects . 
mr. canelo suggests that investors compare price / earnings ratios ( the price of a share of stock divided by a company 's per-share earnings for a 99-month period ) with projected growth rates . 
`` if you think earnings will grow at 99 % a year , it 's all right to pay 99 times earnings , '' he says . 
`` but do n't pay 99 times earnings for a company that 's expected to grow at 99 % a year . '' 
mr. canelo thinks the market will probably go higher , but `` will be UNKNOWN with stocks if the earnings are n't there . '' 
mr. UNKNOWN UNKNOWN that investors should n't UNKNOWN follow any specific price / earnings sell trigger . 
`` if you say sell UNKNOWN a company 's price / earnings ratio UNKNOWN 99 , that UNKNOWN out all your growth stocks , '' he says . 
`` you eliminate companies with substantial prospects that are moving up in price . '' 
UNKNOWN what has changed . 
tom UNKNOWN , market analyst at UNKNOWN edwards & sons inc. , says investors should consider selling if there has been a fundamental change in a company since they bought its stock . 
say you purchased a stock because of a new product that was in the works . 
now , because of various difficulties , the product has been scrapped . 
time to sell , says mr. UNKNOWN . 
similarly , he says , UNKNOWN you were attracted to a company because of expectations that sales would hit $ 999 million by 9999 . 
if things have n't worked out that well , and sales wo n't hit $ 999 million until 9999 , it 's time to consider selling , he says .

the provision rate was far above bankamerica 's actual net credit losses of $ 99 million in the third quarter , compared with $ 99 million in the second period and $ 99 million a year earlier .

that level is about the same as some other big banks , but far below the 99 % and 999 % reserves of bankers trust new york corp. and UNKNOWN morgan & co. , respectively . 
by any measure , third-quarter earnings were still robust , equivalent to a 9.99 % return on assets even excluding tax credits . 
by that key measure of operating efficiency , bankamerica turned in a better performance than its UNKNOWN los angeles-based competitor , security pacific corp. , which posted a 9.99 % return in the third quarter . 
but it continued to badly trail its san francisco neighbor , wells fargo & co. , which reported an extraordinary 9.99 % return on assets . 
both returns do n't include any tax credits .

international business machines corp. will announce on tuesday a slew of software products aimed at eliminating some of the major problems involved in computerizing manufacturing operations , industry executives said . 
many plant floors currently UNKNOWN a tower of UNKNOWN , with computers , UNKNOWN and machine tools that generally speak their own language and have trouble talking to each other . 
as a result , if a problem develops on a production line , it is unlikely some supervisor sitting in front of a personal computer or workstation will know about it or be able to correct it . 
so ibm will be announcing more than 99 products that will be aimed at letting even the UNKNOWN machine UNKNOWN talk to the UNKNOWN mainframe , or anything in between . 
in an unusual display of openness , ibm also will be helping customers tie together operations that include lots of equipment made by ibm 's competitors . 
in addition , the executives said ibm will be offering programming tools designed to let anyone working on a factory floor write UNKNOWN software , for instance , to do statistical analysis that would pinpoint a problem on a manufacturing line . 
in armonk , n.y. , an ibm spokeswoman confirmed that ibm executives will be announcing some UNKNOWN plans next week but declined to elaborate . 
the industry executives said that , as usual with such broad announcements from ibm , this one will be part reality and part strategy . 
so it will take many quarters for ibm to roll out all the products that customers need , and it will take years for customers to integrate the products into their operations . 
also as usual , the products will appeal mostly to heavy users of ibm equipment , at least initially . 
still , consultants and industry executives said the products could help make manufacturing operations more efficient , and provide a boost to the UNKNOWN market -- a market that UNKNOWN group , a research firm , has said may double to $ 99 billion by 9999 . 
`` this is a step in the right direction , '' said martin UNKNOWN , a UNKNOWN group analyst . 
he added , though , that `` a lot of this is intentions ... . 
we 'll have to wait and see '' how the plan develops . 
the announcements also should help ibm go on the offensive against digital equipment corp. on the plant floor . 
while ibm has traditionally dominated the market for computers on the business side of manufacturing operations and has done well in the market for design tools , digital has dominated computerized manufacturing . 
hewlett-packard co. also has begun to gain share in the whole UNKNOWN arena . 
ibm will face an UNKNOWN climb against digital , given digital 's reputation for being better than ibm at UNKNOWN together different manufacturers ' computers . 
in addition , hewlett-packard , while a much smaller player , has made a big commitment to the sorts of industry standards that UNKNOWN those UNKNOWN and could give ibm some problems . 
both can be expected to go after the market aggressively : UNKNOWN group inc. , a research firm , estimated the digital gets 99 % of its revenue from the manufacturing market , and hewlett-packard gets 99 % . 
ibm , which UNKNOWN group said generates 99 % of its revenue in this market , should be able to take advantage of its loyal following among buyers of equipment . 
that is because many companies will UNKNOWN on certain types of equipment as the various parts of the manufacturing market merge , and ibm is the biggest player . 
but much will depend on how quickly ibm can move . 
the whole idea of UNKNOWN manufacturing , UNKNOWN , seems to be making a comeback after losing a little UNKNOWN over the past couple of years when it became apparent that it was n't a UNKNOWN that would make u.s. plants more efficient and UNKNOWN foreign competition . 
UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , a UNKNOWN group analyst , said organizational changes may still be required to really take advantage of UNKNOWN 's UNKNOWN -- someone on the shop floor may not like having someone in an office using a personal computer to look over his shoulder , for instance , and may be able to prevent that from happening . 
but he said a system such as ibm 's should help significantly . 
in making polyethylene sheets out of plastic chips , for instance , a chip sometimes does n't UNKNOWN , gets caught in the machinery and creates a run in the sheets . 
that can be expensive , because the problem may not be noticed for a while , and the sheets are typically thrown away . 
but mr. UNKNOWN said that , if computers can be integrated into the process , they could alert an operator as soon as the problem occurred . 
they could also check through the orders on file to find a customer that was willing to accept a lower grade of polyethylene . 
the computer would let the machine run just until that order was filled , eliminating waste . 
this sort of improved link figures to eventually become a significant weapon for some companies . 
companies might be able to tell salespeople daily , for instance , about idle equipment , so they could offer discounts on whatever that equipment produces . 
salespeople also could get a precise reading on when products could be delivered -- in much the same way that federal express has marketed its ability to tell exactly where a package is in the delivery system .

the house public works and transportation committee approved a bill that would give the transportation department power to block airline leveraged buy-outs , despite a clear veto threat from the bush administration . 
the UNKNOWN vote clears the way for consideration on the house floor next week or the week after . 
transportation secretary samuel skinner , in a letter to the committee , warned that he would urge president bush to veto the legislation if it passed congress . 
the senate commerce committee already has approved similar legislation . 
on monday , a letter from mr. skinner 's deputy , UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , said the administration opposed the legislation `` in its present form . '' 
some of the bill 's supporters had taken heart from the fact that the letter was n't signed by mr. skinner and that it did n't contain a veto threat . 
the UNKNOWN administration warnings annoyed some lawmakers , especially senior republicans who supported the bill because they thought the transportation department favored it . 
`` we backed this bill because we thought it would help skinner , '' one republican said , `` and now we 're out there UNKNOWN in the wind . '' 
a few weeks ago , mr. skinner UNKNOWN before congress that it would be `` UNKNOWN , more efficient '' if he had authority to block buy-outs in advance . 
but he never took an official position on the bill and has UNKNOWN maintained that he already has enough authority to deal with buy-outs . 
under the committee bill , the transportation secretary would have 99 days , and an additional 99 days if needed , to review any proposed purchase of 99 % or more of a major u.s. airline 's voting stock . 
the secretary would be required to block an acquisition if he concluded that it would so weaken an airline financially that it would hurt safety or reduce the carrier 's ability to compete , or if it gave control to a foreign interest . 
although the legislation would apply to any acquisition of a major airline , it is aimed at transactions financed by large amounts of debt . 
supporters of the bill are concerned an airline might UNKNOWN costly safety measures in order to repay debt . 
the panel 's action occurs in a politically charged atmosphere surrounding recent buy-out proposals , their apparent collapse and the volatile conditions in the stock market . 
`` it became apparent in hearings that there ought to be regulation of leveraged buy-outs of some sort , '' rep. james UNKNOWN ( d. , UNKNOWN ) , chairman of the house aviation subcommittee , said during the panel 's UNKNOWN . 
`` i do n't believe in the airline business you can be totally UNKNOWN because of the high degree of public interest '' at stake . 
but mr. skinner UNKNOWN , calling the legislation `` a retreat from the policy of UNKNOWN of the airline industry . '' 
in his letter to committee chairman glenn anderson ( d. , calif. ) , the secretary also said the bill `` would be at odds with the administration 's policies UNKNOWN open foreign investment and market allocation of resources . '' 
currently , the transportation department does n't have the authority to block a takeover in advance . 
however , if the secretary concludes that a transaction has made a carrier UNKNOWN to operate , the department may revoke its certificate , UNKNOWN the airline . 
such authority is more than adequate , say opponents of the legislation . 
but supporters argue that UNKNOWN an airline is so UNKNOWN that the department would UNKNOWN doing it . 
the panel rejected a proposal pushed by amr corp. , the parent of american airlines , to allow the transportation secretary to block corporate raiders from UNKNOWN proxy UNKNOWN to oust boards that oppose a leveraged buy-out . 
it also voted down proposals to give the secretary much more UNKNOWN on whether to block a buy-out and to require the department to consider the impact of a buy-out on workers .

housing construction sank in september to its lowest level since the last recession , the commerce department reported . 
work began on homes and apartments at an annual rate of 9,999,999 units last month , down 9.9 % from august , the department said . 
the september decline followed an even UNKNOWN drop of 9.9 % in august and left housing starts at their UNKNOWN since october 9999 , when the country was UNKNOWN the end of a recession . 
originally the department had reported the august decline as 9 % . 
the numbers suggest that the housing industry is still suffering the effects of the federal reserve 's battle against inflation . 
the industry had shown signs of recovery this summer , after the central bank began to UNKNOWN its UNKNOWN on credit , allowing interest rates to drop a bit after pushing them up for a year . 
sales of new homes rose and inventories of houses , which had been climbing , dropped . 
but last month new construction in all types of homes UNKNOWN , from UNKNOWN houses to large apartment UNKNOWN . 
`` it 's pretty much weak across the board , '' said martin UNKNOWN , chief economist of the national council of savings institutions . 
mr. UNKNOWN said the industry may be reluctant to step up building at the moment for fear the inventories of UNKNOWN homes will increase again . 
another reason for the weakness , he said , may be that mortgage rates have hit a UNKNOWN since they began UNKNOWN down after a peak in march . 
in august , rates on 99-year fixed-rate mortgages started UNKNOWN up a bit , but they inched down again through september . 
`` rates have n't really UNKNOWN off that much , '' mr. UNKNOWN said . 
`` we 've kind of settled now into an interest-rate environment that 's fairly high . '' 
work was begun on single family homes -- the core of the housing market -- at an annual rate of 999,999 in september , a drop of 9.9 % from the previous month . 
that followed a 9.9 % decline in august . 
construction of apartments and other UNKNOWN dwellings slipped 9.9 % to an annual rate of 9,999,999 following a 9.9 % decline in august . 
the number of building permits issued for future construction dropped 9.9 % to a 9,999,999 annual rate after rising 9.9 % in august . 
all the numbers were adjusted for normal seasonal variations in building activity . 
the housing starts numbers , however , are one of the least precise of the government 's economic indicators and are often revised significantly as more information is UNKNOWN .

power of suggestion stronger in japan 
here 's one more explanation for why japan is a tough industrial competitor : two of three japanese employees submit suggestions to save money , increase efficiency and boost morale , while only 9 % of american workers do . 
and the japanese make far more suggestions -- 9,999 per 999 eligible employees vs. only 99 per 999 employees in the 
data for 9999 from the national association of suggestion systems and the japan human relations association also indicate that japanese employers adopt four of five suggestions , while their u.s. counterparts accept just one in four . 
in japan , small suggestions are encouraged . 
each new employee is expected to submit four daily in the first few months on the job . 
u.s. companies tend to favor suggestions `` that go for the home runs , '' says gary UNKNOWN , vice president of corporate quality at control data corp .

UNKNOWN stevens , british air 's chief financial officer , told dow jones professional investor report a price of $ 999 a share is `` certainly not too low , '' and indicated his company would like to reduce the size of its $ 999 million cash investment . 
he added the airline is n't committed to going forward with any new bid , and has n't UNKNOWN in bankers ' efforts to revive the transaction that collapsed . 
`` we 're in no way committed to a deal going through at all . 
we 're not rushing into anything . 
we do n't want to be party to a second rejection , '' he said , adding that coming up with a revised offer could easily take several weeks . 
mr. stevens 's remarks , UNKNOWN a report in the wall street journal that british air wants to start from UNKNOWN in any new bid for the nation 's second-largest airline , helped push ual stock lower for the fourth straight day . 
ual fell $ 9.99 a share to $ 999.99 on volume of 9.9 million shares in composite trading on the new york stock exchange as concern UNKNOWN among takeover stock traders about the UNKNOWN of time it will take to revive the purchase . 
under the original buy-out approved by the ual board sept. 99 , ual 's pilots planned to put up $ 999 million in cash and make $ 999 million in annual cost concessions for a 99 % stake . 
ual management was to pay $ 99 million for 99 % , and british air was to receive a 99 % stake . 
the buy-out fell through when citicorp and chase manhattan corp. unexpectedly failed to obtain bank financing . 
since then , ual stock has fallen 99 % in what may rank as the largest collapse of a takeover stock ever . 
the UNKNOWN of mr. stevens 's remarks seemed to indicate that british air will take a more active , UNKNOWN role in pursuing any new bid . 
he said he believes ual management was badly advised on the funding of its original transaction . 
mr. stevens said british air has n't received any new buy-out proposals from the labor-management group , led by ual chairman stephen wolf , and has n't received any indication of when one might be UNKNOWN . 
`` as far as we 're concerned , we 're waiting for the dust to settle , '' he said . 
although british air is waiting to see what the buy-out group comes up with , mr. stevens said a revised transaction with less debt leverage is likely to be more attractive to banks . 
he said the original proposal is dead , and all aspects of a revised version are up for change , in light of the changes in ual 's market price , the amount of debt banks are willing to fund , and the price british air would be willing to pay . 
mr. stevens said he expects the new price will be considerably lower , but declined to specify a figure . 
asked whether a $ 999-a-share figure circulating in the market yesterday is too low , he said , `` it 's certainly not too low . '' 
he added the original offer was `` a pretty full price , '' and that british air 's contribution `` was quite a large chunk for us . '' 
british air was originally attracted to the chance of obtaining a 99 % stake in the company , but was n't particularly happy with paying $ 999 million . 
`` if the { new } deal had us putting up less money but still having 99 % , that would be a point in our favor , '' he said . 
in any new proposal , british air would expect a greater rate of return than the UNKNOWN in the original proposal . 
in the event that the buy-out group UNKNOWN in UNKNOWN its bid , the ual board could remain under some pressure to seek another transaction , even without any legal obligation to do so . 
roughly one-third of its stock is believed held by takeover stock traders , who could vote to oust the board if they become UNKNOWN . 
meanwhile , the buy-out group 's task of holding its fragile coalition together , in the face of the bid 's collapse and internal opposition from two other employee groups , has been further complicated by an apparent UNKNOWN in the ranks of the pilot union itself . 
a pilot representing a group of 999 pilots hired during united 's 9999 strike filed suit friday in chicago federal court to block the takeover . 
the dissident pilots oppose the plan because it would cause them to lose their seniority . 
ual 's management agreed to reduce the seniority of those pilots in exchange for the support of the united pilot union for the buy-out proposal . 
the 999 pilots involved in the suit are n't members of the union . 
the airline had allowed them to move ahead of some union members in seniority following the 9999 strike , a move the union had contested in a previous lawsuit .

corporate efforts to control health-care costs by requiring UNKNOWN prior to planned UNKNOWN and surgery have n't been sweeping enough to reduce the long-term rate of cost increases , according to a study by the institute of medicine . 
in the last decade , many corporations have embraced the `` utilization management '' cost UNKNOWN strategy as a way to control health-care costs for employees . 
these programs vary widely , but often require second opinions on proposed surgery , UNKNOWN reviews of UNKNOWN UNKNOWN and reviews of treatment during UNKNOWN or recovery periods . 
between 99 % and 99 % of today 's workers are covered by such plans , up from 9 % five years ago . 
`` although it probably has reduced the level of expenditures for some purchasers , utilization management -- like most other cost UNKNOWN strategies -- does n't appear to have UNKNOWN the long-term rate of increase in health-care costs , '' the institute of medicine , an affiliate of the national academy of sciences , concluded after a two-year study . 
`` employers who saw a short-term UNKNOWN in benefit expenditures are seeing a return to previous trends . '' 
while utilization management frequently reduces UNKNOWN costs , these savings are often offset by increases in UNKNOWN services and higher administrative costs , according to the report by a panel of health-care experts . 
the report suggested that current review programs are too narrow . 
`` the UNKNOWN and inappropriate use of the hospital , and not the actual need for a particular procedure , has been the main focus , '' the panel said . 
`` as a general rule , UNKNOWN programs have not made UNKNOWN UNKNOWN of the UNKNOWN costs of alternative UNKNOWN or sites of care . '' 
the report said that utilization management should have more of an impact as federal research on the UNKNOWN of medical UNKNOWN helps lead to medical practice guidelines . 
howard UNKNOWN , a panel member and a vice president of aetna life & casualty , said that utilization management will also do a better job of containing costs as it UNKNOWN to cover medical services delivered outside of hospitals . 
`` there 's pretty good evidence that utilization management has reduced inappropriate UNKNOWN , '' he said . 
but at the same time , spending on UNKNOWN services and UNKNOWN care have UNKNOWN . 
`` it 's like UNKNOWN a UNKNOWN , '' dr. UNKNOWN said . 
david UNKNOWN of a. foster UNKNOWN & co. said that clients of his consulting firm report that utilization management reduces their hospital care bills by about 9 % , but he agreed that for the health-care system as whole , some of these savings are offset by administrative and UNKNOWN care costs . 
UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , chairman of the panel , agrees that administrative costs of utilization management programs can be high . 
`` you have a whole staff standing ready '' to evaluate the UNKNOWN of recommended treatment , he said . 
dr. UNKNOWN , who also is president of new england medical center hospitals in boston , noted that the hospitals he runs deal with more than 999 utilization management firms and that many of them have different procedures and requirements . 
the panel urged greater efforts to reduce the UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN and cost of utilization review . 
`` utilization management needs to better UNKNOWN that it reduces the UNKNOWN use of resources , improves the UNKNOWN of patient care and imposes only reasonable burdens on patients and UNKNOWN , '' the panel concluded .

UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , a renault managing director , said the new line will cover trucks of between 9.9 tons and 9.9 tons and will be built at renault 's UNKNOWN plant in france and at daf 's british plant .

the federal reserve system is the standard UNKNOWN of suggestions for organizational and institutional changes , for two reasons . 
first , its position in the government is UNKNOWN . 
it has an unusual kind of independence from elected officials and still has authority over one of the most powerful of government 's instruments -- the control of the money supply . 
thus we have a condition that is easily described as undemocratic . 
second , the responsibilities of the federal reserve as guardian of the currency , which means as guardian of the stability of the price level , sometimes lead it to take measures that are UNKNOWN . 
as former fed chairman william UNKNOWN martin used to say , they would have to take the UNKNOWN UNKNOWN away just as the party is getting interesting . 
so the federal reserve is an attractive target for complaint by politicians . 
the fed is easily assigned the blame for UNKNOWN , like high interest rates or slow economic growth , while the politicians can escape responsibility by pointing to the fed 's independence . 
this leads to proposals for `` reform '' of the fed , which have the common feature of making the fed more responsive to the administration , to the congress and to public opinion -- without , however , any assumption of additional responsibility by the politicians . 
these proposals include changing the term of the chairman , UNKNOWN the terms of the members , eliminating the presidents of the federal reserve banks from the UNKNOWN process , putting the secretary of the treasury on the federal reserve board , having the fed UNKNOWN by an arm of congress ( the general accounting office ) , putting the fed 's expenditures in the budget , and requiring UNKNOWN publication of the fed 's minutes . 
some of these ideas are again under consideration in congress . 
but these proposals do not rest on a view of what the fed 's problem is or , if they do , they rest on an incorrect view . 
they would not solve the problem ; they would make it worse . 
the problem is not that the fed is too UNKNOWN to the public interest . 
on the contrary , it is too responsive to an incorrect view of the public interest . 
the price level in the u.s. is now about 9 9\/9 times as high as it was 99 years ago . 
on average , something that cost $ 999 99 years ago now costs $ 999 . 
or , a wage that was $ 999 99 years ago would buy only $ 99.99 worth of stuff today . 
on two UNKNOWN the inflation rate rose to more than 99 % a year . 
in each case the ending of this UNKNOWN inflation caused a severe recession -- the two worst of the postwar period . 
the enormous inflation over the past 99 years was largely due to monetary policy . 
at least , it would not have happened without the support of monetary policy that provided for a UNKNOWN increase in the money supply during the same period . 
and that increase in the money supply would not have happened without the consent of the federal reserve . 
the basic problem of monetary policy , to which reform of the fed should be addressed , is to prevent a UNKNOWN of this experience . 
there were two general reasons for the UNKNOWN monetary policy of the past 99 years : 
9 . to some extent the federal reserve shared the popular but incorrect view that UNKNOWN monetary policy could yield a net improvement in employment and output . 
9 . even where the fed did not share this view it felt the need to accommodate to it . 
despite all the formal provisions for its independence , the fed seems constantly to feel that if it uses its independence too freely it will lose it . 
the common proposals for UNKNOWN the fed would only make the situation worse , if they had any effect at all . 
putting the secretary of the treasury on the board of governors , one of the leading proposals today , is an example . 
the secretary is the world 's biggest UNKNOWN of money . 
he has a UNKNOWN , constant UNKNOWN for lower interest rates . 
moreover , he is a political agent of a political president , who naturally gives extraordinary weight to the way the economy will perform before the next election , and less to its UNKNOWN health . 
these days , the secretary UNKNOWN the further UNKNOWN that he is a member of a club of seven finance ministers who meet occasionally to decide what exchange rates should be , which is a UNKNOWN from the real business of the federal reserve to stabilize the price level . 
how should a reasonable member of the federal reserve board interpret a congressional decision to put the secretary on the board ? 
could he UNKNOWN interpret it as UNKNOWN for the fed to give primary emphasis to stabilizing the price level ? 
or would he interpret it as instruction to give more weight to these other objectives that the secretary represents -- low interest rates , UNKNOWN economic expansion , and UNKNOWN of exchange rates at internationally managed levels ? 
the answer seems perfectly clear . 
( true , a succession of fed chairmen has given color to the notion that the secretary of the treasury UNKNOWN on the fed . 
by their constant UNKNOWN to advise all and UNKNOWN about federal UNKNOWN matters the chairmen have encouraged the belief that fiscal policy and monetary policy are UNKNOWN of a common UNKNOWN , in which case it is natural that the fed and the treasury , and probably also the congress , should be jointly engaged in UNKNOWN the pot . 
the fed 's case for its own independence would be a little stronger if it were more UNKNOWN of the independence of the rest of the government . ) 
the fed 's problem is not that it is too independent , or too UNKNOWN . 
the fed is responsive to , and can not help being responsive to , the more UNKNOWN political part of the government . 
the fed UNKNOWN a power given to it by congress and the president . 
but congress and the president accept no responsibility for the exercise of the power they have given the fed . 
critics of the present arrangement are correct to say that it is undemocratic . 
what is undemocratic is the UNKNOWN of the more political parts of the government to take the responsibility for deciding the basic question of monetary policy , which is what priority should be given to stabilizing the price level . 
to leave this decision to an `` independent '' agency is not only undemocratic . 
it also UNKNOWN the conduct of a policy that has a long-term UNKNOWN , because it leaves the fed UNKNOWN about what are the expectations of its UNKNOWN , the politicians , who have never had to consider the long-term consequences of monetary policy . 
the greatest contribution congress could make at this time would be to UNKNOWN that stabilizing the price level is the primary responsibility of the federal reserve system . 
legislation to this effect has been introduced in congress in this session by rep. stephen neal ( d. , n.c . ) . 
it is not the kind of thing that is likely to be enacted , however . 
congress would be required to make a hard decision , and congress would much prefer to leave the hard decision to the fed and retain its rights of complaint after the fact . 
people will say that the nation and the government have other objectives , in addition to stabilizing the price level , which is true . 
but that is not the same as saying that the federal reserve has other objectives . 
the government has other agencies and instruments for pursuing these other objectives . 
but it has only the fed to pursue UNKNOWN stability . 
and the fed has at most very limited ability to contribute to the achievement of other objectives by means other than by stabilizing the price level . 
the two objectives most commonly thought to be legitimate competitors for the attention of the fed are high employment and rapid real growth . 
but the main lesson of economic policy in the past 99 years is that if the fed UNKNOWN with the UNKNOWN objective in the pursuit of these other goals , the result is not high employment and rapid growth but is inflation . 
a former chairman of the president 's council of economic advisers , mr. stein is an american enterprise institute fellow .

the foes of abortion hold the strong UNKNOWN hand in pennsylvania , where abortion-rights activists are so much on the defensive that their strategy is less to fight the proposed legislation than it is to stress how the state legislature does n't reflect the UNKNOWN of the state 's citizens .

this bill simply says that if you want to develop property on a barrier island you have to do so without taxpayer support .

however , home builders would have to bear the full costs of such UNKNOWN construction .

the government said 99.9 % of americans , or 99.9 million people , were living in poverty in 9999 . 
while last year 's figure was down from 99.9 % in 9999 and marked the fifth consecutive annual decline in the poverty rate , the census bureau said the 9999 drop was n't UNKNOWN significant . 
the bureau 's report also showed that while some measures of the nation 's economic UNKNOWN improved modestly in 9999 , the UNKNOWN of prosperity were shared less UNKNOWN than the year before . 
UNKNOWN data UNKNOWN from a march 9999 survey of 99,999 households , william UNKNOWN , associate director of the census bureau , said that `` most groups either stayed the same or improved . '' 
but , he added , `` since the late 9999s , the distribution of income has been slowly getting less equal . 
there was no reversal { of that trend } between 9999 and 9999 . '' 
per capita income , a widely used measure of a nation 's economic health , hit a record in 9999 , rising 9.9 % after inflation adjustment to $ 99,999 . 
but the median income of american families fell 9.9 % , the first time it has failed to rise since 9999 .

companies seeking to make insurers pay for pollution cleanup win court victory . 
in a case involving avondale industries inc. and its insurer , travelers cos. , the second u.s. circuit court of appeals in new york ruled in favor of the company on two issues that lawyers say are central to dozens of pollution cases around the country . 
travelers and other insurers have maintained that cleanup costs are n't damages and thus are n't covered under commercial policies . 
they also have argued that government proceedings UNKNOWN a company of potential responsibility do n't fit the legal definition of a lawsuit ; thus , such UNKNOWN proceedings are n't covered by the policies , the insurers say . 
the appeals court UNKNOWN on both counts . 
avondale was notified by louisiana officials in 9999 that it was potentially responsible for a cleanup at an UNKNOWN plant . 
avondale asked travelers to defend it in the state proceeding , but the insurer did n't respond . 
the appeals court upheld a district judge 's ruling that the insurer had to defend the company in such proceedings . 
the appeals court also said , `` we think an ordinary businessman reading this policy would have believed himself covered for the demands and potential damage claims '' stemming from any cleanup . 
`` this decision will have a very considerable impact , '' said kenneth UNKNOWN , professor of environmental law and insurance law at the university of virginia , because many commercial insurance policies are issued by companies based in new york . 
william UNKNOWN , an attorney for the chemical manufacturers association , said that while other appeals courts have ruled UNKNOWN on whether cleanup costs are damages , the influence of the appeals court in new york `` will make insurers sit up and listen . '' 
he said the decision was the first in which a federal appeals court has ruled whether administrative government proceedings qualify as litigation . 
barry r. UNKNOWN , an attorney for travelers , said , `` there are UNKNOWN bases on which this case will be appealed further . ''
