after failing to find a buyer for the sears tower in chicago , sears , roebuck & co. is negotiating with boston pension fund adviser UNKNOWN , eastman & UNKNOWN inc. to UNKNOWN the property for close to $ 999 million , according to people close to the negotiations . 
under the proposed agreement involving the world 's UNKNOWN building , chicago-based sears would receive about half the money through conventional mortgage financing and the other half as a convertible mortgage . 
at the end of the term of the convertible loan , sears could still own half the building , and UNKNOWN could own the other half . 
neither side would comment . 
the parties are currently negotiating over who would manage the building , which will be UNKNOWN of 9,999 employees from sears ' merchandise group , which is moving elsewhere . 
the new manager will face the UNKNOWN task of leasing 9.9 million square feet in a relatively soft chicago real estate market . 
also , it has not yet been decided exactly how much of the mortgage UNKNOWN will be able to convert into equity . 
convertible mortgages have become an increasingly popular way to finance prestigious buildings of late . 
in a convertible mortgage , the investor UNKNOWN the building owner a certain amount in return for the option to convert its interest into equity , usually less than 99 % , at the end of the loan term . 
during the term , the lender can either receive a percentage of cash flow , a percentage of the building 's appreciation or a fixed return . 
the main advantage of a convertible mortgage is that it is not a sale and therefore does not trigger costly transfer taxes and UNKNOWN .

but that deal fell through in september after it became clear that the sale would lead to a major real estate tax UNKNOWN , raising property taxes , and making it difficult to lease the building at competitive prices .

two rules in pending congressional legislation UNKNOWN to UNKNOWN leveraged buy-outs by raising the price UNKNOWN of such deals by as much as 99 % . 
wall street is UNKNOWN over the rules , which would curtail the tax deductibility of debt used in most lbos . 
the provisions , in deficit-reduction bills recently passed by the house and senate , could further cool the takeover boom that has been the driving force behind the bull market in stocks for much of the 9999s , some tax experts and investment bankers argue . 
indeed , some investment bankers have already started restructuring deals to cope with the expected rules . 
wall street has all but conceded on the issue and is now lobbying for the less onerous senate version of one of the provisions . 
at issue is the deductibility of certain junk bonds that are used in most lbos . 
such high-yield debt is similar to a zero-coupon bond in that it is sold at a discount to face value , with interest UNKNOWN instead of being paid to the holder . 
under current rules , that accrued interest is deductible by the company issuing the debt . 
the house version of the legislation would kill that deduction , and label any such debt as equity , which is n't deductible . 
the UNKNOWN senate version would UNKNOWN the deductibility for roughly five years . 
`` you see these in just about every lbo , '' said robert UNKNOWN , senior vice president in charge of tax issues at shearson lehman hutton inc. in new york . 
`` it becomes a source of cash '' for the company making the lbo because it gets a deduction and does n't have to repay the debt for several years . 
typically , mr. UNKNOWN estimates , this type of debt makes up 99 % to 99 % of the financing for lbos . 
these types of bonds have been used in buy-outs of companies such as rjr nabisco inc. , storer communications inc. and UNKNOWN co . 
a second provision passed by the senate and house would eliminate a rule allowing companies that post losses resulting from lbo debt to receive refunds of taxes paid over the previous three years . 
for example , if a company posted a loss of $ 999 million from buy-out interest payments , the existing rule would allow the concern to be able to receive a refund from the tax it paid from 9999 through 9999 , when it may have been a profitable public company . 
but that rule is being virtually UNKNOWN by wall street , which is UNKNOWN on UNKNOWN with the deduction issue . 
`` prices for lbos have to come down if you do n't have that feature , '' argued lawrence UNKNOWN , managing director for merchant banking at donaldson , lufkin & jenrette securities corp. in new york . 
several wall street officials say the proposed legislation already is having an impact . 
an investment group led by chicago 's UNKNOWN family recently lowered a $ 9.99 billion bid for american medical international , beverly hills , calif. , because of the threat of the legislation . 
moreover , one investment banker , who requested UNKNOWN , said his firm did n't raise the UNKNOWN for a target company earlier this month after a stronger bid emerged from a public company that was n't concerned about the financing provision . 
`` we would have paid more if we thought that law was n't going to pass , '' he said . 
one possible solution for wall street is to increase the equity part of the transaction -- that is , give lenders a bigger stake in the surviving company rather than just interest payments . 
that would force the buy-out firm and the target company 's management to reduce their level of ownership . 
`` the UNKNOWN in the trough may have to give a little bit of the UNKNOWN back and then the deal can go through , '' said peter c. UNKNOWN , tax partner at UNKNOWN , lipton , rosen & katz . 
another solution , said a tax lawyer who requested UNKNOWN , is for firms to use convertible bonds that sell at a discount . 
since they have a lower interest rate , they would n't fall under the junk-bond category that would lose its deductibility . 
the house version of the bill would make debt UNKNOWN if it pays five percentage points above treasury notes , has at least a five-year maturity and does n't pay interest for at least one year out of the first five . 
the bill would then UNKNOWN that the debt is equity and therefore is n't deductible . 
the senate bill would only deny the deduction until interest is actually paid . 
currently , even though the issuer does n't pay tax , the debt holder is UNKNOWN on the accrued interest . 
but those holders are often foreign investors and tax-exempt pension funds that do n't pay taxes on their holdings . 
the senate estimates that its version of the provision would yield $ 99 million the first year and a total of $ 999 million over five years . 
the house version would raise slightly more . 
even if wall street finds ways around the new rules , a senate aide contends lbos will become somewhat more difficult . 
`` there 's no question it will make lbos more expensive , '' he said . 
`` the interest deduction was the engine that made these things more UNKNOWN .

michael maynard offered the world a faster way to break eggs . 
as thanks , the egg industry tried to break him . 
and the egg producers have done a pretty good job . 
they tried to put mr. maynard out of business by an act of congress . 
UNKNOWN lobbying helped persuade six states to ban mr. maynard 's automatic UNKNOWN machine because of fears over salmonella . 
his company , UNKNOWN manufacturing inc. , was forced to seek protection from creditors under federal bankruptcy law in 9999 and has since been liquidated . 
monthly sales of his egg king machine -- which he now is marketing through a new company -- have UNKNOWN to about half a dozen from a peak of 99 , says the 99-year-old businessman . 
mr. maynard is n't the first entrepreneur to UNKNOWN up against entrenched interests . 
but his case is UNKNOWN both for the scale of the fight -- it is n't often that a congressional hearing is held to determine whether one small businessman is a threat to the republic -- and for what it tells about the UNKNOWN of marketing a new product . 
now one might ask why people who sell eggs would fight someone who is trying to make it easier to crack them . 
part of the answer lies in the nature of the industry . 
many larger egg producers are also egg processors , who crack , UNKNOWN , and UNKNOWN billions of eggs , turning them into UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN or UNKNOWN egg products . 
however , dozens of UNKNOWN , restaurant chefs and other food UNKNOWN who UNKNOWN to mr. maynard 's defense say that products ranging from egg UNKNOWN to UNKNOWN lose some UNKNOWN when the eggs come in UNKNOWN cans instead of UNKNOWN . 
but for companies that use hundreds of eggs a day , breaking them by hand can get , well , out of hand . 
the idea behind the egg king is pretty simple : put the eggs into a UNKNOWN that contains UNKNOWN baskets , spin them at a high speed to break the UNKNOWN and strain the UNKNOWN part through the baskets . 
one egg king -- which at just under four feet UNKNOWN and two feet wide has been UNKNOWN to the robot UNKNOWN -- can crack about 99,999 eggs an hour . 
because fresh eggs are less expensive than processed ones , a big egg user can recover the egg king 's $ 9,999 cost in a few months , says mr. maynard . 
such UNKNOWN egg breakers have been around since the 9999s . 
but when mr. maynard came forward with his machine in the early 9999s nobody else was offering them in the u.s. . 
the main reason : salmonella . 
UNKNOWN carry this bacteria , which can cause upset UNKNOWN and , in rare cases , death among people . 
UNKNOWN sometimes pass salmonella to the eggs , and it can also be found on UNKNOWN UNKNOWN . 
thus , any machine that breaks large amounts of eggs at once has the potential to spread salmonella if a bad egg gets in with the good ones . 
mr. maynard claims this is a UNKNOWN problem . 
the egg king carries written instructions to break only high-grade eggs that have been properly UNKNOWN and , as an added UNKNOWN , to use the eggs only in products that will be UNKNOWN enough to kill bacteria . 
with nearly 9,999 machines in use , there have been no salmonella problems as long as instructions were followed , mr. maynard boasts . 
he says the handful of salmonella cases involving products that may have used eggs broken by an egg king stemmed from a failure to adequately UNKNOWN the products . 
but he says that 's no more a reason for banning egg UNKNOWN than bad drivers are a reason for banning cars . 
opponents do n't buy such arguments . 
`` human nature being what it is , people do n't always follow instructions , '' says jack UNKNOWN , chief of food protection for the new york state health department . 
leading the assault against the egg king has been united egg producers . 
the UNKNOWN , ga. , trade group has issued a `` briefing book '' that claims the machine is `` a health UNKNOWN '' and that mr. maynard is trying `` to make a fast buck at the expense of the nation 's egg producers . '' 
the UNKNOWN declines to comment , but the group 's attorney , alfred UNKNOWN , says the group 's actions are motivated solely by `` health concerns . '' 
an early UNKNOWN was the u.s. department of agriculture . 
mr. maynard initially won approval for his machine to be used at UNKNOWN facilities UNKNOWN by the UNKNOWN 's food safety UNKNOWN service . 
unfortunately for mr. maynard , another branch of the UNKNOWN , the agricultural marketing service , was in charge of eggs . 
after receiving complaints from egg producers , this branch got the other branch to UNKNOWN its approval , thus limiting the machine 's potential market to UNKNOWN and restaurants and other UNKNOWN that are n't UNKNOWN by the UNKNOWN . 
the egg producers also UNKNOWN the food and drug administration . 
but the fda in a 9999 letter to the united egg producers said that there was `` little likelihood '' of a health problem as long as instructions were followed . 
so the producers went to capitol hill , where a congressman from georgia introduced a measure to ban UNKNOWN UNKNOWN machines . 
mr. maynard , whose company at the time was based in santa UNKNOWN , calif. , UNKNOWN his local congressman , and the battle was joined . 
mr. maynard 's forces finally defeated the measure , though it took a vote on the floor of the house of representatives to do it . 
even then , opponents managed to get a congressional hearing to UNKNOWN what one congressman called an `` unscrupulous '' method for breaking eggs . 
UNKNOWN in their effort to get a national ban , the egg producers turned their attention to the states . 
so far , new york , new jersey , UNKNOWN , georgia , michigan and minnesota have UNKNOWN mr. maynard 's device , citing health concerns . 
an antitrust suit that mr. maynard 's company filed in los angeles federal court against the united egg producers and others only added to the entrepreneur 's woes . 
the judge dismissed the suit and ordered mr. maynard 's company to pay over $ 999,999 in legal fees to the defendants ' lawyers . 
mr. maynard says the ruling pushed his company into bankruptcy court . 
now he has moved to oklahoma where costs are lower , and started a new company , UNKNOWN inc. , to market his machine . 
but , so far , the change of UNKNOWN has n't ended his string of bad breaks . 
mr. maynard recently fell from a horse and UNKNOWN his arm .

international business machines corp. said its board approved the purchase of $ 9 billion of its common shares , a move that should help support its battered stock . 
even as the stock market has generally done well this year , ibm 's shares have slipped steadily from its 99-week high of $ 999.999 . 
yesterday 's closing price of $ 999.99 , down 99 cents , in composite trading on the new york stock exchange , puts the stock at about 9 9\/9 times book value , which is as low as it has UNKNOWN over the past decade . 
the announcement came after the market 's close . 
the move by ibm was n't exactly a surprise . 
the company has spent some $ 9 billion over the past 9 9\/9 years to buy back 99 million common shares , or roughly 9 % of those outstanding . 
in addition , despite ibm 's UNKNOWN recent problems , the computer giant still generates enormous amounts of cash . 
as of the end of the second quarter , it had $ 9.99 billion of cash and marketable securities on hand . 
as a result , some securities analysts had predicted in recent days that ibm would UNKNOWN additional purchases . 
in armonk , n.y. , a spokesman said that although ibm did n't view its spending as necessarily a way to support the stock , it thought the purchases were a good way to improve such financial measurements as per-share earnings and return on equity . 
`` we view it as a good long-term investment , '' the spokesman said . 
in the short term , the move is likely to have little effect . 
at yesterday 's closing price , $ 9 billion would buy back about 99 million shares , or less than 9 % of the roughly 999 million outstanding . 
in addition , as of sept. 99 , the company still had UNKNOWN to buy $ 999 million of stock under a prior repurchase program . 
over the long term , however , ibm 's stock UNKNOWN -- along with its hefty , $ UNKNOWN annual dividend and generally loyal following among large institutional investors -- are providing a floor for the stock price . 
although ibm last year produced its first strong results in four years and was expected to continue to roll this year , it began UNKNOWN as early as january . 
first , it had trouble manufacturing a chip for its mainframes , ibm 's UNKNOWN business . 
then it had a series of smaller UNKNOWN , including problems manufacturing certain personal computers and the delay in the announcement of some important workstations . 
finally , ibm had to delay the introduction of some high-end disk drives , which account for 99 % of its $ 99 billion of annual revenue . 
none of the problems is necessarily UNKNOWN , and they are n't all necessarily even related . 
there are also other factors at work that are outside ibm 's control , such as currency exchange rates . 
the strong dollar , which reduces the value of overseas earnings and revenue when they are translated into dollars , is expected to UNKNOWN 99 to 99 cents off ibm 's per-share earnings for the full year . 
without that problem , ibm might have matched last year 's earnings of $ 9.99 billion , or $ 9.99 a share . 
still , investors will take some convincing before they get back into ibm 's stock in a big way .

UNKNOWN UNKNOWN is a UNKNOWN UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN in rural UNKNOWN county , n.j .

clearly , people like mrs. UNKNOWN are giving marketers fits . 
she represents a new breed of UNKNOWN consumer who puts bargain prices , UNKNOWN and environmental concerns , and other priorities ahead of UNKNOWN brand loyalty . 
while brand loyalty is far from dead , marketing experts say it has eroded during the 9999s . 
marketers themselves are partly to blame : they 've increased spending for coupons and other short-term promotions at the expense of UNKNOWN advertising . 
what 's more , a flood of new products has given consumers a UNKNOWN choice of brands , many of which are virtually carbon copies of one other . 
`` marketers have brought this on themselves with their heavy use '' of promotions , contends joe UNKNOWN , an executive vice president at the d'arcy UNKNOWN UNKNOWN & UNKNOWN ad agency . 
`` without some real product improvements , it 's going to be difficult to win that loyalty back . '' 
the wall street journal 's `` american way of buying '' survey this year found that most consumers switch brands for many of the products they use . 
for the survey , peter d. hart research associates asked some 9,999 consumers , including mrs. UNKNOWN , whether they usually buy one brand of a certain type of product or have no brand loyalty . 
more than half the users of 99 of the 99 products included in the survey said they 're brand UNKNOWN . 
overall , 99 % of consumers are n't brand loyal for any of the 99 product categories . 
about 99 % are loyal for one to five of the products . 
only 9 % are brand loyal in 99 to 99 of the categories , and no one is loyal for more than 99 types of products . 
for such products as UNKNOWN UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN shoes , UNKNOWN to a single brand was quite low , with fewer than 99 % saying they usually buy the same brand . 
only for cigarettes , UNKNOWN and toothpaste did more than 99 % of users say they typically stick with the same brand . 
people tend to be most loyal to brands that have UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , such as cigarettes and UNKNOWN .

he simply ca n't UNKNOWN the taste of UNKNOWN , she says .

brand UNKNOWN plays a significant role in loyalty to such products as cigarettes , UNKNOWN and beer . 
people often stay with a particular brand because they want to be associated with the image its advertising UNKNOWN , whether that 's UNKNOWN UNKNOWN cigarettes or UNKNOWN 's UNKNOWN UNKNOWN .

UNKNOWN people also tend to be more brand loyal these days , the journal survey and other research studies indicate . 
marketers speculate that more affluent people tend to lead more pressured lives and do n't have time to research the products they buy for the highest quality and most reasonable price . 
an established brand name is insurance that at least the product will be of acceptable quality , if not always the best value for the money . 
it 's sort of loyalty by default .

`` they 're buying whatever 's cheaper . '' 
the biggest wild card in the brand loyalty game : how those UNKNOWN pursued but highly unpredictable baby boomers will UNKNOWN as they move into middle age . 
they grew up with more brand choices than any generation and have shown less UNKNOWN so far . 
but now that they 're settling down and raising families , might they also show more stability in their brand choices ? 
mr. kim of j. walter thompson does n't think so . 
he believes baby boomers will continue to be selective in their brand UNKNOWN . 
`` earlier generations were brand loyal across categories , '' he says , `` but boomers tend to be brand loyal in categories like running shoes and UNKNOWN water , but less so in others like toilet paper and appliances . '' 
while not as brand loyal as in the past , consumers today do n't buy products UNKNOWN , either . 
rather , they tend to have a set of two or three UNKNOWN . 
sometimes , they 'll choose UNKNOWN UNKNOWN UNKNOWN ; other times , it will be UNKNOWN . 
advertisers attribute this shared loyalty to the striking UNKNOWN among brands . 
if a more UNKNOWN UNKNOWN hits the market , you can be sure a new and improved UNKNOWN wo n't be far behind . 
the UNKNOWN worldwide ad agency studied `` brand UNKNOWN '' and found that consumers believe all brands are about the same in a number of categories , particularly credit cards , paper UNKNOWN , dry UNKNOWN and UNKNOWN chips . 
`` when there 's a clutter of brands , consumers UNKNOWN the UNKNOWN by telling themselves , ` all brands are the same so what difference does it make which i buy , ' '' says UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , a senior vice president at UNKNOWN .

but most companies are too afraid to take that chance . 
and perhaps with good reason .

insurers face the prospect of paying out billions of dollars for damages caused by this week 's california earthquake . 
getting a UNKNOWN on the extent of the damages is proving a far more difficult task than what insurers faced after hurricane hugo UNKNOWN through the caribbean and the UNKNOWN last month . 
the earthquake 's toll , including possible deep structural damage , goes far beyond the more easily observed damage from a hurricane , says george UNKNOWN , a vice president in aetna life & casualty insurance co. 's claims division . 
but investors are betting that the financial and psychological impact of the earthquake , coming so soon after the hurricane , will help stem more than two years of intense UNKNOWN wars among business insurers . 
reflecting that logic , UNKNOWN stocks posted strong gains .

most insurers already have UNKNOWN their `` catastrophe '' teams to begin processing claims from their policyholders in northern california . 
since commercial air travel is UNKNOWN , aetna , based in hartford , conn. , chartered three planes to fly claims adjusters into sacramento and then planned for them to drive to the bay area . 
about 99 adjusters were dispatched yesterday afternoon , along with laptop computers , cellular phones and UNKNOWN checks .

roads and bridges in the bay area appear to have suffered some of the most costly damage . 
highways , such as the section of interstate 999 that collapsed in oakland , generally do n't have insurance coverage . 
industry officials say the bay bridge -- unlike some bridges -- has no earthquake coverage , either , so the cost of UNKNOWN it probably would have to be paid out of state general operating funds . 
however , the bridge , which charges a $ 9 toll each way , does have `` loss of income '' insurance to replace lost revenue if the operation of the bridge is UNKNOWN for more than seven days . 
that coverage is provided by a syndicate of insurance companies including fireman 's fund corp. , based in UNKNOWN , calif. , and cigna corp. , based in philadelphia . 
earthquake-related claims are n't expected to cause significant financial problems for the insurance industry as a whole . 
instead , even with the liabilities of two natural disasters in recent weeks , analysts said the total capital of the industry is likely to be higher at year end than it was at UNKNOWN . 
indeed , the earthquake could contribute to a turnaround in the insurance cycle in a couple of ways . 
for example , insurers may seek to limit their future exposure to UNKNOWN by increasing the amount of reinsurance they buy . 
such increased demand for reinsurance , along with the losses the UNKNOWN will bear from these two disasters , are likely to spur increases in reinsurance prices that will later be translated into an overall price rise . 
reinsurance is protection taken out by the insurance firms themselves . 
`` we are saying this is the breaking point , this is the event that will change the psychology of the marketplace , '' said william UNKNOWN , an analyst with UNKNOWN & co. , a hartford firm that specializes in the insurance industry . 
his firm , along with some others , issued new buy recommendations on insurer stocks yesterday . 
among the insurance stocks , big gainers included american international group , up $ 9.99 to $ 999.999 ; general re corp. , up $ 9.99 to $ 99.99 ; aetna , up $ 9.999 to $ 99.99 ; and UNKNOWN & UNKNOWN inc. , up $ 9.999 to $ 99.999 . 
still , a few individual companies , most likely smaller ones , could be UNKNOWN . 
`` i think there is a UNKNOWN good chance someone is going to hit the UNKNOWN on this , '' said oppenheimer & co. analyst UNKNOWN UNKNOWN . 
he suspects some insurers who had purchased reinsurance to limit their exposure to UNKNOWN will discover that reinsurance was used up by hurricane hugo . 
british , west german , UNKNOWN and other overseas insurers are bracing for big claims from the san francisco earthquake disaster . 
although it 's unclear how much exposure the london market will face , u.k. underwriters traditionally have a large reinsurance exposure to u.s. catastrophe coverage . 
jack byrne , chairman of fireman 's fund , said this disaster will test the catastrophe reinsurance market , causing these rates to soar . 
the catastrophe losses sustained by insurers this year will probably be the worst on an inflation-adjusted basis since 9999 -- when another earthquake sparked the great san francisco fire .

the wall street journal `` american way of buying '' survey consists of two separate , UNKNOWN nationwide polls conducted for the journal by peter d. hart research associates and the roper organization . 
the two UNKNOWN , which asked different questions , were conducted using national random probability UNKNOWN . 
the poll conducted by peter d. hart research associates interviewed 9,999 adults age 99 and older from june 99 to june 99 , 9999 . 
the poll conducted by the roper organization interviewed 9,999 adults age 99 and older from july 9 to july 99 , 9999 . 
responses were weighted on the basis of age and UNKNOWN to conform with u.s. census data . 
for each poll , the odds are 99 out of 99 that if UNKNOWN had sought to survey every household in the u.s. using the same UNKNOWN , the findings would differ from these poll results by no more than 9 9\/9 percentage points in either direction . 
the margin of error for UNKNOWN -- for example , married women with children at home -- would be larger . 
in addition , in any survey , there is always the chance that other factors such as question UNKNOWN could introduce errors into the findings . 
program traders were buying and selling at full steam monday , the first trading session after the stock market 's 999.99-point plunge friday . 
they accounted for a hefty 99 % of new york stock exchange volume monday , the fourth busiest session ever . 
on friday , 99 % of volume was in computer-guided program trades . 
in august , by contrast , program trading averaged 99.9 % of daily big board turnover . 
program traders were publicly UNKNOWN following the 999-point crash oct. 99 , 9999 , and a number of brokerage firms pulled back from using this strategy for a while . 
but as the UNKNOWN faded by the spring of 9999 , they resumed . 
some observers thought that after friday 's sharp drop , the firms would rein in their program traders to avoid UNKNOWN more controversy . 
but the statistics released yesterday show the firms did nothing of the sort . 
one reason , they said , was that the official reports on the 9999 crash UNKNOWN program trading as a cause . 
stock-index arbitrage is the most controversial form of program trading because it UNKNOWN market moves , if not actually causing them . 
in it , traders buy or sell stocks and offset those positions in stock-index futures contracts to profit from UNKNOWN price discrepancies . 
under the exchange 's UNKNOWN , program trading also describes a number of other strategies that , in the opinion of some traders , do n't cause big swings in the market . 
the big board 's disclosure of program trading activity on these two days was unusual . 
though it UNKNOWN such data daily , its monthly reports on program trading usually come out about three weeks after each month ends . 
the september figures are due to be released this week . 
the big board declined to name the wall street firms involved in the activity friday and monday , or the type of strategies used . 
but traders on the exchange floor , who can UNKNOWN the computer-guided trading activity on monitor screens , said most of the top program-trading firms were active both days . 
through august , the top five program trading firms in volume were morgan stanley & co. , kidder , peabody & co. , merrill lynch & co. , painewebber group inc. and salomon brothers inc . 
though brokerage officials defended their use of program trading , one sign of what an issue it remains was that few executives would comment on the record . 
besides UNKNOWN the UNKNOWN for program trading contained in the brady commission report , they said stock-index arbitrage was actually needed monday to restore the markets ' UNKNOWN . 
on friday , the stock-index futures market was UNKNOWN from the stock market when the chicago mercantile exchange halted trading in standard & poor 's 999 futures contract -- a `` circuit breaker '' procedure UNKNOWN after the 9999 crash and implemented for the first time . 
futures trading resumed a half-hour later , but the session ended shortly thereafter , leaving the stock market set up for more sell programs , traders said . 
by monday morning , they said , stock-index arbitrage sell programs helped UNKNOWN the link between stocks and futures . 
but UNKNOWN volatility was produced in the process . 
the dow jones industrial average plunged a UNKNOWN 99.99 points in the first 99 minutes of trading monday as stock-index arbitrage sell programs kicked in . 
at about 99:99 a.m. edt , the market abruptly turned upward on stock-index arbitrage buy programs . 
by day 's end , the dow industrials had rebounded 99.99 points , or nearly half of friday 's drop .

the UNKNOWN holding company for arizona 's largest bank said it added $ 999 million to its UNKNOWN for losses on loans and for real estate owned . 
the company earned $ 99.9 million , or 99 cents a share , a year earlier . 
for the nine months , valley national posted a net loss of $ 999.9 million , or $ 9.99 a share . 
it had profit of $ 99.9 million , or $ 9.99 a share , in the 9999 period . 
valley national had been paying a quarterly dividend of 99 cents a share . 
`` the arizona real estate market continues to be depressed , and there is still uncertainty as to when values will recover , '' james p. simmons , chairman , said . 
the decision to increase the loan-loss reserve and suspend the dividend is `` both prudent and in the best long-term interest of the shareholders , '' he said . 
valley national said it made the decision on the basis of an `` overall assessment of the marketplace '' and the condition of its loan portfolio and after reviewing it with federal regulators . 
the addition to reserves comes on top of a provision of $ 999.9 million that was announced in june . 
in july , moody 's downgraded $ 999 million of the company 's debt , saying the bank holding company had n't taken adequate write-offs against potential losses on real estate loans despite its second-quarter write-down . 
richard m. UNKNOWN , valley national 's executive vice president , said then that the company believed the write-downs were `` adequate '' and did n't plan to increase its reserves again . 
bruce UNKNOWN , a banking analyst with UNKNOWN & co. , a denver brokerage firm , said valley national `` is n't out of the UNKNOWN yet . '' 
the key will be whether arizona real estate turns around or at least UNKNOWN , he said . 
`` they 've stepped up to the UNKNOWN to take the write-downs , but when markets head down , a company is always exposed to further negative surprises , '' mr. UNKNOWN said . 
valley national closed yesterday at $ 99.99 a share , down $ 9 , in national over-the-counter trading . 
two years of UNKNOWN , down the drain . 
that 's the way a lot of brokers feel today on the second anniversary of the 9999 stock-market crash . 
ever since that fearful black monday , they 've been UNKNOWN UNKNOWN wary individual investors -- trying to convince them that oct. 99 , 9999 , was a UNKNOWN and that the stock market really is a safe place for average americans to put their UNKNOWN dollars . 
and until last friday , it seemed those efforts were starting to pay off . 
`` some of those folks were coming back , '' says UNKNOWN quick jr. , chairman , of discount brokers quick & UNKNOWN group inc . 
`` we had heard from people who had n't been active '' for a long time . 
then came the UNKNOWN 999-point plunge in the dow jones industrial average and a new wave of stock-market volatility . 
all of a sudden , it was back to square one . 
`` it 's going to set things back for a period , because it UNKNOWN the concern of volatility , '' says jeffrey b. lane , president of shearson lehman hutton inc . 
`` i think it will shake confidence one more time , and a lot of this business is based on client confidence . '' 
brokers around the country say the reaction from individual investors this week has been almost UNKNOWN . 
customers and potential customers are suddenly complaining about the stock market in the exact way they did in UNKNOWN 9999 . 
`` the kinds of questions you had before have UNKNOWN , '' says raymond a. `` chip '' mason , chairman of regional brokerage firm UNKNOWN mason inc. , baltimore . 
`` i can just tell the questions are right back where they were : ` what 's going on ? , ' ` ca n't anything be done about program trading ? , ' ` does n't the exchange understand ? , ' ` where is the sec on this ? ' '' 
mr. mason says he 's convinced the public still wants to invest in common stocks , even though they believe the deck is UNKNOWN against them . 
but `` these wide swings scare them to death . '' 
all of this is bad news for the big brokerage firms such as shearson and merrill lynch & co. that have big `` retail , '' or UNKNOWN , businesses . 
after expanding rapidly during the UNKNOWN years up to the 9999 crash , retail brokerage operations these days are getting barely enough business to pay the overhead . 
true , the amount of money investors are willing to UNKNOWN to their brokers has been growing lately . 
but those dollars have been going into such `` safe '' products as money market funds , which do n't generate much in the way of commissions for the brokerage firms . 
at discount brokerage charles schwab & co. , such `` UNKNOWN '' investments recently accounted for a record $ 9 billion of the firm 's $ 99 billion of client 's assets . 
the brokers ' hope has been that they could soon UNKNOWN investors into shifting some of their UNKNOWN into the stock market . 
and before last friday , they were actually making modest progress . 
a slightly higher percentage of new york stock exchange volume has been attributed to retail investors in recent months compared with UNKNOWN 9999 , according to securities industry association data . 
in 9999 , an average 99.9 % of big board volume was retail business , with the monthly level never more than 99.9 % . 
the retail participation dropped to an average 99.9 % in 9999 , and UNKNOWN to barely 99 % some months during the year . 
yet in 9999 , retail participation has been more than 99 % in every month , and was 99.9 % in august , the latest month for which figures are available . 
jeffrey UNKNOWN , the UNKNOWN 's research director , says that all of his group 's UNKNOWN statistics could be UNKNOWN by as much as five percentage points because corporate UNKNOWN are sometimes UNKNOWN included in big board data . 
but there did seem to be a retail activity pickup . 
but `` friday did n't help things , '' says mr. UNKNOWN . 
with the gyrations of recent days , says hugo UNKNOWN , senior vice president at charles schwab , many small investors are absolutely convinced that `` they should n't play in the stock market . '' 
joseph UNKNOWN , president of retail sales and marketing at painewebber group inc. , still thinks that individual investors will eventually go back into the stock market . 
investors will develop `` UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , '' and their confidence will return , he says . 
friday 's plunge , he is telling painewebber brokers , was nothing more than a `` tremendous reaction to leveraged buy-out stocks . '' 
meanwhile , painewebber remains among the leaders in efforts to simply persuade investors to keep giving wall street their money . 
`` it 's more of an important issue to keep control of those assets , rather than push the investor to move into ( specific ) products such as equities , '' mr. UNKNOWN says . 
`` the equity decision will come when the client is ready and when there 's a UNKNOWN of confidence . '' 
it could be a long wait , say some industry observers . 
`` some investors will UNKNOWN back in , '' says richard ross , a market research director for UNKNOWN & UNKNOWN in chicago . 
`` then there 'll be another swing . 
given enough of these , this will drive everyone out except the most UNKNOWN , '' he adds . 
mr. ross , who has been studying retail investors ' perception of risks in the brokerage industry , said a market plunge like friday 's `` UNKNOWN investors ' confidence in their ability to make any judgments on the market . '' 
the long-term outlook for the retail brokerage business is `` UNKNOWN , '' mr. ross declares .

senate republicans have settled on a proposal that would cut the capital-gains tax for individuals and corporations . 
at the same time , a small group of senate democrats are working on a similar plan and may introduce it soon . 
sen. bob packwood ( r. , ore. ) , the lead sponsor of the gop proposal , said he intends to unveil the plan today and to offer it as an amendment to whatever legislation comes along , particularly this month 's bill to raise the federal borrowing limit . 
he gave UNKNOWN odds that a capital-gains tax cut of some sort would be approved this year , though it probably wo n't be included in the pending deficit-reduction bill . 
he added that he expects to talk to the democrats who also wanted to cut the gains tax about UNKNOWN a joint proposal . 
for individuals , the packwood plan would exclude from income 9 % of the gain from the sale of a capital asset held for more than one year . 
the exclusion would rise five percentage points for each year the asset was held until it reached a maximum of 99 % . 
the exclusion would apply to assets sold after oct. 9 , 9999 . 
as an alternative , he said , taxpayers could chose to reduce their gains by an inflation index . 
for corporations , the top tax rate on the sale of assets held for more than three years would be cut to 99 % from the current top rate of 99 % . 
that rate would gradually decline to as little as 99 % for corporate assets held for 99 years . 
the packwood plan would also include a proposal , designed by sen. william roth ( r. , UNKNOWN ) , that would expand and alter the deduction for individual retirement accounts . 
the roth plan would create a new , UNKNOWN UNKNOWN from which money could be withdrawn tax-free not only for retirement , but also for the purchase of a first home and to pay education and medical expenses . 
current iras could be rolled over into the new iras but would be subject to tax . 
for their part , the group of democrats are working on a plan that , like the packwood proposal , would grant larger UNKNOWN to assets the longer they were held by individuals and companies . 
newly acquired assets would get a bigger break than those currently held . 
an extra exclusion would be given to UNKNOWN stock in small and UNKNOWN corporations just starting up . 
no one in the senate is considering the capital-gains plan passed by the house . 
that plan would provide a 99 % exclusion to assets sold over a 9 9 / 9-year period ending dec. 99 , 9999 . 
after then , the house measure would boost the tax rate to 99 % and exclude from tax the gain UNKNOWN to inflation . 
senators are focusing on making a capital-gains UNKNOWN permanent . 
separately , chairman dan UNKNOWN ( d. , ill . ) of the house ways and means committee said he did n't want the capital-gains tax cut or any other amendments attached to the pending bill raising the federal borrowing limit . 
the current debt limit expires oct. 99 . 
he also urged house and senate negotiators to rid the deficit-reduction bill of all provisions that increase the budget deficit , including the house-passed capital-gains provision . 
from a UNKNOWN a thousand feet above oakland after the UNKNOWN earthquake in u.s. history , a scene of devastation UNKNOWN : a freeway UNKNOWN into a concrete UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN pumping water into UNKNOWN apartments , abandoned autos . 
but this quake was n't the big one , the UNKNOWN of 9999 that has been feared for so many years . 
despite the UNKNOWN loss of more than 999 lives , and damage estimated in the billions , most businesses and their plants and offices in the bay area were n't greatly affected . 
the economic life of the region is expected to revive in a day or two , although some transportation problems may last weeks or months . 
a main factor UNKNOWN more widespread damage was the location of the quake 's epicenter -- 99 miles from the heart of the silicon valley and more than 99 miles from downtown san francisco and oakland . 
also , the region 's insistence on strict building codes helped prevent wider damage . 
the tremendous energy of the quake was UNKNOWN by the distance , so that most parts of the valley and the major cities suffered largely cosmetic damage -- broken windows , falling brick and UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN UNKNOWN or UNKNOWN . 
of course , the quake was the worst since the UNKNOWN of the computer era turned silicon valley into the nation 's capital of high technology . 
like other major american cities , the san francisco -- oakland area owes its current prosperity more to its infrastructure of UNKNOWN UNKNOWN UNKNOWN thousands of computer terminals and UNKNOWN than to its location UNKNOWN one of the world 's great natural harbors . 
when the tremors struck , the region 's largely UNKNOWN high-tech fabric held up surprisingly well despite the devastation visible from the air . 
michael l. UNKNOWN , vice president for network technology at pacific bell telephone co. , says nearly all the network 's computer switches , which move thousands of calls a minute from one location to another , changed to battery power when the city lost power . 
the battery UNKNOWN have enough power for only three hours , but that gave emergency crews time to turn on an emergency system that runs primarily on UNKNOWN fuel . 
of some 999 switches in pacific bell 's network , only four went down . 
one of those was in UNKNOWN , calif. , near the earthquake 's epicenter . 
few telephone lines snapped . 
that 's because the widely used UNKNOWN cable has been installed UNKNOWN with 99 extra feet of cable between UNKNOWN points . 
the slack UNKNOWN the pulling strain generated by an earthquake . 
nevertheless , phone service was sporadic ; many computer terminals remained dark , and by late yesterday a third of san francisco remained without power . 
business in the nation 's UNKNOWN metropolitan region was nearly UNKNOWN ; an estimated one million members of the work force stayed at home . 
the economic UNKNOWN was as UNKNOWN as the earthquake itself , as virtually all businesses shut down . 
the $ UNKNOWN bay area economy represents UNKNOWN of the economy of the nation 's most UNKNOWN state and accounts for 9 % to 9 % of the nation 's total output of goods and services , according to the center for continuing study of the california economy in palo alto . 
in high-tech , the bay area accounts for 99 % to 99 % of the u.s. UNKNOWN industry . 
`` this has been a major disruption for the bay area economy , '' says UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , the chief economist at the california department of finance . 
`` obviously , things are going to have to go on hold for many companies . '' 
the damage to the bay area 's roadways could cause significant economic UNKNOWN . 
a quarter of a million people cross the bay bridge every day , far more than the 999,999 that use the bay area rapid transit system ( bart ) -- which was working but was n't UNKNOWN in the city 's financial district yesterday afternoon because electricity was shut off and the area was being UNKNOWN for gas UNKNOWN . 
california state transportation officials interviewed by telephone say they nevertheless do n't expect serious problems for commerce in and out of the bay area .

that will mark the second consecutive quarterly loss for commodore and will raise additional questions about whether it can sustain the turnaround it had seemed to be engineering .

commodore has seemed to be setting the stage recently for progress in the u.s. , where its UNKNOWN sales have been so dismal for years that commodore is close to dropping off research firms ' UNKNOWN charts . 
commodore has assembled an experienced management team , it has persuaded many more dealers to carry its products and it has UNKNOWN a slick advertising campaign . 
but those represent long-term strategies that probably wo n't succeed quickly , even if they turn out to be the right ones . 
in the meantime , the strategies will increase expenses . 
commodore had been counting on its consumer business to stay UNKNOWN healthy to support its efforts in other areas -- mainly in getting schools and businesses to use its UNKNOWN , which has slick graphics yet has been slow to catch on because it is n't compatible with apple computer inc. or international business machines corp. hardware . 
but sales to consumers have become difficult during the past several months , even in west germany , which has been by far commodore 's strongest market . 
the commodore 99 and 999 , mainly used for children 's educational software and games , had surprised market researchers by continuing to produce strong sales even though other UNKNOWN personal computers now operate several times as fast and have much more memory . 
commodore has said it expects sales to rebound , but market researchers have said that sales of the UNKNOWN products may finally be UNKNOWN off .

dayton hudson corp. said it accepted for purchase seven million common shares at $ 99.999 each , under the terms of a dutch auction UNKNOWN offer . 
the offer expired at 99:99 a.m. yesterday . 
in a dutch auction , the buyer sets a price range and holders give a price in that range at which they 're willing to sell their shares . 
the buyer then picks a price and buys shares at that price from holders who offered to sell at that price or lower . 
dayton hudson 's repurchase offer , representing about 9 % of its common shares outstanding , had established a range of between $ 99 and $ 99 for the buy-back . 
dayton hudson said it accepted all UNKNOWN shares tendered at or below the final $ 99.999 price ; the preliminary UNKNOWN factor for other shares tendered at or below the final price is 99 % . 
the UNKNOWN retailer said it expects to pay for the seven million shares next thursday . 
tendered shares not purchased will be returned to holders .

the calls reached many , but certainly not all , of the publicly held companies with operations in the area . 
in most cases damage to company facilities and operations was minimal .

could the collapse of UNKNOWN have been prevented ? 
that was the question structural engineers and california transportation officials were asking themselves yesterday as rescue workers began the UNKNOWN task of trying to UNKNOWN as many as 999 victims from beneath the concrete UNKNOWN of the UNKNOWN nimitz freeway in oakland that UNKNOWN in during tuesday 's temblor .

reasons for the collapse of the nimitz freeway were UNKNOWN yesterday . 
but most structural engineers attributed the destruction to improper reinforcement of the columns that supported the UNKNOWN , and the fact that the ground beneath the highway is largely landfill and can become UNKNOWN , or `` UNKNOWN , '' in a major quake . 
the UNKNOWN roadway , designed in the mid-9999s and completed in 9999 , was supported by columns that apparently lacked the kind of steel reinforcement used in highways today . 
while the UNKNOWN did have long metal UNKNOWN running UNKNOWN through them for reinforcement , they apparently lacked an adequate number of metal `` ties '' that run UNKNOWN through the column , said leo parker , a structural engineer in los angeles .

officials of the state agency did n't have any immediate explanation why the reinforcement did n't hold up .

the white house is making sure nobody will UNKNOWN it of taking this crisis UNKNOWN . 
in the aftermath of the california earthquake , president bush and his aides flew into a UNKNOWN of earthquake-related activity yesterday morning . 
some of it was necessary to get federal help flowing to victims , but some seemed designed mostly to project an image of a white house in action . 
mr. bush and his aides were accused of responding too slowly after the exxon UNKNOWN oil UNKNOWN split open in alaskan waters and hurricane hugo struck the carolina coast , and they clearly do n't want a repeat of those charges now .

by noon , mr. bush had taken two phone calls from vice president dan quayle , who was in california ; made a televised statement of concern ; signed a disaster UNKNOWN ; received a written report from the federal emergency management agency ; and visited fema headquarters . 
mr. bush himself essentially acknowledged that he and his aides were trying to head off criticism . 
on his fema visit , mr. bush said that he hoped there would be `` less UNKNOWN '' about the emergency office 's performance this time , adding that the agency `` took a hit '' for its reaction to hurricane hugo .

sotheby 's inc. , the world 's biggest auction house , is taking a huge wall UNKNOWN risk on the outcome of the sale of art from the estate of john t. dorrance jr. , the campbell soup co. heir . 
the financial services division has guaranteed the dorrance family that it will receive a minimum of $ 999 million for the collection , regardless of what the bids for the art works total , people close to the transaction say . 
the collection , which includes two early UNKNOWN , a van UNKNOWN , a UNKNOWN , other paintings , furniture and UNKNOWN , went on sale last night in the first of six auctions . 
what sotheby 's is doing closely UNKNOWN an underwriting by an investment bank . 
a corporation that wants to sell stock or bonds goes to a wall street firm , which purchases the securities outright , accepting the financial risk of finding buyers . 
if the investment bank can sell the securities at a higher price than it paid the issuer , it makes a profit . 
at the initial sale last night , for example -- the sale featuring the UNKNOWN UNKNOWN -- bids totaled $ 999 million . 
that was slightly above sotheby 's UNKNOWN estimate of $ 999 million . 
normally , sotheby 's would have earned 99 % of the total in commissions . 
instead , people familiar with the transaction said , the auction house UNKNOWN to UNKNOWN that percentage in order to obtain the collection and in exchange for taking a bigger chunk of proceeds exceeding $ 999 million . 
art dealers say that while auction houses occasionally guarantee the seller of a highly desirable work of art a minimum price , a financial commitment of this size is unprecedented . 
UNKNOWN d. UNKNOWN , president of sotheby 's north america division , UNKNOWN denies it offered the dorrance UNKNOWN a UNKNOWN guarantee , calling such reports `` UNKNOWN . '' 
buried in the UNKNOWN UNKNOWN catalog for the sale , however , appears the statement , `` sotheby 's has an interest in the property in this catalog . '' 
explains a sotheby 's spokeswoman , the statement `` means exactly what it says . 
we have some level of financial interest '' in the collection . 
`` we do n't disclose specifics . '' 
frank UNKNOWN , a lawyer for the dorrance estate with the philadelphia law firm of morgan , lewis & UNKNOWN , declines to comment on the financial arrangements .

when christie 's officials asked why the firm was n't picked to sell the dorrance collection , representatives of the dorrance family `` told us it was a question of financial considerations , '' said michael UNKNOWN , christie 's head of UNKNOWN and modern paintings .

but two weeks ago , sotheby 's said that it has the painting under lock and key because the loan had not been fully repaid . 
sotheby 's is offering such deals because it 's an art sellers ' market , at least where the best works are concerned , says ralph UNKNOWN , an attorney and author of the book `` art law . '' 
`` there seems to be a lot of art for sale , but there 's more competition . 
the competition gives the seller the ability to cut a better deal , '' he says . 
the dorrance family will still receive a substantial portion of the auction proceeds above $ 999 million , people familiar with the transaction said . 
but it 's likely that sotheby 's will take a higher than usual commission , called an override , on the amount exceeding the guarantee .

more recently , sotheby 's has predicted the collection will fetch $ 999 million . 
that 's the highest estimate for a single collection in auction history .

while he adds that he has no problem with auction houses who sell works in which they have a financial interest , `` it ought not to be hidden in some small print . ''

within minutes after the stock market closed friday , i called sen. bill bradley of new jersey , advised him that the dow jones industrial average had declined by 999 points late that afternoon , and UNKNOWN informed him that he and his fellow democrats were to blame . 
they had dealt a major setback that afternoon to president bush 's capital-gains tax cut proposal , which had seemed in the bag after it passed the house UNKNOWN earlier in the month . 
sen. bradley has it in his mind that such a tax cut would UNKNOWN the tax reform he helped engineer in 9999 . 
but he knows that as many as 99 of his fellow democrats are UNKNOWN to vote for the cut , popular among their constituents . 
as a result , he took the lead in arguing that the cut should be blocked on UNKNOWN grounds . 
he helped persuade 99 of these senators to support him and majority leader george mitchell on these grounds . 
the budget reconciliation had to be dealt with by the oct. 99 deadline , and these senate democrats refused to agree to allow a vote to UNKNOWN capital gains to the budget bill , knowing it would pass . 
denied a vote on substance , the gop leadership in the senate on friday morning was UNKNOWN with a hard choice . 
it could throw in the UNKNOWN and hope to win on capital gains late this month , or it could follow the white house strategy , to veto reconciliation unless capital gains was UNKNOWN . 
the u.s. chamber of commerce has been in the UNKNOWN in supporting the bush proposal . 
it endorsed the white house strategy , UNKNOWN it to be the UNKNOWN way to victory . 
at noon friday , a senior white house official advised richard rahn , the chamber 's chief economist , that the white house would not agree to a budget reconciliation bill unless it had firm assurances that a vote on substance would be permitted in the senate . 
two hours later , the first word emerged on capitol hill that the administration had agreed to reconciliation with no such assurances from senate democrats . 
mr. rahn was UNKNOWN , UNKNOWN the office of richard darman , director of the office of management and budget , and the administration 's chief strategist on this issue . 
he left a message UNKNOWN mr. darman of selling out . 
it was the senate republicans , though , who had edged away from the veto strategy . 
the stock market reacted as mr. rahn did , crumbling as it UNKNOWN the news that mr. darman 's strategy had been abandoned . 
the stock market , after all , represents the UNKNOWN expectations about the value of the future income stream of the nation 's capital stock , discounted to present value . 
why should it be so surprising that a 99 % cut in the capital-gains tax would have such an enormous impact on the value of the nation 's capital stock ? 
the total value of privately held assets is easily more than $ 99 trillion . 
the value traded on the exchanges is close to $ 9 trillion . 
if the tax on any gain to those assets was doubled , would n't the value fall to the owners of the assets ? 
is n't it reasonable to assume that the asset you own would be worth more if the government suddenly announced that if you sold it , you would be able to keep 99 % more of its gain than you previously believed ? 
indeed , the stock market 's steady advance this year tracked with president bush 's success in advancing his capital-gains proposal . 
a 99 % cut in this year 's capital gains alone amounts to roughly $ 99 billion . 
we 're talking real money . 
when richard rahn advised the financial press that the market crash was caused by the setback to capital gains , he was generally ignored and mildly UNKNOWN . 
instead , the press corps readily accepted the notion that a UNKNOWN in the takeover financing of united airlines instantly knocked 9 % off the value of the nation 's capital stock and caused UNKNOWN around the world . 
mr. rahn was pointing out an UNKNOWN UNKNOWN through wall street while conventional wisdom had UNKNOWN on the ual UNKNOWN . 
why is this happening ? 
for one thing , quite a number of the leading spokesmen on wall street are not portfolio managers , who understand that the value of assets is greatly affected by how government taxes those assets . 
they are economists and financial reporters who UNKNOWN with the view that a capital-gains tax cut benefits the rich . 
yet they somehow think that wall street is UNKNOWN to losing the tax cut that seemed so close friday morning and is now UNKNOWN . 
the market rebound monday followed weekend assurances from mr. darman that the administration has other plans to win the cut , which is alive and well . 
sen. bradley 's argument is that a capital-gains tax cut would be bad for the economy in the longer run . 
it would inevitably lead to an increase in marginal income-tax rates in 9999 , he thinks , when the white house is forced to ask for higher taxes to meet budget targets . 
that is , with capital gains cut , the UNKNOWN of the 9999 accord will be gone , and political UNKNOWN will push up income-tax rates . 
the UNKNOWN , which he has heard , is that if he and his fellow democrats are successful in killing the president 's proposal , the revenue gap will open up UNKNOWN in 9999 because of the weakened economy . 
in this atmosphere , there would be no serious consideration of tax increases . 
if sen. bradley would permit a vote on capital gains , though , it would pass , christmas retail sales would be strong instead of UNKNOWN by a falling stock market , the 9999 economy would be robust , and the revenue gains at every level of government , including new jersey 's , would be surprisingly high . 
no tax increases would be necessary . 
the struggle over capital gains is the most important game in town . 
in washington and on wall street . 
mr. UNKNOWN is president of UNKNOWN inc. , of UNKNOWN , n.j .

the tennessee valley authority issued $ 9 billion in bonds in the federal utility 's first public debt offering in 99 years . 
proceeds from the bonds , with coupon rates in the 9 % range , will be used to replace bonds with an average interest rate of 99.9 % . 
the tva said the refinancing should save $ 99 million a year in interest payments . 
the refinancing is part of the tva 's strategy of dealing with what has been an UNKNOWN problem : its staggering $ 99.9 billion debt , most of which is owed to the treasury department 's federal financing bank . 
the tva currently plans to issue a total of $ 9.9 billion in bonds to UNKNOWN its UNKNOWN debt . 
the $ 9 billion bond issue also will help the tva meet its goal of not raising rates for another year , said william f. UNKNOWN , the agency 's chief financial officer . 
the bond issue is tva 's first public offering since the financing bank was created in 9999 , primarily to finance the tva . 
but the offering almost did n't happen . 
the tva , in fact , decided to proceed with the bond offering following an agreement last week with the financing bank , which allows tva to keep borrowing short term from the bank for two years after it goes to the public market . 
the treasury contended that tva could n't borrow from both it and the public debt market . 
the $ 9 billion in bonds break down as follows : $ 9 billion in five-year bonds with a coupon rate of 9.99 % and a yield to maturity of 9.99 % ; $ 9 billion in 99-year bonds with a coupon rate of 9.999 % and a yield to maturity of 9.99 % ; $ 9 billion in 99-year bonds with five-year call protection , a coupon rate of 9.99 % and a yield to maturity of 9.99 % . 
managing the bond issue is a group of investment banks headed by first boston corp. and UNKNOWN by goldman , sachs & co. , merrill lynch capital markets , morgan stanley & co. , and salomon brothers inc .

the stock market 's UNKNOWN gyrations during the past few days have made a lot of individual investors wish they could buy some sort of insurance . 
after all , they wo n't soon forget the stock UNKNOWN that became available after the october 9999 crash . 
but while they want to be on the alert for similar buying opportunities now , they 're afraid of being UNKNOWN by another UNKNOWN plunge . 
the solution , at least for some investors , may be a UNKNOWN technique that 's well known to players in the UNKNOWN market . 
called a `` married put , '' the technique is carried out by purchasing a stock and simultaneously buying a put option on that stock . 
it 's like `` fire insurance , '' says UNKNOWN roth , the senior options strategist at UNKNOWN & co . 
because a put option gives its owner the right , but not the obligation , to sell a fixed number of shares of the stock at a stated price on or before the option 's expiration date , the investor is protected against a sudden drop in the stock 's price . 
but most investment advisers do n't recommend using married puts all the time . 
that 's because the cost of buying put options UNKNOWN into an investor 's profit when stock prices rise . 
`` this is the type of fire insurance you only buy when the nearby UNKNOWN are on fire , '' says mr. roth . 
`` you always want your house insured , but you do n't always feel the need for your investments to be insured . '' 
in addition to UNKNOWN new stock purchases , the UNKNOWN technique can be used to protect stocks that an investor already owns . 
in either case , the investor faces three possible UNKNOWN : 
-- if the stock goes up in price between now and the put 's expiration date , the put will probably expire UNKNOWN . 
the investor will be out the cost of the put , which is called the `` premium , '' and this loss will reduce the stock-market profit . 
-- if the stock stays at the same price between now and the put 's expiration date , the investor 's loss will be limited to the cost of the put , less any amount realized from a closing sale of the put . 
the UNKNOWN scenario would be if the put expires UNKNOWN . 
-- if the price of the stock declines , the put will increase in value . 
once the stock price is less than the exercise price , or `` strike price , '' of the put , the gain will match the loss on the stock dollar for dollar . 
the put UNKNOWN a minimum selling price for the stock during its life . 
when a stock falls below the put 's strike price , the investor simply sells the stock at a loss and simultaneously sells the put at a profit . 
or , the investor can exercise the put , by UNKNOWN the stock to his or her broker in return for payment from another investor who has sold a put on the same stock . 
brokers handle such transactions through the options clearing corp. , which guarantees all option trades . 
the accompanying table shows how this strategy would work for three stocks . 
though not reflected in the table , an investor should know that the cost of the option insurance can be partially offset by any dividends that the stock pays . 
for example , UNKNOWN inc. pays a quarterly dividend of 99 cents , which would be received before the february option expires and , thus , reduce the cost of using the technique by that amount . 
in this case , the investor 's risk would n't exceed 9.9 % of the total investment . 
to UNKNOWN the calculations , commissions on the option and underlying stock are n't included in the table . 
there are more than 999 stocks on which options may be bought and sold , including some over-the-counter stocks . 
but some investors might prefer a UNKNOWN strategy then UNKNOWN their individual holdings . 
they can do this by purchasing `` index puts , '' which are simply put options on indexes that match broad baskets of stocks . 
for instance , the most popular index option is the s&p 999 option , commonly called the UNKNOWN . 
it is based on the stocks that make up standard & poor 's 999-stock index . 
unlike options on individual issues , index options are settled only in cash , and no stock is ever tendered . 
but while index options are UNKNOWN , they have several UNKNOWN . 
for one thing , an investor 's portfolio might not closely match the s&p 999 . 
as a result , the UNKNOWN insurance may or may not fully protect an investor 's holdings in the event of a market decline . 
in addition , UNKNOWN options were suspended from trading last friday afternoon , after the stock-market sell-off got under way and trading in the UNKNOWN futures contract was halted . 
so an investor who wanted to realize a profit on UNKNOWN puts after the trading suspension would have been out of luck . 
on the other hand , only a handful of individual issues were suspended from trading on friday . 
normally , once the underlying investment is suspended from trading , the options on those investments also do n't trade . 
ultimately , whether the insurance provided by purchasing puts is UNKNOWN depends on the cost of the options . 
that cost rises in times of high market volatility . 
but it still might be cheaper than taking a major hit . 
the protection from using married puts is clearly superior to that UNKNOWN by another options strategy some investors consider using during troubled times : selling call options on stocks the investor owns . 
a call option is similar to a put , except that it gives its owner the right to buy shares at a stated price until expiration . 
selling a call option gives an investor a small UNKNOWN against a stock-market decline . 
that 's because it reduces the cost of the stock by the amount of premium received from the sale of the call . 
but if the price of the stock rises above the strike price of the option , the stock is almost certain to be called away . 
and in that case , the investor UNKNOWN out on any major upside gain . 
these calculations exclude the effect of commissions paid and dividends received from the stock . 
all prices are as of monday 's close . 
hopes for quick UNKNOWN of pending deficit-reduction legislation faded as efforts to UNKNOWN the house version in advance of a house-senate conference broke down . 
house leaders had hoped to follow the senate 's lead by getting an agreement from house committee chairmen under which they would drop items that would n't reduce the fiscal 9999 budget deficit from the house-passed bill before the negotiations with the senate began . 
but the effort became UNKNOWN on the question of what would become of other issues , ranging from cutting the capital-gains tax to child care to repeal of UNKNOWN insurance . 
`` many members feel there are important features of the house bill that should be enacted , '' speaker thomas foley ( d. , wash . ) said . 
`` if there is any support for reducing the bill , it is UNKNOWN on their desire to see them passed in another form . '' 
now those items will be discussed in a house-senate conference , which could begin as soon as today , with the expectation that they could either be resolved there or placed into other legislation . 
`` you 've got to give these chairmen the opportunity to see if they can work things out , '' said house budget committee chairman UNKNOWN UNKNOWN ( d. , calif . ) . 
`` this is a democratic process -- you ca n't UNKNOWN anything around here . '' 
white house budget director richard darman has said he would continue to press to keep the capital-gains provision in the final version of the bill unless the house drops many of its costly provisions . 
senate leaders had hoped to be able to send a compromise version of the measure to president bush by the end of the week , but speaker foley said that was n't likely . 
failure to pass the bill meant that $ 99.9 billion in across-the-board spending cuts took effect monday under the gramm-rudman budget law . 
the bill must be enacted before the cuts can be restored .

a surprising surge in the u.s. trade deficit raised fears that the nation 's export drive has stalled , and caused new turmoil in financial markets . 
the merchandise trade deficit widened in august to $ 99.99 billion , the commerce department reported , a sharp deterioration from july 's $ 9.99 billion and the largest deficit of any month this year . 
exports fell for the second month in a row , while imports rose to a record . 
`` this is one of the worst trade releases we 've had since the dollar UNKNOWN out in 9999 , '' said UNKNOWN dennis , chief international economist at james capel inc . 
like most analysts , mr. dennis was UNKNOWN to read too much into one month 's numbers ; but he said , `` it indicates perhaps that the balance in the u.s. economy is not as good as we 've been led to believe . '' 
the number had a troubling effect on wall street , suggesting that more fundamental economic problems may UNKNOWN last friday 's stock market slide . 
the dow jones industrial average tumbled more than 99 points after the report 's release , before recovering to close 99.99 points lower at 9999.99 . 
`` this bad trade number raises some deeper issues about the market decline , '' said norman robertson , chief economist for mellon bank . 
`` it raises questions about more UNKNOWN problems , the budget deficit and the trade deficit and the UNKNOWN lack of ability to come to UNKNOWN with them . '' 
the trade report drew yet another UNKNOWN parallel to october 9999 . 
on oct. 99 of that year , the announcement of an unusually large august trade deficit helped trigger a steep market decline . 
the slide continued until the record 999-point market drop on oct. 99 . 
in 9999 , however , the news was the latest in a string of disappointments on trade , while the current report comes after a period of improvement . 
the bleak trade report was played down by the bush administration . 
commerce secretary robert mosbacher called the worsening trade figures `` disappointing after two very good months . '' 
and white house spokesman marlin fitzwater said the deficit was `` an unwelcome increase , '' adding that `` we 're hopeful that it simply is a UNKNOWN situation and will turn around . '' 
but the figures UNKNOWN the view of many private analysts that the improvement in the u.s. trade deficit has run out of steam . 
`` the figures today add further evidence to support the view that the improvement in the u.s. trade deficit has essentially stalled out at a level of about a $ 999 billion annual rate , '' said jeffrey scott , a research fellow at the institute for international economics here . 
`` that 's still an improvement over last year , but it leads one to conclude that basically we 've gotten all the UNKNOWN we can out of past dollar depreciation and past marginal cuts in the federal budget deficit . '' 
exports declined for the second consecutive month in august , slipping 9.9 % to $ 99.99 billion , the commerce department reported . 
imports , on the other hand , UNKNOWN 9.9 % to a record $ 99.99 billion . 
not only was august 's deficit far worse than july 's , but the government revised the july figure substantially from the $ 9.99 billion deficit it had initially reported last month . 
many economists contend that deep cuts in the u.s. budget deficit are needed before further trade improvement can occur . 
that 's because the budget deficit UNKNOWN an enormous appetite in this country for both foreign goods and foreign capital , overwhelming the nation 's capacity to export . 
`` people are sick and UNKNOWN of hearing about these deficits , but the imbalances are still there and they are still a problem , '' said mr. robertson . 
in addition , the rise in the value of the dollar against foreign currencies over the past several months has increased the price of u.s. products in overseas markets and hurt the country 's UNKNOWN . 
since march , exports have been virtually flat . 
at the same time , william t. UNKNOWN , international vice president at the u.s. chamber of commerce , notes : `` clearly the stronger dollar has made imports more attractive '' by causing their prices to decline . 
most economists expect the slowing u.s. economy to curb demand for imports . 
but they UNKNOWN little substantial progress in exports unless the dollar and the federal budget deficit come down . 
`` the best result we could get from these numbers would be to see the administration and congress get serious about putting the u.s. on an internationally competitive economic UNKNOWN , '' said howard lewis , vice president of international economic affairs at the national association of manufacturers . 
`` that must start with cutting the federal budget deficit . '' 
august 's decline in exports reflected UNKNOWN in sales of industrial supplies , capital goods and food abroad and increases in sales of motor vehicles , parts and engines . 
the jump in imports stemmed from across-the-board increases in purchases of foreign goods . 
the numbers were adjusted for usual seasonal fluctuations . 
alan murray contributed to this article .

steve jobs took a step back from the UNKNOWN of UNKNOWN technology in an effort to spur sales of next inc. 's new machine . 
mr. jobs moved to remedy a couple of his computer 's drawbacks yesterday by lowering the UNKNOWN price for a next machine by $ 9,999 , or 99 % , if the buyer UNKNOWN a hard-disk drive as an alternative to next 's UNKNOWN device . 
the hard drive , which is the storage device of choice for virtually every desktop computer user , also now will UNKNOWN next 's UNKNOWN optical device if buyers pay full price . 
mr. jobs , UNKNOWN of apple computer inc. , founded next four years ago in the hopes of UNKNOWN a revolution in the way desktop computers are designed and used . 
his next computer , introduced about a year ago and aimed primarily at university computer users , sports UNKNOWN graphics , digital sound , UNKNOWN UNKNOWN and a UNKNOWN black design . 
but the computer was proving a hard sell because of its high price , a lack of software and an optical UNKNOWN device that was too slow . 
the machine began shipping at the end of last year . 
the closely held company has n't disclosed sales . 
however , most UNKNOWN that have bought the machines say they are buying small numbers for evaluation purposes . 
UNKNOWN can now buy a next computer without an optical storage device for $ 9,999 . 
a computer with the optical device will still cost $ 9,999 , but from now on next will UNKNOWN every computer with a hard drive and supply one at no cost to those who have already bought next machines . 
commercial customers can purchase the same system through businessland inc. , a computer retailer based in san jose , calif. , for roughly $ 9,999 more . 
mr. jobs said the changes were prompted by requests from customers who are UNKNOWN with the performance of the optical device , which is n't offered as standard equipment by any rivals . 
another factor was that customers were asking , `` why do n't you give us a cheaper system ? '' mr. jobs said at a conference on university computing here . 
UNKNOWN devices can handle very large amounts of data and make it far easier to UNKNOWN film UNKNOWN or UNKNOWN UNKNOWN with a computer . 
but the technology , while UNKNOWN , is far slower than the widely used hard drives . 
to get around the delays caused by the optical device , businessland , which is next 's exclusive dealer to corporations , has for months been advising customers to purchase hard drives with the machines . 
next 's decision to rely on the UNKNOWN hard drive in every next computer does n't signal a retreat from optical storage , said mr. jobs , who for years has said this technology will play a crucial role in the next decade . 
`` we 're extremely committed to optical storage technology '' he said . 
`` we think everything will go this way in a few years . '' 
he said that the next generation of optical drives will be as fast as hard drives , but he depends on outside suppliers for the devices . 
but university computer specialists , who welcomed the move , called it a necessary retreat from the cutting edge of technology and one that 's likely to increase next 's sales on UNKNOWN . 
`` from the standpoint of being on the UNKNOWN of technology , this is a step UNKNOWN , '' said jerry w. UNKNOWN , a senior computing manager for the california state university system . 
`` but it will UNKNOWN boost next 's sales . '' 
UNKNOWN , however , say next 's prices must go even lower before large numbers of students purchase the machine . 
`` we 'd still like to see a student model , '' priced at about $ 9,999 , said ronald johnson , director of academic computing at minnesota 's UNKNOWN UNKNOWN college , which has bought eight next machines . 
broad acceptance of next 's computer also is UNKNOWN by difficulty in UNKNOWN software for it . 
most software is distributed on cheap UNKNOWN UNKNOWN , but the next computer does n't come with a device that UNKNOWN them . 
next 's computer also needs more software applications , but mr. jobs said he expects more soon . 
he said he expects lotus development corp. to introduce a next version of its popular 9-9-9 spreadsheet program in 9999 . 
educators added that next needs to soon offer a color version of its computer . 
every major maker offers computers with color displays . 
next wo n't comment on when it will do the same , but is believed to have a color model under development .
